LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: YOU COULD CALL IT A WAR game. Let's say you were a young Frenchman during the Occupation and you chose the losing side, the wrong side, the German side. Let's say you were tried in absentia and sentenced to death as a war criminal.
LEAD: An article on Sept. 17 about fall lectures gave an incorrect date for a talk by Daniel Robbins at the Neuberger Museum in Purchase about the museum's collection. It is Oct. 29, not Oct. 20.

LEAD: Every museum director dreams of the exemplary acquisition - the one that will appear to have found its way to the museum with a beautiful inevitability. Almost never, of course, does it happen like that. But that is how it can look in retrospect, just as when we have watched a golfer hole out in one we forget that, before the little white ball nestled down at the bottom of the hole, luck, wind, weather and a supreme degree of nervous concentration all had a part to play.
LEAD: YIDDISH THEATER

LEAD: Just a week ago, after watching a rout of his Duke squad, Coach Steve Spurrier pronounced his team's chances of victory in the coming game against Clemson as one in a million. Today, that most improbable triumph came to pass, as the Blue Devils defeated the previously unbeaten Tigers, 21-17.

LEAD: The only top hat seen at the Metropolitan Opera's opening Monday was worn by David McDermott, an artist. The opera was ''Aida,'' and Michel Orloff, a descendant of Ismail Pasha, who commissioned the opera in l870, attended. Later, at the Waldorf-Astoria, Saul Steinberg rang the dinner bell at a dance honoring Carolyne Roehm and Henry Kravis for their philanthropy.

LEAD: Luciano Pavarotti has canceled his series of performances in ''La Gioconda'' at the Metropolitan Opera in January because he must undergo treatment for sciatic nerve inflammation, the company has announced. The tenor Nicola Martinucci will replace him in the first two performances, on Jan. 15 and 19.
LEAD: SMYTHE DIVISION
LEAD: Stephanie Johns missed the basic point underlying hospice care in her letter.

LEAD: At a dramatic pace that would have been unthinkable only a year ago, the Vatican and the Eastern bloc have begun to forge fundamental changes in their relationship, easing mutual suspicions and lowering diplomatic barriers that had been intact for decades.

LEAD: The site, at Avenue I and East 16th Street in the Midwood section of Brooklyn, is not promising. On one side, the Q and D trains of the IND subway line go rattling by. A hundred feet away, the Long Island Rail Road runs four freight trains a night.

LEAD: Because of the Pulaski Day Parade, Fifth Avenue between 26th and 52d Streets will be closed today from noon to 4 P.M.

LEAD: Farming is always a gamble, but this year Richard Rice and his son Michael are putting down a bigger wager than usual. They are using about 130 of their 1,000 acres to plant a crop that most American farmers have never produced.

LEAD: For whatever reasons, Stephanie Johns's letter to the New Jersey editor on Aug. 20 is a bitter and angry attack on the ''freestanding'' hospice. As a volunteer for the Center for Hope Hospice in Roselle, I would like to offer comments that might have a salutary result for her.

LEAD: THE last two times I was on the road for research, I started gathering information on new types of inexpensive accommodations along the highway or near the airport. Three of four of the places explored were parts of chains, so you could reasonably expect to find the same thing each time.

LEAD: An Alabama cornerback, John Mangum, halted a frantic Vanderbilt rally with a pass interception at the 16-yard line today as the 13th-ranked Crimson Tide held off the Commodores, 20-14, in a Southeastern Conference matchup.

LEAD: MINGUS/MINGUS: Two Memoirs. By Janet Coleman and Al Young. (Creative Arts Book Company, $14.95.) Charles Mingus was one of the more tempestuous talents of jazz: a bassist, bandleader, composer and dynamo of creativity who never let up. Two of his friends wrote this recollection of his life and times.

LEAD: At St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn., Margaret Elizabeth Tsang, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew W. Tsang of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Eugene Anthony Miao, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ling Miao of Palos Verdes, Calif. The Rev. Leo Gorman officiated.

LEAD: WITH Strindberg, Shakespeare and Shaw at Yale Rep, Buchner, Moliere and Wilde at Hartford Stage and Feydeau at the Long Wharf, the new theater season has the makings of an international playwrights festival.

LEAD: The space agency Friday named astronaut crews for five shuttle missions. Those named included Dr. Mae C. Jemison, the first black woman selected for space flight.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: BENEATH THE STANDARD FRENCH ROAD SIGN FOR ST.-Sauveur-en-Puisaye, in Burgundy, another larger one proclaims with elaborate flourish that this is ''Colette's Country.'' In the village itself, crude hand-lettered wooden arrows point the way to the house where she was born. Dun-colored signs identify every street but one - there, on fresh royal-blue enamel (blue was her favorite color), a sharp white replica of her signature marks the ''Rue Colette.

LEAD: Sony is buying into Hollywood. Columbia Pictures accepted a $3.4 billion offer from the Japanese electronics giant. Columbia produces several successful television series but its movie division has lagged. The biggest attraction for Sony executives, led by the president, Norio Ohga, apparently was the 2,700 films in Columbia's library.

LEAD: Golf Kite Leads U.S. Into Title Match: Tom Kite converted mistakes by Christy O'Connor of Ireland into a playoff victory that sent the United States into the championship match in the Dunhill Cup tournament yesterday at St. Andrews, Scotland. O'Connor put his ball into a stream on the first extra hole of the decisive match.

LEAD: Letitia Humphreys Barroll, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Barroll of Baltimore, was married yesterday to James Bradley Frederick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore J. Frederick of New Britain, Conn. The Rev. David H. LaMotte officiated at St. Christopher's By-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Gibson Island,

LEAD: THE SMELL OF a wood fire on a crisp fall day has a certain allure to a certain set of people, those susceptible to the imagined romance of snuggling indoors near the flames on a chilly night. Since much of my childhood was endured in a house that relied on wood fires for both cooking and heating, the mystique has always mystified me.

LEAD: THEY were everywhere. On the floor. The furniture. The cat. Me. The futility of battling an army of nearly microscopic, indefatigable creatures called fleas has left me confident that roaches won't be the lone survivors of a nuclear disaster.

LEAD: SQUIRRELS are not among my favorite creatures. Actually, they're listed high on my rodent list. Besides, I'm afraid of them. This fear is strongly rooted in my childhood, when my parents took me to the Bronx Zoo and a squirrel, aggressive little thing, chased me. No, I have no need for squirrels.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on page 17 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the film ''Breaking In,'' which will close the New York Film Festival, gives an incorrect date. The film will be shown on Oct. 9, not tomorrow.

LEAD: Jeanmarie Hamilton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George L. Hamilton of Fair Haven, N.J., and Richard Allen Drucker, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Drucker, were married yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Nantucket, Mass. The Rev. Edward O. Miller officiated.

LEAD: THE SERFS ARE GONE FROM YASNAYA POLYANA, BUT birches still sway on this serene piece of Russia that was universe enough for the riotous creativity of Leo Tolstoy. Here, on his aristocratic family's estate, the writer and moral reformer was born, and here he alternately despaired and then took heart from fallible humanity, reworking its lessons and language into art.

LEAD: WHEN the housing market is weak, sellers are sometimes forced to accept less for a home than the price stipulated in the sales contract. Brokers and lawyers say buyers are increasingly chipping away, between the signing of the contract and the closing, in an effort to get the seller to lower the agreed-upon price.

LEAD: Assuming that music has been around nearly as long as people have been talking, then recordings, which first became available soon after Thomas Edison figured out his wax cylinder in 1877, have been around for just a short blip on the long graph of mankind. But in that short time, recordings, and the technology that allows them to exist, have radically changed music.
LEAD: Army demonstrated clearly today why Ivy League schools no longer want any part of the Cadets on a football field.

LEAD: Pants, pants and more pants. That's what designers on both sides of the Atlantic overwhelmingly suggested for fall. They showed them for day, for evening, for weekends and for work. They showed them with tailored jackets, with oversize tunic sweaters and with simple white cotton shirts.

LEAD: Those who yearn to be in the fashion forefront ought to keep an eye on the soft pants suits emerging from the workrooms of a few precedent-setting designers. The term avant-garde could aptly be applied to the prototypes shown here.

LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: AT the final farewell ceremony for Vietnamese soldiers here last week, the General Secretary of the People's Revolutionary Party of Cambodia, Heng Samrin, was the centerpiece of a typical socialist-style tableau of Politburo leaders and distinguished guests.

LEAD: Beginning in 1801, when Greece was still part of the Ottoman Empire, the British Ambassador to Constantinople, the seventh Earl of Elgin, acquired from Turkish authorities much of the sculptural ornament of the Parthenon in Athens. Known as the Elgin Marbles, the sculptures are generally recognized as the most sublime expression of the Classical Greek style of the fifth century B.C.

LEAD: An article last Sunday about airline safety included incorrect figures from the National Transportation Safety Board. In 1979, 354 people were killed in accidents involving large commercial jet flights flown by United States airlines. This year 277 have been killed.

LEAD: The tax code, like other American products, should become obsolete every five years. Planned obsolescence would force the writers of the tax code to be concise. A lawmaker, pressed for time, might write a few pithy pages but would not have the patience to amend a 2,000-page fossil. DUWASKY SNOW

LEAD: Imagine an elephant as big as a brownstone, rearing back, straight up, on its hind legs. Place the pachyderm atop a column twice as high again. The column is on an arch, flanked by scores of stairs. Multiply by six, surround with stenciled walls taller than Times Square billboards, throw in a few more oversize elephants, sundry 10-foot lions and 5,000 antlike humans on a movie set.
LEAD: An American Government plan to renovate a California canal has locked the United States and Mexico in a major dispute over the use of water from the Colorado River.

LEAD: The Chilean Army has taken delivery on 15 helicopters bought from a United States manufacturer, but American officials say the transaction does not represent a lifting of the ban on military sales to Chile.
LEAD: A Federal grand jury here has indicted five men linked to racist skinhead groups in connection with vandalism at a Jewish temple and attacks on black and Hispanic people.

LEAD: Pinning its fortunes to a sharp escalation of a long-simmering contract dispute, the state's largest hospital workers union is preparing for a high-stakes strike Wednesday against most of the New York City area's private hospitals and nursing homes.
LEAD: Upholding a central contention of the plaintiffs, a Federal district judge has approved a $78 million settlement in a lawsuit against the Government by neighbors of a uranium processing plant.

LEAD: THE CURRENT CLIMATE. By Bruce Jay Friedman. (Morgan Entrekin/Atlantic Monthly Press, $18.95.) In his novel ''About Harry Towns,'' which was published 15 years ago, Bruce Jay Friedman presented a disturbing portrait of a hedonistic Manhattan playboy. The life of Harry Towns, a moderately successful screenwriter in his 40's, degenerates through episodes of drug abuse, disease-spreading sex and finally the molestation of his girlfriend's daughter.

LEAD: The marriage of Treacy Barbara Moran, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Farley Moran of Madison, N.J., to Carl Watson Badenhausen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl S. LEAD: Posting on Sept. 10 gave an incorrect time for the start of condominium sales at the Coronado, at Broadway and West 70th Street. Sales are currently under way.

LEAD: ALONG the Mianus Road, a half-mile stretch of country road in Bedford, there are no utility lines, driveways or mailboxes. Except for several drainage pipes added under the dirt road many years ago and a guiderail installed by the town in the last year, the road has not changed since it was dug by hand in the 19th century.

LEAD: Paolo Soleri is a frustrating figure to put your finger on: the parts of him do not quite fit together. Architect, scientist, visionary, philosopher and engineer, Soleri is truly successful only as a visionary. His architecture hovers between the magical and the totalitarian; it is late Frank Lloyd Wright blown up to gargantuan scale.
LEAD: FOUR months before she died of cirrhosis and heart failure, a ruin at the age of 44, Billie Holiday was relegated to singing in a seedy bar in South Philadelphia.

LEAD: SUNLIGHT COMES THROUGH THE HATCH OF the crew compartment in this 50-foot sailboat - now at anchor in Suva, Fiji - and wakes me at dawn. I've taken the lower berth, 24 inches across at its widest point. Through the hull, a few inches from my ear, I hear snapping shrimp crackle softly like popcorn as they graze along the bottom of the sea.

LEAD: IT all seemed very Italian, renting a house in Tuscany with my husband, our two sons and my mother, all five of us piling in and out of the car wherever we went. The two women collecting money for the use of the public toilets at Pisa's Campo dei Miracoli thought it was terrific. They laughed when my husband kept shelling out coins as we straggled in, one by one.

LEAD: Philip Roth's ''Goodbye, Columbus,'' published in 1959 as the title novella in a collection of stories, has turned out to be an enduring commentary on postwar America and, more specifically, the Jews who were part of it. ''Goodbye, Columbus'' won the author the National Book Award at the age of 26.

Wegner, a professor of psychology at Trinity University in San Antonio, at the start of his book, ''White Bears and Other Unwanted Thoughts.

LEAD: NEVER WAS THERE A CITY THAT LIVED more in the present than does Delhi today. To arrive at the Indira Gandhi International Airport, and drive from there into New Delhi, is to be struck at once by its unfinished appearance. Huge public housing estates in unpainted concrete rise out of the gravelly red soil where cattle still linger, as if no one had informed them that the past was over, fini.

Janet Evans, the swimmer who won three gold medals at the 1988 Olympics, was named the Women's Sports Foundation Amateur Athlete of the Year.

LEAD: EACH TIME AMERICA SEALS ME IN A laminate of deadlines and Dow Jones averages, bills due and bills payable, I journey to a place where urgencies fade, colors brighten and all claims on reality begin to look relative. Just a stroll down the hill - though, like a good Californian, I usually drive - leads me out of my silent, wind-scoured, chillingly pretty neighborhood into a raucous, mouldering, charmingly unscrubbed caldron.

LEAD: One day last March, Marc Eisenoff walked into the office of Ira Madris, deputy creative director at McCann-Erickson Worldwide advertising, to ask for a raise. The 39- year-old senior art director spotted one of the agency's executive recruiters. For a split second, he thought that might be standard procedure - but she wasn't smiling.

''They'll hate it simply because it's different and not the 'American Document' they saw before.

LEAD: The time: late July. The place: the local 10-plex. The weather: horrid. The line: unbelievably long. Every kid from miles around has been brought to the movies this afternoon, and most of the buzz is about ''Batman.'' They've been hearing about it for weeks; they all want to see it, and most of them aren't going to get in.

LEAD: IT is called Castello di Polgeto, it's near Umbertide in Umbria and we rented its only ground-floor apartment. With it came our own cherry tree in full fruit, our own owl and cuckoo, our own private garden with two elegant cypresses flanked by a low stone wall. On one side of the garden stood a small stone barn where the previous owner had wintered his lemon trees; behind us rose a hollow 70-foot tower connected to a wing of the castle by the tower bridge under which we parked our car.

LEAD: IN recent years, New York City officials have done little to stop thousands of homeless people from staying in the city's bus and rail terminals, some subway stations and parks. But lately, as the number of homeless people and the number of complaints about them have continued to rise, the officials seem to have taken a tougher approach.

LEAD: NEARLY 50 years after the Western democracies lost Eastern Europe to Communism, they are beginning to see how they can help Poland and Hungary find a way back. What they lack, diplomats here say, is an overall strategy for the effort, one that will probably require leadership from the United States.
LEAD: Arthurian romances were on Kathy Lavezzo's mind until Federal agents with German shepherds came to her classroom door at the University of Virginia.

LEAD: Not everyone in this conservative military town approves, but San Diego this fall hosts what is billed as the largest festival of Soviet art and culture ever brought to the United States. The Soviet events represent a kind of reverse glasnost, part of Mayor Maureen O'Connor's efforts to show that San Diego is more than just a warm quiet place by the ocean for retired naval captains to tend their gardens of hibiscus and oleander.

LEAD: WHEN Loren Schoenberg was growing up, musical groups like the Beatles and the Grateful Dead were the voices of his generation. But he longed for the sound of another time, made popular by big-band greats like Benny Goodman. For Mr. Schoenberg, an opportunity to work with the renowned ''King of Swing'' was a dream come true.

LEAD: A HUGE grill manned by two or three chefs and the barbecue meals it produces are the cornerstone of Khan's Mongolian Garden in Stamford, and the grill is what sets this newcomer apart from other Chinese restaurants in the area.

LEAD: It is always risky to copy a previous game without subjecting it to your own independent study, even if it is the moves of the world champion you are following. This becomes truer than true if your present opponent happened to be the champion's opponent in the earlier game.

LEAD: With their hopes for freedom suddenly granted, several thousand East German refugees were allowed to leave the West German Embassy here tonight and were being transported to West Germany.

LEAD: A WELL-DRESSED customer entered a White Plains clothing store recently. Julian DiDonato, who owns the store, Dakota Dry Goods Ltd. on Mamaroneck Avenue, recalled that they exchanged a friendly word or two. It wasn't until after the customer left, Mr. DiDonato said, that he noticed a pair of deerskin gloves, valued at $59, were missing.

LEAD: No ball descended from the top of the Washington Monument at midnight last night to celebrate the new fiscal year. There was nothing to celebrate. The budget deficit in the old year had grown -again. The new year's budget is a sham. And problems are piling up for future years. LEAD: Radon gas has become the most serious environmental health threat in New Jersey, state environmental officials said today, causing more cancer cases than exposure to hazardous waste sites, drinking-water contaminants or food with pesticides.

LEAD: Darryl has proven to be a liability in the field, lazy on the bases, and a poor hitter in both his average and his power when men are on base. Would the Mets be sacrificing home runs by trading Darryl? Probably. But more importantly, would the Mets be a better team with a player in right field who batted, played hard everyday, and who hit better than .260 for a career?
LEAD: VOTERS in the county will face no significant judicial choices in the next three general elections, in the wake of decisions made by the two major political parties.

LEAD: Having spent most of the 1980's delving into musical territory outside the pop-rock mainstream, Linda Ronstadt returns to contemporary pop with a strong new album, ''Cry Like a Rainstorm - Howl Like the Wind'' (Elektra 96082; all three formats).

LEAD: WANTON destruction, in wartime, was once a frequent German amusement. In 1871, for instance, the palace of St.-Cloud, outside Paris, was shelled for the sheer fun of it. And during World War II, Hitler's army, as it whiled away the siege of Leningrad, destroyed the imperial palaces just outside the city.

LEAD: It is a character that Michael Caine seems born to play. Sinister yet seductive, immoral yet irresistible, he conceals his madness with a coating of charm. When a beautiful young co-worker, played by Elizabeth McGovern, discovers that he may have committed a horrible crime, he quickly and effortlessly puts his powers to work.
LEAD: The Soviet Legislature is to digress from the gloomy, down-to-earth business of next year's budget on Monday to consider what may be the ultimate issue: who owns the Soviet Union?

LEAD: Turkey's Foreign Minister asserted in an interview this week that Bulgarian officials must restore the ''usurped'' rights of people of Turkish origin living in Bulgaria. He said his Government would call on the General Assembly to give political support to the Bulgarian Turks.

LEAD: Dance 2000, the Felice Lesser Dance Theater, is certainly ambitious. It uses ballet as its basic technique, yet remains open to other stylistic influences. Felice Lesser favors serious themes in her choreography, and she sets her troupe dancing to contemporary music.

LEAD: A part of what was once Ulysses S. Grant Jr.'s Westchester County farm has been subdivided and offered for sale to anyone who wants a piece of history along with the privacy that 10 or 15 acres can provide.

LEAD: We were delighted to see the magnificent pictures of the senior olympics in your magazine but were disappointed that you did not mention Washington University and its unique role in Olympic history.
LEAD: TO ASMARA By Thomas Keneally. 290 pp. New York: Warner Books. $18.95.

LEAD: Making his first official visit to the Vatican, the Archbishop of Canterbury prayed alongside Pope John Paul II today as the two spiritual leaders discussed future reunification of the Roman Catholic and Anglican churches.

LEAD: Stephen P. King, an architect, died of cancer Friday at his home n East Hampton, L.I. He was 44 years old and also lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Bruce S. Gelb, the new director of the United States Information Agency, says he heard ''no complaints about the Voice of America, not one at all,'' when he met Soviet officials in Moscow this month.

LEAD: Millions of small American businesses that provide health coverage for their employees have been staggered in recent months by insurance rate increases of 20 percent to more than 100 percent.

LEAD: One of my more exotic gastronomic quests occurred in 1978, during a trip with a photographer friend through the Micronesian Islands in the Western Pacific. Along the way, we stopped in Ponape, a 129-square-mile volcanic island famous for its rugged beauty and for the ancient ruins of Nan Madol, man-made islets believed to have had both religious and defensive significance.

LEAD: Dai-Ichi Kangyo, the world's largest bank, isn't trying to catch the fancy of millions of American consumers, as Toyota and Sony have. It will settle for a close relationship with 10,000 or so corporate treasurers.
LEAD: THE SEARCH FOR THE PICTURESQUE Landscape Aesthetics and Tourism in Britain, 1760-1800. By Malcolm Andrews. Illustrated. 269 pp. Calif.: Stanford University Press. $49.50.

LEAD: AN APPETITE FOR POETRY By Frank Kermode. 242 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press.
LEAD: The 19th-century American fascination with wealth fostered an American art form - the trompe l'oeil painting of paper money.

LEAD: The Egyptian President, Hosni Mubarak, made a rare telephone call to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir on Friday night and repeated a conditional offer to meet with the Israeli leader, an official said today.
LEAD: The owner of a tanker that spilled 300,000 gallons of heating oil off Newport when it ran aground in June has been fined $500,000 and its captain has been fined $30,500.
LEAD: Yogi Berra's announcement that he's about to hang up his uniform for the last time calls for the usual statistical rundown.

LEAD: I am thrilled to learn there is no shortage of people who are able to pay $2 million to $10 million for a house in Beverly Hills. To think - on my modest income, I am in the same tax bracket they are!

LEAD: Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $490,000 299 Elm Road 5-bedroom, 3 full- and 2 half-bath, 59-year-old colonial; fireplace, den, family room, w/b stove, deck, 0.62 acre; taxes $6,564. Chappaqua, N.Y. $1.2 million 300 Millwood Road 6-bedroom, 6-bath, 77-year-old colonial; library, pub room, studio, sauna, service wing, pool, 3-car garage, 3 acres; taxes $13,920.

LEAD: WHEN Helen Augelli retired as the principal's secretary at Newtown, Conn., High School in 1986, she and her husband, Joseph, moved to Kitty Hawk on the North Carolina Outer Banks. They had summered there for years, bought a building lot a few years ago, and when the time came, moved into their beach house to stay.

LEAD: SHE is back from paradise, with an Italian wardrobe and a new appreciation of the ''air kiss.'' Michelle Ekizian's year at the American Academy in Rome is over, and she has now begun to assess its influences.

LEAD: THE glitter of glass objects and the history of glassmaking are the focus of an exhibit at the Lyman Allyn Art Museum in New London. Entitled ''All That Glitters Is . . . Glass,'' the exhibit does indeed glitter and gleam, with special lighting on some items like an 1820 English candelabrum with facets and drops.

LEAD: HERE they come, floating so merrily and drifting so gracefully down into my yard. I marvel at the colors, but only for the moment, for I know each leaf will soon fade and lie in the shadow of another and another and another.
LEAD: The Japanese don't like the pale, watery pink color Americans seem to prefer in pork. They like their meat to be deeper in color.
LEAD: FOR LOVE & MONEY A Writing Life, 1969-1989. By Jonathan Raban. 344 pp. New York: An Edward Burlingame Book/Harper & Row.

LEAD: Right now, it's just a small corner of the market, but Howard Skolnik thinks he could be on to something a lot bigger. This week he unveiled a process for making what he thinks is the first kosher steel shipping drum.

LEAD: ''These new addicts are business executives and house painters and doctors and receptionists. And if you met them on the street or at the Little League game, you wouldn't have a clue they're smoking their brains out on crack back home in the basement.'' - Dr. Arnold M. Washton. [ 1:2. ]
LEAD: THE BELLAROSA CONNECTION By Saul Bellow. 102 pp. New York: Penguin Books. Paper, $6.95.

LEAD: Does Estelle Stanecky still have to be told by someone else that if she stands on a windowsill of the Empire State Building she's likely to fall? (''Dinosaur Display Can Be Scary,'' Letter, Sept.17.) Or has she now -- having put away childish things -- learned it for herself?

LEAD: Absolutely not. Trading away Strawberry would become a blunder similar to the exportation of Nolan Ryan and Tom Seaver. Darryl is the premier left-handed power hitter in the National League. He has been plagued by injuries all season which have resulted in a drop of his statistics. RICHARD S.

''How come we never see movies where John Wayne is the head of the tax department?'' he protested. ''Or what about Conan the Certified Public Accountant or Friday the 15th?
LEAD: Bret Saberhagen set a club record today with his 23d victory and clinched the American League earned run average title as the Kansas City Royals beat the Oakland Athletics, 6-1.

LEAD: UNDER SOME COCONUT PALMS NEAR THE entrance to Manuel Antonio Park, a woman sells juice. Little capital investment has gone into this business: a booth, a glass juice squeezer for oranges, a machete to cut coconuts constitute the operation. The woman twists and presses the oranges for me with wholehearted vigor.

LEAD: The name of Kevin Mitchell is pratically engraved on the 1989 National League most valuable player award. Why not? Mitchell has been the best all-round hitter in baseball this season and he has helped power the San Francisco Giants to a division championship.

LEAD: INSIDE the Austin, Tex., laboratories of Sematech, the research consortium struggling to restore American manufacturing skills in memory chips, the Japanese are distinctly unwelcome. The clean rooms where chips are fabricated are closed to most foreigners. When Sematech needed a Nikon repairman to keep a vital piece of equipment running, he was walled off from the rest of the lab.

LEAD: WHEN the curtain slowly ascends on ''42d Street'' at the Paper Mill Playhouse, an all-out blast of tap dancing is under way. Here, indeed, are ''those dancing feet'' that the title song invites us to ''come and meet,'' and all at once, one is overtaken by the rush that only a real live musical can produce.

LEAD: AS surely as B follows A, evil transpires in plays set in isolated houses in remote rural regions. Peter Colley's play, ''I'll Be Back Before Midnight,'' currently at the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale, is set in such a farmhouse.
LEAD: THE ADVENTURES OF GOODNIGHT & LOVING By Leslie Thomas. 510 pp. Los Angeles: Price Stern Sloan. $15.95.

LEAD: As a child, Zina Glazebrook used to get together with a friend and move all the furniture around. ''It used to make my mother nuts a bit,'' recalled Ms. Glazebrook, who was born in Philadelphia, grew up in Bedford, N.Y., and is 39 years old. ''But for me I guess it was the genesis of what I'm doing now.
LEAD: A woman who gave birth in a jetliner restroom in July 1988 and left the infant in a wastebasket will not go to jail until December because she is expecting another baby in mid-October.

LEAD: Jamie Denise Jett and C. Carter Walker 3d, 1987 graduates of the Rhode Island School of Design, were married yesterday in Las Cruces, N.M. The Rev. James Galbraith performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: WHEN I GET TO MUNICH, THIS IS WHAT I do. I check into the Hotel Vier Jahreszeiten - if I can afford it, which is not every year -and I take a room overlooking a quiet side street from which I can see the unmistakable upper bulge of the rebuilt opera house (which in Munich is called the National Theater).

LEAD: NEARLY one-fourth of the seasoned investigators in the western district of the state police will not be showing up for roll-call after today. At Western Connecticut State University in Danbury some ''mega-classes'' are being taught because so many professors will not be returning tomorrow.

LEAD: In the course of his new 12-part PBS series, ''Travels,'' which begins tomorrow night at 8, John Heminway devotes an hour to ''Yesterday's Travelers,'' notably Lowell Thomas, James Fitzpatrick and Osa Martin Johnson, who introduced a generation of homebound moviegoers in the 1930's and 40's to faraway places and exotic peoples.

LEAD: PICASSO: Creator and Destroyer, by Arianna Stassinopoulos Huffington. (Avon, $4.95.) Considering how badly he treated his lovers, Picasso's painting ''Les Demoiselles d'Avignon,'' with its twisted, tormented women, might have been a family portrait. Last year our reviewer, James R. Mellow, called this biography ''a lively and tendentious book.

LEAD: Three new polls on the race for Governor of New Jersey indicate that voters who have made up their minds or are leaning toward a candidate now favor the Democrat, Representative James J. Florio, over his Republican opponent, Representative Jim Courter, by substantial margins.

LEAD: The Democratic defeat on the capital gains tax in the House of Representatives this week is raising new questions on Capitol Hill about the party's message, the strength of its leadership and its ability to hold the line against a popular President.

LEAD: THE bluegrass and variety series have begun at Mamaroneck's Emelin Theater, but five other music cycles are waiting in the wings, with subscriptions still available. That is important to know, because the Emelin has fewer than 300 seats, which sell out quickly for the more popular events.

LEAD: The police fired on crowds protesting the arrest of a separatist leader in northern Jammu-Kashmir state, killing at least 5 and wounding 75, officials said. The authorities imposed a curfew and sent soldiers in Anantnag, where three people were killed by police gunfire on Friday, a Government spokesman said.

LEAD: When Theodore Roosevelt summoned representatives of Harvard, Princeton and Yale to the White House in October 1906, he told them in no uncertain terms that the Federal Government would not hesitate to impose its own solution for ending the mounting violence in college football. He offered two options: clean up the sport or have it abolished.

LEAD: If there is a time for everything, the time for Frans Hals came in the middle of the 19th century, some 200 years after he died. Hals had spent more than five decades as a portraitist in his adopted city of Haarlem, a position not without significance but hardly one that qualified him as eminent. Painters of grand historical and religious scenes were considered artists of ambition; portraiture was an altogether more lowly endeavor.

LEAD: Finding fine wines really isn't all that difficult. It can cost plenty, but it can be done. A 1945 Petrus? Or a 1934 Le Musigny, Comte de Vogue? Or a magnum of '28 Krug? Just say the word; Christie's or Sotheby's or your favorite wine shop will probably be able to track it down.
LEAD: Bret Saberhagen set a club record today with his 23d victory and clinched the American League earned run average title as the Kansas City Royals beat the Oakland Athletics, 6-1.

LEAD: Workers in the 1990's will have one advantage they have lacked for nearly 25 years: scarcity. This shortage will have profound implications for both managers and employees into the 21st century, economists and labor experts say.

LEAD: FINE handcrafts, especially pottery, have become a major attraction for visitors to southern Vermont. Whether the basic plan is to camp out under the summer stars, gaze at the fall foliage, or zoom down a sugar-white ski slope, more and more Vermont vacationers are visiting some of the region's many craft centers and artisans' studios, seeking something to take home that will not merely be a reminder of the trip but also a work of art.
LEAD: Soccer Cup

LEAD: LAST year, East Northport's Peter's Inn headed my list of exciting food finds. This neighborhood bar-turned-gourmet restaurant was a diamond in the rough. Its sparkle emanated from the unexpectedly innovative dishes created by the chef, Bruce Grasley.

LEAD: Even with my Cantonese ancestral and culinary roots, I have always had a passion for the fiery foods of Sichuan. A year or so ago, in the markets, restaurants and food stalls of the region, I finally tasted the real thing (not Taiwan- or Hong Kong-influenced or, even worse, Americanized - the foods with the * next to the menu listing).

LEAD: Civic Action Council's Property Tax Committee watches with sympathy the looming specter of reassessment in the City of Long Beach (Sept. 19, ''In Long Beach, Revaluation Brings Specter of Higher Taxes'').

LEAD: How sad that Cindy E. Soehner has chosen to home tutor her 8-year-old son, Shane, rather than send him to school.

LEAD: SANTIAGO DE COMPOSTELA HAS BEEN A lodestar for visitors for more than a thousand years. The world's first guidebook was written in 1130 by Aimeri Picaud, a French monk, to give information to travelers on their way there. In the early Middle Ages, between 500,000 and 2 million people came each year.

LEAD: Secretary of State Baker is a political craftsman of uncommon toughness and skill, as the Democrats have learned to their regret. In his new role he may prefer the statesman's aura. But he has a chance now at a diplomatic prize that requires his political instincts.

LEAD: Dmitri Shostakovich was 32 years old and had five symphonies behind him when he completed his first string quartet, in 1938. At his death in 1975, the symphonies and quartets had reached parity - 15 each. The cycles complement each other, with the symphonies standing as his more public pronouncements and the quartets as records of his private turmoil.

LEAD: MANHATTAN BROWN-stones that have remained single-family houses are a rarity these days, especially those that have retained their original layouts and intricate architectural details. The rooms in this 1860's house were remodeled, but nearly 80 years ago during the Edwardian era. In the intervening years, they have been lovingly preserved and purposely decorated to reflect the spirit of the place.

LEAD: This year, when thousands of people in Alaska felt the effects of the nation's largest oil spill, the state's residents will receive their second largest annual check from Alaska's oil wealth savings account.

LEAD: A CONGRESSIONAL hearing in Central Islip this week will throw a national spotlight on an innovative Suffolk County program that can better enable localities to shoulder the burden of their growing population of the elderly and disabled poor.
LEAD: MY daughter would be proud of me. In my advanced middle age, I finally attended my first rally. And I stood up and was counted.

LEAD: Christine Chih Chuan Chang, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Yuan Chang of New York, was married yesterday to William Shriver Hanway, the son of Mr. and Mrs. D. William Hanway of Hypoluxo, Fla. The Rev. Susan Harris officiated at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

LEAD: MANY educators and state officials feared that President Bush's ''edu-cation summit'' last week at the University of Virginia would be little more than an extended photo opportunity for the man who has vowed to be ''the education President.'' But afterward, there was growing agreement among the experts that something more substantive had occurred.

LEAD: After Shayna Felts, a computer-science and engineering major, graduated last spring from Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, N.J., she did not have to look hard for a job. Ms. Felts, 22 years old, was recruited by Bell Laboratories, the research and development arm of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, to write software for high-level computers.

LEAD: Why not? They have traded all the other players who might have made the Mets great again. People like Hubie Brooks, Wally Backman, Mookie Wilson, Len Dykstra, Roger McDowell, Rick Aguilera, David West. And on and on. So why trade Strawberry and let him hit .350 with somebody else?
LEAD: AS a member of the vast army of commuters that passes through Grand Central Terminal twice a day, I am pained by the seemingly hopeless plight of the homeless and by my inability to be of help.

LEAD: The quivering anger of Rudolph W. Giuliani as he defended his criticism of David N. Dinkins last week made painfully clear the predicament he faces: How to raise enough doubts about his rival for the New York City mayoralty to beat him without being accused of beating up on him.
LEAD: In the high Andean plains here, Reynaldo Garcia Navas lives in a world bounded by Thanksgiving, Valentine's Day and Secretary's Day.
LEAD: Eric Griffin, who lost a chance to make the 1988 United States Olympic team because of a positive test for marijuana, stood tonight as the world amateur boxing champion at 106 pounds.
LEAD: A front-page article in The Times Book Review today discusses the publicity fanfare that has heralded political memoirs, including Nancy Reagan's forthcoming book, ''My Turn.''
LEAD: MILE ZERO By Thomas Sanchez. 349 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

LEAD: In each corner of the clubhouse, there were Blue Jays with their heads buried in towels. Now and again, a head would emerge, eyes ringed red and burning. There were, though, no tears, for the only hurt the 1989 season produced was the wonderful sting of champagne.

LEAD: Lebanese legislators who have survived more than 14 years of civil war gathered here today for peace talks intended to overcome differences over the deployment of Syrian forces and Muslim demands for greater political power.

LEAD: The day after a French airliner broke up over the desert of southern Niger, killing all 171 people on board, I arrived at the airport in Niamey, the capital of Niger, for my flight to Abidjan.

LEAD: Leslie Anne Schnurr, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Thomas Schnurr of New York and Sheffield, Mass., and Richard Jeffrey Lyman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Bardwell Lyman Jr. of Wayland, Mass., and Sweden, Me., were married yesterday at Our Lady of the Valley Roman Catholic Church in Sheffield.

LEAD: I was encouraged by Deborah Franklin's article ''What a Child Is Given'' (Sept. 3). My adoptive mother suffers from bipolar illness, and I spent much of my early childhood wondering if I, too, would suffer from it. I know now that my concern about ''contracting'' her illness was unnecessary, but the emotional scars of growing up in an unstable family remain.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: An article last Sunday about the effect of divorce upon children omitted the title of a book and the name of Dr. Judith S. Wallerstein's co-author. The book is ''Second Chances'' (Ticknor & Fields, New York, 1989). The co-author is Sandra Blakeslee, a contributor to The New York Times.
LEAD: I SOMETIMES think that people must think that my name is Rand McNally. It seems that a day doesn't go by when some motorist doesn't pull up to me when I'm walking and asks me directions.

LEAD: THE legislative behemoth that Congress will be wrestling with for the next month or so is artfully described as a deficit reduction package, and in the narrowest sense that description is correct.
LEAD: Organizers of last Sunday's Condom Olympics at the University of Wisconsin say their event may not have had the spectacle of Seoul but their goals were just as noble.

LEAD: In reference to the recent articles ''Homeworkers warned of Fraudulent Schemes'' and ''More On L.I. Are Working at Home, (Aug. 27) in which myself and my organization, the Long Island Freelance Exchange, were mentioned, I would like to advise you of a few errors and exclusions regarding the organization's services and locations.

LEAD: Strawberry's lack of maturity and lackadaisical play both on defense and offense make him expendable. He definitely should be traded to the American League for a number of quality players, while he still has value. By trading him, it may help him to grow up and also help the Mets, by showing that even big name stars can be traded.

LEAD: A city legislator's proposal that would force some landlords to register their buildings as private dormitories and could eventually lead to the use of resident advisers to help curb student rowdyism in off-campus housing has met with opposition from students in this high-density college town.
LEAD: THE WHOLE COUN-try has gone >country.
LEAD: South Africa disbanded its police counterinsurgency force in Namibia today in response to pressure from the United Nations and complaints of intimidation from civilians in the territory.
LEAD: Ray Benevenuti threw three touchdown passes and Greg Harris scored twice as undefeated Wagner routed Alfred, 35-19, yesterday on Staten Island.
LEAD: The man who claims to have been the late Congressman Stewart McKinney's lover for five years plans to appeal a probate court ruling that essentially denies his claims to the estate.

LEAD: For 37 years, the ''Game of the Week'' has been Saturday's national Main Street, a televised grandstand linking baseball to provinces hundreds of miles from the nearest big league city. It is network television's longest-running sports program; indeed, according to the A. C. Nielsen Company, it is the most popular April

LEAD: Both Meredith Monk's ''Book of Days'' and Isaac Julien's ''Looking for Langston'' are strong-minded films that juxtapose the past and the present; that is all they have in common. ''Book of Days,'' which transports its audience into the Middle Ages, has visual grace and a good deal of artistic success.
LEAD: Dissident parishioners of a predominantly Polish church here say they have decided to end their protest after 41 weeks of demonstrations at St. Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic Church.

LEAD: David Burnham focused on I.R.S. abuses that occurred prior to 1976, the year in which sweeping revisions were made to Section 6103 of the Internal Revenue Code. The provision as it reads today carries stiff penalties (5 years' imprisonment and a fine of up to $5,000 for each offense) for abuse of the information gathered by the Internal Revenue Service.
LEAD: An article last Sunday about thefts of statues from parks in Buenos Aires described the poet Antonio Machado incorrectly. He was Spanish, not Argentine.
LEAD: Consider the pig. It has a public relations problem. That erstwhile tub of lard apparently has 50 percent less fat than it did 20 years ago but few consumers know it.

LEAD: Yogi Berra has been a player, coach and manager for 45 years. As a player, he won three most valuable player awards. As a manager, he won pennants in each league. Last week he announced his retirement and today in Cincinnati, he will end his career, finishing it as a coach with the Houston Astros.

LEAD: Last year, Gen. Alfredo Stroessner, dictator of Paraguay for 35 years, paid a rare visit to the United Nations. When Paraguayan exiles attempted a peaceful protest, they were set upon by pro-Stroessner goons.

LEAD: All that talk that the Giants need defensive turnovers to win is a myth they helped create. What they need is good defense when it counts. They got enough of that today, kept Herschel Walker from doing too much damage and scored a methodical 30-13 victory over the Dallas Cowboys.

LEAD: From early this morning, packed East German trains pulled into this border junction town at three-hour intervals, disgorging exhausted East Germans whose departure had been allowed only the day before through an extraordinary face-saving arrangement reportedly approved by Erich Honecker, the East German leader.

LEAD: Although many Wall Street executives and real estate developers welcomed the House of Representatives' vote on Thursday to cut the capital gains tax rate, few thought the reduction, if passed by the Senate, would have any significant impact on their business or on stock prices.

LEAD: One man was killed and two other persons were injured last night when a fire of undetermined origin destroyed a three-story dwelling at 559 Lafayette Avenue between Bedford and Nostrand Avenues in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

LEAD: The bags of mail are stuffed into an adjacent locker, a season's worth of unanswered correspondence. Fred McGriff, the notoriously quiet first baseman for the Blue Jays, apparently eschews other forms of communication, as well.

LEAD: When the restaurant Chez Josephine celebrates its third anniversary with a private party tonight, it will honor another anniversary as well. It was 64 years ago today that Josephine Baker, an entertainer from St. Louis, opened in Paris at the Theatre des Champs-Elysees in ''La Revue Negre'' and took the town by storm.

LEAD: Rudolph W. Giuliani's mayoral campaign demonstrated last week the pitfalls of racial politics. The campaign's apparent failure to capitalize on race represents what for a politician of any color is the ultimate ineptitude.

LEAD: Kenneth Huff was parading around the granite Federal Courthouse here as usual, hollering at the top of his lungs, ''The District Court in Charlotte, North Carolina, is crucifying Christ through Jim Bakker,'' when some onlookers began derisively howling like stray dogs.

The victim, Roger Justice, 32 years old, was attacked from behind with a baseball bat and a pool cue as he walked in front of 440 East 13th Street at 10 A.M., said a police spokesman, Sgt.

LEAD: The police arrested more than 200 people today while breaking up the latest in a series of antinuclear protests at an Australian-American military intelligence-gathering base. Officers said 217 of the 500 protesters were arrested in the base's outer security zone, bringing the arrest total in five days of the protests to 490.

LEAD: Now that the Toronto Blue Jays have drawn the short straw, this is what awaits them in the American League playoff that begins Tuesday: perhaps a deeper, better, more focused Oakland Athletics team than the one that ravaged Boston in last season's championship series.

LEAD: THE Century Road Club is looking for a few brave women and some older men too, equally brave. The club is a bicycle organization almost a century old that stages races in Central Park on Saturday mornings for the fun of it, and there are some membership openings.

LEAD: A BAD joke in Hollywood last week suggested that Columbia television had started pitching a series to the networks based on the film ''Tora, Tora, Tora.'' That film tells the story of the Pearl Harbor attack from the Japanese point of view.

LEAD: Once there was a quarterback at East Islip High School with the name Norman Julius Esiason. He became more famous at the University of Maryland and then with the Cincinnati Bengals under the nickname Boomer, which he got because of the way he kicked inside his mother before he was born.

LEAD: A growing crush of commuter traffic threatens the economic vitality and air quality of the nation's cities. Yet present Federal tax policy actively encourages people to drive to work. Legislation now pending in the Senate could help erode this perverse tax bias.

LEAD: Federal agents have arrested three more people in the biggest drug case on record in this country.

LEAD: These are bad times for generic drug makers and their regulators. Three officials of the Food and Drug Administration have pleaded guilty to receiving bribes, and two generic drug companies have admitted to providing false data. Now, after a new scandal involving defective generic drugs for epilepsy, Representative John Dingell says he's lost confidence in the industry's integrity and the F.D.A.

LEAD: Lebanese lawmakers clashed today over the presence of Syrian troops in their country and the Lebanese Christian military leader demanded a timetable for their withdrawal before agreeing to peace.

Two years after the end of the First World War, on the former battlefields of France, there is still grim business at hand. And business it is: as the nightmare of war recedes, it has been replaced by bustling, impromptu forms of industry that call for their own curious brand of sang-froid. Those who have undertaken, quite literally, to sift through the rubble do so with patience, fussiness, occasional opportunism, gallows humor and most of the same bureaucratic instincts they might bring to other, less catastrophe-laden lines of work. It is the only way of bringing the horror to heel. In the setting near Verdun where Bertrand Tavernier's ''Life and Nothing But'' takes place, the first stages of recovery have produced a constant hum of activity. Soldiers are everywhere, an international group searching methodically for the dead and resting in the temporary barracks and restaurants that have sprung up to accommodate them. Relatives of the missing, guided by desperate optimism and not really expecting anything but the worst, have also arrived upon the scene. All are united by a deliberately short-sighted pragmatism that almost succeeds in making tragedy matter of fact.

LEAD: President Bush today named Edward H. Fleischman, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission since 1986, to be acting head of the panel. Mr. Fleischman, 57 years old, a former New York lawyer, will head the S.E.C. while the Senate considers the President's appointment of Richard C. Breeden, a White House aide, as permanent chairman.

LEAD: COMPANIES Zenith Electronics is leaving the computer business. In a surprising announcement, the company said it would sell the division to Groupe Bull for about $635 million in an attempt to concentrate on its consumer electronics. [ Page D1. ] Zenith is cashing in one of its most valuable chips to bet on the risky new technology of high-definition television, analysts said.

LEAD: The Ford Motor Company's 1990 model cars will cost an average of 4.9 percent more than comparably equipped 1989 vehicles, the company announced. Ford said nearly half of the increase came because of Government-required passive safety devices like driver-side air bags or automatic seat belts. LEAD: The utter simplicity of ''Yaaba,'' set against flat, barren plains in an African village made of mud and straw and acted by a barefoot, nonprofessional cast, bespeaks great sophistication. LEAD: In the late afternoons, when he would sit at his locker and dream aloud, Rickey Henderson would talk about the thing he wanted most in his career. He could see himself right there, smack in the middle of the post-season at Yankee Stadium, and the mere thought would sometimes make him smile.

LEAD: In response to a dropoff in the number of the firm's employees, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. has decided to consolidate its New York operations into its main headquarters on Broad Street, the firm said yesterday. Drexel currently occupies 1.5 million square feet of office space in four downtown locations in New York, of which 400,000 will be vacated in a year and a half.

LEAD: The Supreme Court upheld today the legality of President Virgilio Barco Vargas's decree allowing extradition of suspected drug traffickers to the United States, giving support to his campaign against the cocaine cartels.

LEAD: Harley-Davidson Inc., the Milwaukee motorcycle company, said it is not for sale. Harley's announcement came a day after Malcolm I. Glazer, a Rochester businessman, disclosed he had acquired a 6.24 percent stake in the company for more than $17 million and indicated that he might seek control of the company.

LEAD: Alice T. McGillion, the New York City Police Department's chief spokeswoman, was named yesterday to the No. 2 police post, first deputy commissioner, making her the highest-ranking woman ever in the department.

LEAD: Private hospitals in New York City said yesterday that services would not be greatly affected in the event of a strike today by members of Local 1199 of the Drug, Hospital and Health Care Workers union.

LEAD: A magistrates' court here sentenced Abie Nathan, one of Israel's best-known peace campaigners, to six months in prison today for meeting with Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

LEAD: Though there are movie stars who regard classic roles as a careerlong mission instead of a one-shot summer vacation - Kevin Kline and Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio among them -New York audiences have lately seen too many Hollywood visitors treat Shakespeare like a cheap tart. These are the stars who milk the Bard for all the self-serving publicity he's worth during rehearsal, then turn their backs on him by self-indulgently goofing their way through his plays in performance.

LEAD: In the latest sign of closer ties between the United States and Mexico, Presidents Bush and Carlos Salinas de Gortari signed an agreement today intended to enlarge trade and investment between the two nations.

LEAD: The Pyramid Technology Corporation, a minicomputer manufacturer based in Mountain View, Calif., entered a strategic partnership agreement with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to develop a new generation of high-performance computer systems.

LEAD: Orders to American factories for manufactured goods rose 2.9 percent in August, the Government said today. But analysts said a one-month increase from automobile orders belied weakness in the industrial sector.

LEAD: Yale lags behind leading colleges and universities in recruiting and retaining minority professors and has to respond swiftly and boldly to avoid an intolerable situation, a university committee has urged.

Reynolds Tobacco Company agreed yesterday not to misrepresent the results of a study linking smoking and heart disease in the tobacco company's future advertisements, settling a false advertising claim brought by the Federal Trade Commission. LEAD: A 30-year-old worker in a heating plant near Leipzig said his rickety Trabant automobile, carrying his wife and two children, crept across the border from East Germany to Czechoslovakia at 3:45 P.M. today, one of the last before East Berlin closed itself off from the last country to which its citizens could travel with relative freedom.

LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission may be allowed to raise fees and increase its budget if a little-noticed provision in the House of Representative's budget reconciliation bill becomes law.
LEAD: Sun Microsystems Inc. said today that it expected a small operating profit in the quarter that ended last Saturday.

LEAD: Dissident Panamanian officers tried to overthrow Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega today but failed when troops loyal to the Panamanian leader recaptured a central military headquarters the rebels had seized.

LEAD: Gypsies who had occupied a former concentration camp for a month to dramatize their campaign to remain in West Germany were driven out by the police this week in an action that highlighted a troubling aspect of West Germany's immigration policies.

LEAD: The Seagram Building on Park Avenue and the Four Seasons restaurant within it -which have long been seen as pinnacles of the cool, sleek, International style of architecture that dominated American cities after World War II - became official New York City landmarks yesterday.

He called his party Fete de Famille IV.

LEAD: When New Jersey embarked in 1978 on the dubious course of using casino gambling to spur urban redevelopment, it wisely erected a legal wall between the gaming industry and politics. Now the casino king Donald Trump calls for tearing down the barrier. He couldn't be more wrong.

LEAD: Willis M. Tate, who was president of Southern Methodist University for nearly 20 years, died Sunday, apparently from a heart attack, while on a trip to Colorado. He was 77 years old and lived in Dallas.

LEAD: The underground leadership of the Palestinian revolt in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip sought today to broaden the protest, calling for a five-day general strike and ''rebellion'' in the streets.

Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya came as close to getting under Washington's political skin.

LEAD: THE effects of New York City's glut of office space and the economic slowdown may be catching up with the midtown south office district.
LEAD: Comparisons of the speed of the fastest computer work stations have frequently relied on inflated claims and even a bit of trickery.

LEAD: Marjorie C. Vietor, an organizer of the Red Cross Blood Donor Service in Manhattan in World War II, died in her sleep on Sept. 21 at Lawrence (Mass.) General Hospital. She was 97 years old and moved in 1984 to Needham, Mass., from Woodbury, Conn., where she had lived for many years.

LEAD: Good players who want to become even better will have a rare opportunity later this month. His subject will be competitive bidding, on which he has written extensively.

LEAD: The Trump Shuttle introduced its advertising campaign yesterday and Donald J. Trump was nowhere to be seen.
LEAD: Jim Bakker was described by prosecutors as a con man and by his defense lawyers as a victim of Government interference today at his trial on conspiracy and fraud charges.

LEAD: A survey of college and university presidents and deans has found that 86 percent of those polled believe that the financial rewards of intercollegiate athletics are interfering with the educational mission of schools in the United States. LEAD: The Devils have been guilty in the past of overrating their personnel and aiming too high, but this year the high expectations may be justified.

LEAD: Tina Sasser, a single mother of two, earns $17,000 a year as an admitting clerk at the Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. LEAD: There are few more enjoyable evenings in the theater than to accompany those Oscar Wilde dandies John Worthing and Algernon Moncrieff as they pursue, both in town and the country, love and earnestness. In ''The Importance of Being Earnest,'' which is being presented by the Jean Cocteau Repertory company, Wilde uses his epigrams like a rapier, slashing his way through Mayfair drawing rooms and Hertfordshire gardens and leaving the cloak of hypocrisy that covered Victorian manners in tatters of laughter.

LEAD: The Congressional compromise reached this week on automobile emissions is one of the most significant indications of how far American industry has been forced to retreat from unbending opposition to tougher Federal clean air laws.

LEAD: A B-1 bomber made an emergency landing at Edwards Air Force Base in the California desert today after an increasingly desperate 12-hour flight in which the crew struggled unsuccessfully to lower the landing gear in the plane's nose.

LEAD: U S West Inc., the regional Bell telephone company serving the Rocky Mountain states, announced plans yesterday to more than double its investments in financial services businesses by acquiring Financial Security Assurance Holdings Ltd., the largest insurer of corporate bonds.

LEAD: The Agriculture Department said today that the net income of farm cooperatives last year rose to nearly $1.7 billion, continuing a rebound from the sharp declines of the mid-1980's. Combined business volume of cooperatives in 1988 was reported at $66.3 billion, up 10.3 percent from $60.2 billion in 1987.

LEAD: The Justice Department today filed lawsuits against Detroit, Phoenix, San Antonio and El Paso, charging failure to control industrial discharges of toxic wastes into their sewage treatment systems.

Conditions became so hectic that the police had to clear the Dresden terminal by force and the doors of trains were sealed from the outside to block them.

LEAD: Hospital Strike Averted In New York City Area After a night of frenzied bargaining, negotiators for 44 private hospitals and nursing homes in the New York City area and their employees reached agreement on a three-year contract, narrowly averting a strike by thousands of workers. Page B1.

LEAD: Following is the roll-call vote of 360 to 66 by which the House of Representatives today voted to repeal the Medicare program insuring against financial catastrophe from high medical bills. A ''yes'' vote is a vote to repeal the program. Voting ''yes'' were 196 Democrats and 164 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 56 Democrats and 10 Republicans.

LEAD: Ken Stabler had suddenly been leveled by one of the Browns' pass-rushers. John Madden hurried onto the field in Cleveland that day in 1977 to check the health of his quarterback, and then the Oakland Raiders' coach began hollering angrily at the perpetrator. After a few words, the Browns' pass-rusher took a few ominous steps toward Madden until Art Shell, the Raiders' huge All-Pro offensive tackle, spoke up.

LEAD: The Atlantic City Electric Company offered $135 million of 30-year first mortgage bonds at competitive bid.

LEAD: Mark Grace, Chicgo's first baseman, spoke admiringly of the hitting exhibition San Francisco's first baseman displayed tonight. ''It was his night tonight,'' Grace said. Grace's manager chose to disagree. ''He didn't have a night,'' Don Zimmer said. ''He had a week.''

LEAD: Senate Republicans threatened today to bring the Senate to a halt if Democrats invoked parliamentary rules to prevent the full Senate from voting on a proposal to reduce the capital gains tax rate.

LEAD: Top personnel executives, educators and New York City officials agreed yesterday that businesses must work more closely with public schools and expand their own training programs to cope with an acute and worsening shortage of qualified workers.

LEAD: The odds of getting an AIDS infection from a typical blood transfusion were just 1 in 28,000 two years ago, and the risk is dropping by more than 30 percent a year as fewer AIDS carriers donate blood, a study says.

LEAD: Dan Hampton, a Chicago Bears defensive tackle, underwent arthroscopic surgery on his left knee yesterday and will be out for at least six weeks. The Bears placed Hampton on the injured reserve list. (AP)
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Cadence Design Systems Inc. agreed to buy the Gateway Design Automation Corporation of Lowell, Mass., for stock valued at more than $72 million. Cadence, a growing supplier of software for the design of integrated circuits, reported sales of $67.1 million last year.

LEAD: THE nation's independent money managers slightly outperformed the overall stock market over the last 12 months, but trailed the market just a bit for the first three quarters of this year, according to statistics released yesterday.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A top Federal regulator confirmed today what private economists had been saying for some time: The $50 billion that Congress approved in August to liquidate and sell off hundreds of ailing savings and loan associations over three years could be inadequate to cover the losses at the institutions.
LEAD: ''When it first started, I thought, 'Maybe I could get wiped out, here.' I thought it could definitely end my career.''

LEAD: If you can't win a political argument on the merits, attack your opponent as a Communist. It is an old Washington tactic. But I have not seen it used as crudely in years as it has just been by Senator Orrin Hatch, Republican of Utah.
LEAD: In the first inkling of what his life might be like after he leaves office in January, Mayor Edward I. Koch is discussing with New York University the possibility of becoming a professor.
LEAD: Milton Goldman, a prominent theatrical agent, died of heart failure in his sleep yesterday in Manhattan in his Sutton Place home. He was 75 years old.

LEAD: The White House considered military support for the Panamanian uprising but ruled it out because it was uneasy with the rebel leadership, fearful of a trap and uncertain whether Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega had been captured, Administration officials said today.
LEAD: An article on Sept. 26 about a debate between candidates for governor of New Jersey misstated the site in some copies. It was Monmouth College.

LEAD: Question: What evidence do prosecutors and political opponents have to prove that Representative James F. Florio, the Democrat running for governor, is linked to the Mafia? Answer: None. Question: Then are Republicans trying to smear a candidate as mob-tainted because he has an Italian last name?

LEAD: The leader of Belgium's principal Jewish organization was shot Tuesday in a hospital parking lot and died early today. The police said they were investigating whether it was an anti-Semitic or political act.

LEAD: A FRIEND recently recalled how, when she was 11 years old, her parents told her she would spend the sixth grade in a class for gifted children instead of continuing at her old elementary school. They expected their daughter, who had always been at the top of her class and who was generally bored with her schoolwork, to be elated.

LEAD: * Aerospace Corp., El Segundo, Calif., a research and engineering company on military space systems, was awarded a $415.3 million increase in a Defense Department contract for engineering and technical support for the Air Force and other agencies in the 1990 fiscal year.
LEAD: In five years, the Islanders dropped from the elite of the National Hockey League to the third-best team in a three-team market.

LEAD: The Bulova Corporation has a new face, indeed a variety of new faces -15 original one-inch-square geometric designs by Victor Vasarely, the French painter who is known as the father of ''Op Art.''

LEAD: The Mets said today that Frank Cashen had finally reached Davey Johnson by telephone and opened a dialogue that would decide whether Johnson returned as manager next year. They denied again in the strongest terms that the decision had been made.

LEAD: Two weeks after the State Department asserted that the Soviet bloc had increased arms shipments to Nicaragua, American intelligence officials have concluded that shipments have instead declined by about 20 percent this year, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: ''STOVE Mania,'' David Erickson calls his passion. After buying an 1876 wood-burning parlor stove for himself 12 years ago, the 38-year-old Mr. Erickson became so enraptured that he left his job as a teacher in Boston and set up Erickson's Antique Stoves in a Victorian railroad depot in Littleton, Mass.

LEAD: Two Palestinian guerrillas were shot and killed late Tuesday night by Israeli soldiers on a routine patrol in the self-declared Israeli security zone just a few hundred feet from the northern border, an Israeli Army spokesman said today.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY The Administration will regulate international money transfers by U.S. banks, the Treasury said, in an attempt to curb the laundering of drug profits. The Government will open a financial crimes center next month in Virginia to supply information on money laundering to several Federal agencies.
LEAD: Senior officials of The Athletics Congress voted yesterday to invesitgate any accusations of drug use in track and field in the United States that occurred within the previous six years.

LEAD: Under pressure from Democratic lawmakers to respond more aggressively to the changes in Eastern Europe, the White House announced today that President Bush would ask Congress for an additional $200 million in economic aid for Poland.

LEAD: R. H. Macy & Company said it plans to convert seven Bullock's Wilshire specialty stores into I. Magnin stores next February. The two chains have been operating under the same divisional management since their acquisition last year. The larger Bullock's department store chain is not affected by the change.

LEAD: Walking into the Renwick Gallery right now is like walking into a rainbow: a visitor is enveloped in the glowing colors of a lush exhibition of the masterworks of Louis Comfort Tiffany, which opened Friday. Many of the 65 objects on display, including windows, lamps, glassware and jewelry, come from private collections and have never before been on public view.

LEAD: A sailor stationed aboard a United States aircraft carrier in Japan has been sentenced to 35 years in prison for spying, a Navy spokesman said today.

LEAD: A Superior Court jury recommended today that Richard Ramirez, a 29-year-old drifter convicted last month as the ''Night Stalker'' responsible for at least 13 murders, be sentenced to the gas chamber.

When the body of a young woman is found lying in a thicket in a Paris suburb, murdered, it appears, by a holdup man who panicked, the police inspector first checks out Mr. Hire (Michel Blanc), mostly because nobody likes him. Mr. Hire once served a six-month sentence for indecent exposure. He also changed his name to Hire from Hirevitch, but neither fact would seem to justify the policeman's interest in him as a robbery-murder suspect. The only excuse is profound suspicion of someone alien.

LEAD: Edmund Jan Osmanczyk, a Polish journalist, independent legislator and compiler of encyclopedias on international affairs, died Tuesday in Warsaw, where he lived. He was 76 years old and had been suffering from heart disease.

LEAD: Elizabeth V. Murrell-Fax, a social worker and former director of the Forest Neighborhood House in the South Bronx, died of cancer Tuesday in La Guardia Hospital in Queens. She was 78 years old and lived in Queens.

LEAD: Akio Morita, co-founder of the consumer electronics giant Sony, is widely known in the United States. LEAD: A student at Herbert H. Lehman High School in the Bronx was arrested yesterday after menacing two school officials with a loaded .357-magnum revolver in the school's hallways, the police said.

LEAD: Arnold Ehrlich, deputy editor of Town & Country magazine and a former editor in chief of Publishers Weekly, died of lung cancer Tuesday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Tonight at 11:30, Channel 2 gets closer to the drug scene than many viewers may find comfortable. Smoking crack and shooting heroin are apparently the main activities for many residents.

LEAD: A draft audit at the Department of Housing and Urban Development has identified yet another low-income Federal housing program that was marred by mismanagement and potential favoritism involving politically well-connected consultants and developers.

LEAD: The number of registered voters in New York City is at its highest in at least 10 years, and the figure is likely to grow in the next week, the final registration period before the Nov. 7 mayoral election.

LEAD: It is half an hour before the opening tipoff, and the leather-lung crowd at the Palaeur is already in a lather, screaming for victory, blood and heaven knows what else at unchartable decibel levels.

LEAD: MOST storm and screen doors are equipped with mechanisms to assure automatic closing and to protect the door from opening too wide or being blown open by wind. Although these door closers seldom break, they need regular lubrication to keep operating smoothly and occasional adjustment to compensate for internal wear.

LEAD: New Jersey seized control of Jersey City's troubled public schools today, saying ''total educational failure'' in the state's second-largest city had deprived its 28,000 students of their constitutional right to a ''thorough and efficient education.''

LEAD: For more than two decades, Crate & Barrel has built a dedicated following as a stylish but inexpensive merchandiser of glassware, kitchen utensils and accessories suitable for finishing a young adult's first real apartment. LEAD: Joel Stephenson Mitchell, the former chief executive of Standard Brands Inc., died Monday at his home in Lake Wales, Fla. He was 90 years old.

No more veiled talk about ''economic sovereignty'' or confederation with the Soviet Union - the magic word is independence, the state of nationhood stolen from the Latvians 50 years ago in a pact between Stalin and Hitler.

LEAD: Frank J. Zolfo is in a business that booms when others do not. The head of an accounting firm devoted to troubled businesses and their investors, he has thrived on the explosion in demand for services like his own.

LEAD: In an attempt to halt the extensive laundering of drug profits earned illegally in this country and sent abroad, the Bush Administration has decided to regulate international money transfers by American banks, the Treasury Department announced today.

LEAD: Vowing to continue fighting, a coalition of Muslim and Druse Lebanese militias today strongly criticized the Arab League's efforts to mediate a peaceful settlement to the 14-year Lebanese civil war.

LEAD: Every day 20 million Americans take pills to lower their blood pressure. And if some physicians had their way, most of the remaining 38 million Americans who have high blood pressure would be similarly medicated, taking one or more pills every day for the rest of their lives to ward off strokes, heart attacks and kidney disease.

LEAD: As thousands of East Germans boarded trains tonight for their passage to the West, there were growing signs that the continuing exodus from East Germany was severely shaking the Governments in Prague as well as East Berlin.

LEAD: President Bush tried today to revive a faltering cease-fire in Angola as the Administration stepped up its efforts to bring about direct negotiations between the Angolan Government and rebel forces armed by the United States.

LEAD: After pleading no contest to a driving while intoxicated charge, George Gervin, the former San Antonio Spurs star, says he hoped to make a National Basketball Association comeback this year. Gervin was sentenced to 45 days in jail Tuesday. But County Court-at-Law Judge Tony Ferro placed him on probation for one year, meaning Gervin will not have to serve jail time.

Under its terms, KLM Royal Dutch Airlines will retain a seat on Northwest's board, not relinquish it. But that director must abstain from decisions involving ''sensitive competitive and international aviation matters.

LEAD: Couples who circumvent public and private agencies to adopt a baby independently have become part of an increasingly self-protective institution with its own advocacy groups, its own protocol and its own lawyers.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The three best-performing mutual funds in the third quarter benefited from owning big blocks of airline stocks involved in takeovers and substantial stakes in Fannie Mae, Nike and a handful of Japanese insurance companies, according to a survey released yesterday.

LEAD: A COUPLE of years ago a friend in the nursery business sent me several perennials - two daisies and an aster - he had just imported from West Germany and wished to test for winter-hardiness in various regions of the United States. These three not only got through the winter splendidly but also proved to be indispensable for the late-season garden.
