LEAD: In a move designed to reduce time demands on college athletes, the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Presidents' Commission today decided to recommend a measure that would all but eliminate spring practice in football, shorten the basketball season by a month and reduce the number of basketball games by three.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The contract agreement with the hospital workers' union is as much a political victory for the union and its young president, Dennis Rivera, as it is a triumph at the bargaining table.
LEAD: The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees is under fire from senior associates and diplomats who deal with the agency.
LEAD: The Philadelphia Electric Company yesterday offered $175 million of first and refunding mortgage bonds at competitive bid.

LEAD: Mike Tyson, the heavyweight boxing champion, will be allowed to perform a community-service sentence for speeding after the original 60-day deadline date. Judge Stephen Safranko agreed yesterday in Albany to let Tyson conduct three youth clinics on Monday, two days after the deadline set Aug. 7 by the judge.
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds inched lower in slow, featureless trading yesterday.
LEAD: Yields of money market mutual funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report rose modestly during the week ended yesterday.

LEAD: TENNIS Navratilova Bounces Back: Martina Navratilova lost the first three games but bounced back to beat Tine Scheuer-Larsen of Denmark, 7-5, 6-3, yesterday and clinch a quarterfinal berth for the top-seeded United States in the Federation Cup women's tournament in Tokyo. The American team swept past Denmark, 3-0.

LEAD: The saxophone has been with us for nearly 150 years, and there have been ensembles of saxophonists for nearly all that time. Yet, the repertory for saxophone quartet is surprisingly small, a problem many of today's ensembles sidestep by transcribing works written for other instruments.

LEAD: Conspirators who tried to overthrow Gen. Antonio Manuel Noriega on Tuesday planned to trap him in his office and turn him over to United States authorities, a businessman with close ties to the Panamanian armed forces said today.

LEAD: Responding to allegations that CBS broadcast faked combat films during the war in Afghanistan in the mid-1980's, David W. Burke, the president of CBS News, said yesterday that the charges ''are simply not true.''

LEAD: After a night of frenzied bargaining, negotiators for most of the New York City area's private hospitals reached a contract agreement yesterday, narrowly averting a strike by thousands of their workers.

LEAD: The Canadian Government said today that it would cut passenger train service by more than 50 percent nationwide, touching off bitter protests in a country that was stitched together by railroads in the 19th century and where trains and the people who ride them are the stuff of national folklore.

LEAD: The Senate tonight stopped just short of passing a statute outlawing flag burning, legislation that many Democrats hoped would defuse the drive for a constitutional amendment to protect the flag.

LEAD: Prosecution and defense attorneys rested their cases today in the McMartin preschool molestation trial, which, now in its third year, is the longest criminal proceeding in American history. Closing arguments are to begin next week, and Judge William Pounders of Superior Court said he expected the case to go to the jury by Nov.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The tears that Gen. Augusto Pinochet shed at a recent ceremony served as a powerful reminder of the uncertain future facing the man who has reigned over Chile bigger than life for 16 years.
LEAD: Dennis McGee, a fiddler who performed on some of the earliest recordings of Cajun music, died on Tuesday. He was 96 years old and lived in Eunice.

LEAD: In a preview tour of the new Children's Museum of Manhattan, several members of an advisory committee kicked bottle caps around an empty gallery, peeled back the brown paper covering the wall-to-wall carpet and chased each other around a cluster of their colleagues being interviewed for television.

LEAD: As the House voted to kill a program intended to protect the elderly from ruinous medical bills, residents of several retirement homes here continued to express the fears that inspired the plan in the first place.

LEAD: A secret analysis prepared for the Chinese leadership says that China's relationship with the United States has deteriorated sharply and will continue to be rocked by new conflicts, but that President Bush is quietly trying to limit the damage.

LEAD: The San Francisco Giants brought the act to 75-year-old Wrigley Field and shattered the Chicago Cubs tonight, 11-3, to win the opening game of the playoff for the National League pennant. And most of the shattering was done by the power tandem of Will Clark and Kevin Mitchell.

LEAD: Michael Eugene Choukas, an expert on the uses of propaganda who taught sociology at Dartmouth College for 30 years, died Monday at the Hanover Terrace Health Care Facility in New Hampshire. He was 87 years old and lived in Portsmouth, N.H.

LEAD: The Ford Motor Company has recalled about 70,000 1988 Ford Taurus, Mercury Sable and Lincoln Continental cars to repair a potential power-steering problem. Ford announced the recall Tuesday, saying it would replace a power-steering pump pulley on cars with 3.8-liter engines. The pulleys could come off, causing a loss of power steering, the company said.

LEAD: The Giants will carry a 4-0 record and a two-game division lead into their game Sunday against the Eagles in Philadelphia. One unexpected reason for that early-season success is Dave Meggett, an undersized, small-college rookie who keeps finding new ways to help the Giants win.

LEAD: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association put off endorsing a mayoral candidate yesterday, prolonging the battle between David N. Dinkins and Rudolph W. Giuliani for the blessing of the city's most influential law-enforcement union.

LEAD: Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner said today that it would be more effective for his department to review airline takeovers in advance, as would be required by proposed legislation, than retroactively, as it did recently in the case of Northwest Airlines.

LEAD: The world of medicine is understandably experiencing anxiety palpitations these days. Soaring costs, malpractice suits, often frustrating efforts to cope with such crises as AIDS, drug addiction and increasingly indigent patients: the headlines are not comforting. Significant public protests are spreading to Government agencies and pharmaceutical companies.

LEAD: As the Communist Party gathers its shrinking forces for a Congress opening Friday, the party's chief of ideology propaganda said the leadership's expectations were modest.

LEAD: Early in ''Carried Away,'' his breathlessly paced evening of songs with lyrics by Betty Comden and Adolph Green, Jeff Harnar observes that throughout their long-running collaboration, the team kept writing songs for their favorite character, New York City. These remarks introduce ''Lonely Town,'' a memorable ballad with music by Leonard Bernstein that has one of Comden and Green's finest lyrics.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: One of the teen-agers involved in a wilding rampage in Central Park last April has agreed to cooperate with prosecutors and possibly testify against six other youths in the case.

LEAD: Factory-built modular construction normally allows a home to be produced more quickly and at a lower cost than one constructed on the site, but a major drawback has been the difficulty of incorporating custom changes requested by buyers, especially for higher-priced new houses.

LEAD: The autobiography of the Dalai Lama, who won the Nobel Peace Prize yesterday, will be published simultaneously in the United States and Britain next year. Its tentative title is ''Freedom in Exile: The Autobiography of the Dalai Lama.''

LEAD: Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, left his training camp in Las Vegas, Nev., yesterday for Albany to perform court-ordered community service stemming from speeding violations earlier this year, Don King, the fighter's promoter, said. LEAD: Rick Pitino, the University of Kentucky's new basketball coach, has been sued by Dick Regan Productions, which has charged the former Knick coach with breach of contract regarding video and television production agreements. The $5 million suit was filed in New York State Supreme Court yesterday.

LEAD: ''Projects and Portfolios,'' the Brooklyn Museum's 25th National Print Exhibition, which opens today, is not like most other surveys. LEAD: Carl C. Icahn has increased his stake in the USX Corporation and plans to acquire more of its stock, according to documents filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

LEAD: Trailing by four goals early in the third period, the Islanders rallied but lost, 6-5, to the Minnesota North Stars tonight at the Metropolitan Sports Center in the season opener for both teams.

LEAD: Documents released today by the Department of Housing and Urban Development add to the list of prominent Republicans known to have sought help from former Secretary Samuel R. Pierce and other senior H.U.D. officials.

LEAD: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -10 A.M. and 3 P.M. DECOLONIZATION COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M.

LEAD: For Children Shows, Nature, Museums ''THE EMPEROR'S NEW CLOTHES,'' an opera by Judy Spencer, 1 and 3 P.M. Saturdays through Nov. 18, at Hartley House Theater, 413 West 46th Street. Tickets: $6. Information: 666-1716. ''ROCKET AND FRIENDS,'' a show by the Puppet Company, 1 and 3 P.M.

LEAD: The Senate today approved legislation intended to outlaw flag burning and other forms of flag defacement, setting the stage for a battle later this month over a proposed constitutional amendment to accomplish the same purpose.
LEAD: A. J. Foyt's condition was upgraded to good yesterday and he was moved from the intensive care unit to a private room at Charlotte Memorial Hospital in North Carolina.

LEAD: Jim Bakker, who built a multimillion-dollar religious empire on an image of wholesome values and religious faith, was convicted today on all 24 fraud and conspiracy counts he faced in Federal court here.

LEAD: Continuing to outstrip his opponent in raising funds, David N. Dinkins collected three times as much as Rudolph W. Giuliani in the latest filing period, according to financial reports released yesterday by the candidates.
LEAD: Brooks Brothers, the New York-based apparel retailer, said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, Frank T. Reilly, would retire at the end of the year.
LEAD: Two people were killed when a New York City Transit Authority bus and a car collided yesterday afternoon and rolled up onto a sidewalk in Staten Island, the police said.

LEAD: A year ago, many politicians and analysts said the 1988 Presidential campaign would have little to do with governing, little to do with the issues and problems that would shape the years that followed. To the Democrats' despair and the Republicans' delight, they were wrong. If you seek the monument of the 1988 campaign, look around.

LEAD: William Grinker, head of New York City's Human Resources Administration, once called his post ''the toughest job that one could imagine.'' Now he is resigning after three years in that job. While he deserves credit for a few successes, his agency remains swamped by the waves of social problems generated by the housing shortage, crack, AI

LEAD: The young prostitutes rush to the van like children gathering around an ice cream truck on a hot day. ''Hey, man,'' they call. ''Where are the condoms? Give me some condoms.'' The van belongs to Project Street Beat, a program of Planned Parenthood of New York City, and the teen-agers it attracts work the harshest streets of the South Bronx, in decaying neighborhoods rife with drug abuse, unwanted pregnancy and AI

LEAD: Robert L. Crandall, a hard-driving boss who took over a money-losing American Airlines in 1980 and turned it into a highly profitable and highly regarded line, wants to run his own show and would not be happy working for someone else, analysts say.
LEAD: In a coordinated effort to weaken the buoyant dollar, the West Germans and other European countries increased key interest rates today, but the dollar closed higher anyway.

LEAD: Reflecting concern about the possibility of coupon fraud, the Audit Bureau of Circulations said this week that it would begin studying the coupon-handling practices of magazines. In a pilot project, TV Guide will be the first magazine to submit to the examination, which checks the printing, storage, handling and distribution of coupons.
LEAD: The ethical and financial problems of the nation's television evangelists have cost them contributions and followers.

LEAD: The crash of a USAir 737 at La Guardia Airport last month has sharpened Federal and industry scrutiny of pairing relatively inexperienced pilots in the same cockpit. Also receiving more attention is the customary taking of turns at the controls.
LEAD: The Giants are 4-0 and lead their division by two games. The Eagles are 2-2 and are playing erratically and have many key injuries.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Board of Elections reports that the number of registered voters in New York City is now at its highest in a decade. But that still leaves at least two million New Yorkers eligible to vote but not registered.

LEAD: The Devils came up with such an inspiring performance in their season opener tonight at the Spectrum that it overshadowed the National Hockey League debuts of New Jersey's two Soviet defensemen, Vyacheslav Fetisov and Sergei Starikov.
LEAD: A short-order cook accused of dismembering his roommate's body and boiling it was indicted yesterday on murder charges.
LEAD: To the Editor:

Victoriana is a veritable industry here; it's alive and spreading in houses, hotels, bed and breakfasts, guest houses, churches, restaurants and even the Cape May Point Lighthouse that stands between the Atlantic Ocean and Delaware

Andiamo! ** (Nov. 18, 1988), 1991 Broadway, near 67th Street (362-3315) - Andiamo!, two blocks north of Lincoln Center, is set in a lofty space with striking, large abstract paintings and constructions.

LEAD: The bodies of four Hispanic men who were bludgeoned to death have been found since July 31 inside bags in vacant lots in Queens, the police said yesterday. Investigators said they were baffled by the killings and had identified only one of the victims.

LEAD: Pat Petersen, the top American finisher in the event in 1984 and 1985, has entered this year's New York City Marathon, which will be held Nov. 5. Petersen was seventh in the London Marathon last April in 2 hours 10 minutes 4 seconds, the best time by an American since 1983.

LEAD: After the second issue of Gitobu Imanyara's monthly magazine appeared on the newsstands, with a bold title about human rights and a chilling graphic of barbed wire splashed across the cover, some friends in the security forces got in touch with the editor. Not a good idea, they warned. Dangerous copy, they said.

LEAD: In a case that advocates of abortion rights hope could serve as a model elsewhere in the nation, the Florida Supreme Court yesterday relied on its state Constitution to strike down a law restricting abortions.

LEAD: Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. was censured yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission for numerous violations of securities laws governing accounting procedures and operational controls.

LEAD: The German Bach specialist Helmuth Rilling will conduct the New York Philharmonic in a performance of Bach's Mass in B minor this afternoon at 2 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall. The choir will be Mr. Rilling's own Gachinger Kantorei, a resident ensemble at his International Bach Academy in Stuttgart. The soloists are Sylvia McNair, a soprano; Marjana Lipovsek, mezzo-soprano; Howard Crook, a tenor and Mark Pedrotti, a bass.

LEAD: The calendar of cultural events in the New Jersey Weekly on Sunday listed an incorrect date for the performance of ''The Incredible Merlin Magic Show'' at the West Orange High School. The performance will be on Oct. 14, not tomorrow.
LEAD: The Massachusetts House voted Wednesday to delay for a year the key provision of the state's universal health insurance law after turning back an attempt to repeal it.
LEAD: Penn State had its first losing record in more than half a century came last year and it bothered Joe Paterno, the university's revered coach, as much as any rabid alumnus.
LEAD: Senior officials of the nation's four options exchanges squared off today in testimony to a House finance subcommittee over a plan to allow options to be traded on more than one exchange.

LEAD: A prosecution witness who testified against three reputed mobsters in the killing of a New York City police detective - and then recanted -was found shot dead in the Bronx, the police said yesterday.

LEAD: ''The Paintings of Jakuchu, Master Artist of Japan'' at the Asia Society is the first major American retrospective devoted to a single Japanese master. This is the kind of show that a number of American institutions involved with theme, group or masterpiece shows of Asian art are now committed to doing.

LEAD: As a made-for-television movie, ''I Love You Perfect'' has the virtue of not being entirely predictable. In fact, for long stretches, it is downright puzzling. That's one way, apparently, of grabbing a viewer's attention, which is what ABC will be attempting this Sunday night at 9 o'clock.

LEAD: Fourteen of the country's most senior Federal judges have written a highly unusual letter that challenges Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist's authority as a spokesman for the Federal judiciary on the death penalty.

LEAD: Really, it's no less likely than waking up to find oneself metamorphosed into a giant cockroach. Jimmie Rainwood (Tom Selleck), a nice, solid citizen with a chirpy wife (Laila Robins) and an airline job, is minding his own business one day when he chances to take a shower. Moments later, he is drying his hair when the police burst in, mistake the hair dryer for a gun, shoot Jimmie, discover their mistake and then arrest him on a trumped-up drug charge.
LEAD: More than 14 tons of cocaine were seized Wednesday in two raids, one on a house near the Mexican border and the other on a Panamanian vessel at sea, Federal narcotics agents said.
LEAD: * Air and Water Technologies Inc. said it would acquire Falcon Associates Inc., an asbestos abatement company, in a $25 million stock swap.
LEAD: The Estonian legislature voted today to suspend a clause in its new election law requiring that voters in local elections fulfill a residency requirement.

LEAD: An article on Tuesday about a memorial service for A. Bartlett Giamatti misidentified Dr. Leon E. Rosenberg, one of the people scheduled to speak. He is the dean of the Yale School of Medicine. The service is scheduled for 4 P.M. today at Woolsey Hall on the Yale campus.

LEAD: Because it is struggling to fill a huge backlog of orders for commercial airliners, the Boeing Company did not want a strike and was surprised when production workers rejected management's wage proposals and walked out, company executives said yesterday.
LEAD: In her first remarks Wednesday as the state's new Superintendent of the Jersey City school system, Elena J. Scambio complained about ''filthy'' walls at central headquarters.

LEAD: A request by Luis Polonia, the Yankee outfielder, to be transferred from the Milwaukee House of Correction to the Dane County Jail in Madison, Wis., has been denied because of overcrowding, Franklin Lotter, superintendent of the House of Correction, said yesterday in Milwaukee.

LEAD: A 15-year-old boy armed with a shotgun and a handgun took a high school drama class hostage today and shot one student in the face before being talked into surrendering, the police said. The wounded student was in fair condition. The youth, armed with a 12-gauge shotgun and a semiautomatic handgun, entered the class of 35 students at Loara High School, 30 miles southeast of Los Angeles, and shot the youth, then ordered the teacher out of the room, Lieut.

LEAD: The nation's biggest retailers yesterday reported generally strong sales in September, but the lag in big-ticket, household durable goods continued to hurt results, particularly at Sears, Roebuck & Company and Montgomery Ward & Company.

LEAD: Rosewood Financial Partners said it had filed for Federal antitrust clearance to raise its stake in the First Executive Corporation to 49.9 percent from 9.95 percent. Rosewood is controlled by the Caroline Hunt trust, benefiting members of the Hunt family of Texas. First Executive is a Los Angeles-based life insurance comapny.

LEAD: The National Association of Securities Dealers awarded its advertising account yesterday to Messner Vetere Berger Carey Schmetterer. The N.A.S.D., a self-regulatory organization for the securities industry, is best known for running Nasdaq, the computerized trading system for the over-the-counter market.

LEAD: East Germans keep heading west. And Bush Administration officials now say they would like the flow of refugees to slow, but that it's up to East Germany to do so by reforming itself economically and politically. Preferring East Germans to stay home sounds harsh, but it's sound policy. And only a country worth living in, not a socialist workhouse, will keep them there.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: There was a time in the 1960's when it seemed that the whole of painting would go Kenneth Noland's way. What more did we need than those limpid, weightless and perfectly sprung constructions? There seemed at that time to be no emotional need that could not be satisfied by the chevron, the diamond, the irregularly shaped canvas and, as of 1967, the long, narrow, horizontal striped images that stretched out forever.

LEAD: David N. Dinkins has campaigned in the last two weeks in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, the Fordham neighborhood of the Bronx and New Dorp, Staten Island. Within the next two weeks, his quest for City Hall will take him to Beverly Hills, Georgetown and the Loop.

LEAD: The Young & Rubicam advertising agency said late yesterday that it would soon be indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges that it participated in bribing Jamaican officials to obtain the Jamaica Tourist Board's advertising account in 1981. The agency, based in New York, said several of its employees might be indicted as well.

LEAD: In Supreme Court in Brooklyn, a defendant was recently convicted of first-degree assault for having intentionally and horribly disfigured a man by dousing him with gasoline and setting him on fire. At the same time, in an adjacent courtroom, two young men were convicted of first-degree robbery for having stolen money at knifepoint from a cab driver, whom they left shaken but unhurt.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Peter Rodney Lessler, a lawyer and senior vice president for planning and acquisitions at Dun & Bradstreet, died, apparently of a heart attack, on Wednesday at St. Clare's Hospital and Health Center in Manhattan. He was 41 years old and lived in Westport, Conn.
LEAD: Mabel K. Staupers, a nurse who spent her career encouraging black women in the health-care profession, died of pneumonia Saturday at her home in Washington. She was 99 years old.
LEAD: More than 300 members of the hospital workers' union staged a wildcat strike yesterday at a nursing home in Washington Heights.
LEAD: Dorothy D. Giannone and Thomas K. Handy have been named senior vice presidents of Young & Rubicam/ New York.
LEAD: Israel's divided inner Cabinet postponed a decision today on Egypt's proposal for direct Palestinian-Israeli negotiations intended to unlock stalemated Middle East peace efforts.
LEAD: Precautions like insect repellant ''may not be practical'' to protect people against tick-borne Lyme disease, Federal health officials said today.
LEAD: The House today endorsed a greatly expanded government role in assisting parents with child care.

LEAD: Most state governors approved of their ''summit conference'' with President Bush because it focused attention on the nation's troubled education system, and because Washington and the states agreed to set national performance standards - to be measured by a sort of ''report card'' on every state and the Federal
LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson announced yesterday that he plans to be the host of a weekly television program beginning next fall.
LEAD: A fire broke out in a 160-bed nursing home Thursday night, killing at least 11 people and sending dozens to hospitals, the authorities said.

LEAD: The Soviet Union has sharply increased its military aid to the Cambodian Government in Phnom Penh this year, roughly doubling deliveries of arms and ammunition over 1988 levels, Asian diplomats and Cambodian rebel leaders say.

LEAD: Dora Zucker Friedman, an aide to government officeholders and an advocate for West Side tenant groups, died in her sleep, apparently of natural causes, Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 77 years old.

LEAD: The Bush Administration warned today that it might have to re-examine its support for European Community efforts to forge a single market by the end of 1992 if Europeans continued taking actions that discriminated against the United States. Officials cited a recent television directive calling for majority European content in programming and policies that favor European computer chips.
LEAD: The Sysco Corporation, which is engaged in food distribution and service systems, yesterday priced $330 million in liquid yield option notes due 2004 through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
LEAD: Mario Cuomo is a good man to talk to for a fresh supply of an essential weapon in the war against drugs - stubbornness.

LEAD: How important is the use of numbers in everyday life? The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art counts the ways with the free exhibition ''Numbers,'' which will run through Oct. 26 at the college's Arthur A. Houghton Jr. Gallery and Lubalim Study Center, Third Avenue and Seventh Street.

LEAD: Two months before his first meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, Pope John Paul II urged the Soviet authorities today to grant immediate legal status to the long-suppressed Ukrainian Catholic Church.

LEAD: More than 110 dealers will display paintings, rugs, toys, jewelry, quilts, linen and other items at the New York Armory Antiques Show at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 67th Street. Hours are noon to 6 P.M. on Sunday. Admission is $7. Information: 861-3358.

LEAD: The Weirton Steel Corporation, which was bought by its employees a few years ago, is offering $300 million in senior notes due 1999 through Bear, Stearns & Company.
LEAD: Across the street from the cavernous building where the Boeing Company builds 747 jets is an old cafe called the Overtime Inn.

LEAD: GOLF Three Tied for Lead: Lanny Wadkins posted an early eight-under-par 62 yesterday and then watched Mark Wiebe and Tom Sieckmann match it in the first round of the Texas Open at the Oak Hills Country Club in San Antonio. The trio, all seeking their first title of 1989, held a one-shot lead over Dan Forsman.
LEAD: Ben Johnson and Carl Lewis faced each other today for the first time in more than a year, this time in the unlikely setting of a committee hearing room on Capitol Hill.

LEAD: Three men, including the owner and president of the Monarch Funding Corporation of New York, have been charged with racketeering in connection with a penny stock fraud scheme that law-enforcement officials say cost customers around the world more than $10 million.

LEAD: No stereotype of lawyers is more common or more unflattering than that of pin-striped locusts descending on tragedies in quest of clients long before the smoke has cleared or the black box has been found.

LEAD: The Kansas City Star and The Kansas City Times, journalistic institutions in Missouri for more than a century, will merge sometime next year into a single morning newspaper to be called The Kansas City Star, the papers' publisher announced yesterday.
LEAD: Dr. Robert Tuby, a retired orthopedic surgeon, died of a heart attack Saturday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 82 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

LEAD: Frank Robinson, the leading candidate for American League manager of the year, has agreed to return as the Baltimore Orioles' manager in 1990. His coaching staff has also been asked back. Robinson's relationship with the players apparently had much to do with the decision. The Evening Sun, the Baltimore newspaper, yesterday quoted Barbara Robinson, the manager's wife, as having said: ''He wouldn't leave those guys.

LEAD: The Rev. Cedric Fitz-Oswald Thompson, a Perpetual Deacon in the Espicopal Diocese of Newark and the assistant at Christ Church in East Orange, N.J., died of a heart attack Monday at his home in Orange, N.J. He was 62 years old.

LEAD: The fall festival season arrives this weekend in and around the Hudson Valley with a series of country fairs featuring apples, pumpkins, cider, antiques, country cooking and music, with the scenery showing the first signs of autumnal colors.

LEAD: Law students who are packing suitcases for job interviews at firms around the country are likely to find only an interview, not an all-expenses-paid vacation. Troubled by the escalating costs of recruitment, law firms are putting limits on accommodations and expenses for prospective associates.
LEAD: The Rangers, in what they called General Manager Neil Smith's first trade of significant magnitude, yesterday sent Michel Petit to the Nordiques for Randy Moller.

LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose in fairly active trading yesterday, pushed higher by a jump in the dollar, which rose despite a bigger-than-anticipated increase in European interest rates.

LEAD: Biin, a venture between the Intel Corporation and Siemens A.G. of West Germany, said it was seeking a buyer for its computer technology. Formed in June 1988, Biin was developing a computer that would use multiple processors for highly specialized applications, where the possibility of system failures must be minimized.

LEAD: The role of the U.S. military in the Panamanian uprising was greater than what the Administration has been acknowledging, the White House said, also indicating that the Administration performed badly. Page A1 Conspirators in the attempted coup included some of Gen. Noriega's close advisers, said diplomats.

A Boost for Foreign Airlines In a reversal of policy, the Transportation Department proposed rules that would allow foreign companies to fly into many cities in the United States, so long as they do not compete with existing service.
LEAD: The White House said today that President Bush would undergo a minor operation Friday to remove a cyst from the middle finger of his right hand.

LEAD: The Jets' woeful running game, which is averaging 3.7 yards a carry, will finally meet its defensive equal Monday night when the Raiders come into Giants Stadium with a new head coach who, unfortunately for Los Angeles, doesn't play defense.

LEAD: They used to call the Cubs a lot of things when Rick Reuschel pitched here, many of them uncomplimentary. But those are distant if unpleasant memories now, at the end of a season that will be remembered here for the achievements of the Boys of Zimmer.

LEAD: In a move that underscores a long-term change in the auto industry, the General Motors Corporation announced yesterday that for the first time it would establish a joint venture with its smaller competitor, the Chrysler Corporation, to make manual transmissions and other components.

LEAD: The Lodestar Group disclosed that it had proposed a recapitalization plan to ADC Telecommunications Inc. that would have given its shareholders a special dividend of $16 a share in cash and $2 in senior subordinated debt. LEAD: An interesting, if narrow, account of Western culture could be written through the history of its musical instruments. As populations grew, as technologies developed, as economic forces had their impact, old instruments evolved to meet new social needs. That was popularly and reverently known as progress.
LEAD: A judge refused today to block a pact to tear down the Shoreham, L.I., nuclear power plant.

LEAD: Senate Republicans said tonight that they might be willing to strike a deal with Democrats to keep certain spending and tax measures, including their proposed reduction in the capital gains tax rate, out of a pending deficit reduction package.

LEAD: Some 8,000 weary but jubilant East Germans, who had besieged the West German Embassy in Prague since Monday, arrived here aboard sealed trains today after being officially expelled from their homeland.

LEAD: J.R. Reid, the Charlotte Hornets' first-round draft pick, has been signed to a multiyear contract. The announcement yesterday came only hours before the Miami Heat signed its No. 1 draft choice, Glen Rice, the forward who led Michigan to the national championship last season.

LEAD: Among the rebellious officers who took part in the violent coup attempt against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega were some of his close advisers, including two officers directly responsible for protecting the Panamanian leader from such a betrayal, diplomats and officials here said today.

LEAD: The White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, today ordered a review of the Administration's reaction to the attempted coup in Panama in the aftermath of what senior White House officials acknowledge was an ineffective response to the attempted overthrow of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. ''We did not do it perfectly,'' one of the highest officials at the White House said.

LEAD: If the Chicago Cubs viewed their six-run outburst in the first inning tonight as a positive sign, it was nothing compared with the good omen they encountered in the fifth inning: They actually retired Will Clark.

LEAD: Vowing to reform the nation's futures markets ''once and for all,'' the chairman and ranking minority member of the Senate Agriculture Committee introduced legislation today intended to strengthen Federal regulation of the markets.

LEAD: The most dramatic and affecting moment in Hou Hsiao-hsien's ''City of Sadness'' has the calm of a still photograph. The camera lingers on a young Taiwanese named Lin Wen-ching as he stares from a prison window toward the place where his cellmates -also political prisoners of the Nationalist Chinese - have just been taken.
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 469 money market mutual funds decreased by $429.3 million, to $348.94 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

LEAD: A 32-year-old Queens woman whose home life had been unraveling herded her five children into her clothes-strewn bedroom yesterday and forced two of them out the window of the 10th-floor apartment before rescuers burst in, officials said. The woman's 7-year-old daughter died after plunging to the ground, and a 3-year-old son was critically injured.
LEAD: In Laurie Anderson's performance piece ''Empty Places,'' the song that goes the furthest in distilling its mood and summing up its themes is a witty new ballad called ''Hiawatha.''
LEAD: In the English department at Central Connecticut State University, there is an air of quiet desperation: no secretaries remain to type a syllabus or organize a professor's life.

LEAD: Columbus Day will be observed on Monday, but the Columbus Day parade in Manhattan will be held today. LEAD: A team of Federal investigators today began work to determine the cause of an explosion touched off when a fishing boat struck a submerged pipeline.

LEAD: The times have almost caught up with George Ohr, the turn-of-the-century American potter who always knew that he was a genius and that the pots he produced were unprecedented as both art and craft. The exhibition of 91 examples of Ohr's work that has just opened at the American Craft Museum could be larger and more complete.

LEAD: Marina Woroniecka Viets, who won the Polish Army's highest military decoration as a 17-year-old in the Warsaw uprising in World War II, died of lymphoma Sept. 25 at Loudoun Memorial Hospital in Leesburg, Va. She was 61 years old and lived in Middleburg, Va.

LEAD: Even as the racing world mourns the death of Secretariat, it will turn its attention tomorrow to the colt who is on the verge of completing the most impressive 3-year-old campaign since Secretariat's 1973 Triple Crown season.

LEAD: IN this long-lasting bull market, hundreds of companies have either raised their payouts or initiated special dividends, or both. But now, Arnold Kaufman, editor of Standard & Poor's Outlook, an investment advisory newsletter, says the dividend boom has begun what might be a long decline.

LEAD: For some years there have been black assistant coaches in the National Football League with the potential to be head coaches. LEAD: Dr. Lowyd W. R. Ballantyne Jr., a retired plastic surgeon, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at North Carolina Memorial Hospital in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 65 years old and lived in Chapel Hill.

LEAD: Cape May is a New Jersey shore town, but one that is a cut different from most others. It is at the state's southeastern tip, which is actually south of the Mason-Dixon Line. Nevertheless, its charm is not in its Southern ties, but in its Victorian ones - its fidelity to the buildings and parks that have given the place its distinctive look.
LEAD: A Federal district judge today upheld Hialeah's prohibition on animal sacrifices, saying the Constitution protects only a religion's beliefs, not its practices.

LEAD: OPEC and the European Community took the first step today toward closer cooperation between the oil-producing nations and their European consumers. Subroto, Secretary General of the 13-nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, met with officials of the trading bloc in the first high-level contact.

LEAD: Victor Feingold, a lawyer who was general counsel to the Distillery, Wine and Allied Workers International Union, died Monday while recuperating from heart surgery at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 77 years old.

LEAD: If it was not that his compatriots were fleeing his land through every crack they could find or create, the 40th anniversary of East Germany might have been a crowning moment for Erich Honecker.

LEAD: The investor group set to acquire American Medical International Inc. for about $2 billion, plus $1.4 billion in assumed debt, canceled its agreement today and submitted a new proposal worth at least $260 million less in cash.

LEAD: Senior Administration officials said today that the American military had played a greater role in the Panamanian uprising than it had previously acknowledged.

LEAD: In the hours before a game, Tomas Sandstrom can be found in the basement of Madison Square Garden, his stick laying across a work table. With a gas torch, a saw and a bit of imagination, Sandstrom will labor over the stick for half an hour, subtly shaping it to his specifications.

LEAD: Most college conference commissioners said this afternoon that they agreed with the spirit of the dramatic legislation proposed by a National Collegiate Athletic Association panel, legislation intended to reduce the time pressures faced by college athletes.

LEAD: The Dalai Lama, the exiled religious and political leader of Tibet, was named the 1989 winner of the Nobel Peace Prize today in recognition of his nonviolent campaign over nearly 40 years to end China's domination of his homeland.

LEAD: It was a pleasant event at the Penfield Beach Pavilion, the kind some like to call casually elegant. There were a hundred guests or so, and the afternoon sun glinted on the sand and the water outside and streamed in through the ceiling-high windows. There was crab and cold roast beef and breast of turkey and bottles of chardonnay on the long buffet.

LEAD: For the first time in many years, the Knicks had an uneventful off season and will have all their players under contract and ready to go today when they open their first training camp under Stu Jackson at the State University in Purchase, N.Y.

LEAD: Twenty relatives of political prisoners and ''disappeared'' people stormed the Costa Rican Embassy and seized 19 hostages today to protest against the Government of President Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador.
LEAD: In a significant policy change meant to spur competition in world aviation, the Transportation Department today proposed to open additional American cities to foreign airlines.

LEAD: Small shops selling an array of quirky as well as conventional hosiery have been moving leg wear from the obscurity of the lingerie department to the neon-lighted prominence of storefront windows.
LEAD: One day after the House voted to repeal the program of expanded health insurance benefits for older Americans, Senate leaders today made a last-ditch effort to salvage part of it.
LEAD: If the Nets do not improve this season, it will not be because they were afraid to make changes.

LEAD: The Dalai Lama, the exiled religious and political leader of Tibet, was named the 1989 winner of the Nobel Peace Prize today in recognition of his nonviolent campaign over nearly 40 years to end China's domination of his homeland.

LEAD: It was a pleasant event at the Penfield Beach Pavilion, the kind some like to call casually elegant. There were a hundred guests or so, and the afternoon sun glinted on the sand and the water outside and streamed in through the ceiling-high windows. There was crab and cold roast beef and breast of turkey and bottles of chardonnay on the long buffet.

LEAD: When the Hong Kong-based Peninsula Hotel chain took over the Hotel Maxim's de Paris on Fifth Avenue at 55th Street last year, it inherited a somewhat prissy Old World French dining room called Adrienne that, despite its quality food, never really caught on among New Yorkers. Diners in New York City still need compelling reasons to enter a hotel restaurant for a meal, especially one without a separate street entrance.

LEAD: Harriet Winslow: a prim, sexually repressed schoolteacher fleeing the deprivations of her past. Tomas Arroyo: a handsome, smoldering young general in Pancho Villa's revolutionary Mexican army. The old gringo: an American writer, renowned for his crusading journalism and scathing wit, who has elected to cut all ties with his home and family.

LEAD: Reuben Mayes, the tailback for the Saints who twice was selected for the Pro Bowl, will have surgery next week on his right Achilles' tendon and will be out the rest of the season, the club announced yesterday in New Orleans. Mayes first felt pain in the heel July 25, the day after he ran a long run in training camp in La Crosse, Wis.

LEAD: The Soviet Union has bought 100,000 metric tons of soybean meal and an additional 200,000 tons of corn for delivery in 1989-90, under a long-term supply agreement, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. The meal and corn were in addition to an order for 2 million tons of corn announced Tuesday.

LEAD: For the last five weeks, Esther W. Levin and her cat, Amor, have been guests at the Gramercy Park Hotel, courtesy of Consolidated Edison. The utility pays for the room, for food, even for the new pink robe Mrs. Levin wears as she waits for someone to tell her she can go home.

LEAD: Nearly midway between the primary and the general election, David N. Dinkins, the Democratic mayoral nominee, has largely adopted the classic campaign stance of a front-runner -carefully avoiding overexposure while doing whatever he can to help his Republican rival, Rudolph W. Giuliani, self-destruct.
LEAD: COUNTRY music, which all too frequently skirts New York while making its way around the rest of America, is invading Manhattan for more than three weeks, starting tonight.

LEAD: Nothing was too slippery for the Senate Finance Committee as it struggled to polish off the fiscal 1990 tax bill this week. Industrious committee members dredged up a little favor for the tuxedo-rental business, a great big one for grain interests and so many others that literally no one knew what they'd done when they finally finished at 2:15 Thursday morning.
LEAD: Loketo, one of the premier soukous groups now based in Paris, came to S.O.B.'s on Wednesday night and did what it does best: packed the dance floor.
LEAD: The leader of an anti-abortion group was jailed today after refusing to pay a $1,000 fine imposed for his part in a protest during the Democratic National Convention.

LEAD: Moscow will be incapable of a surprise attack on the West by 1991 if it makes the cuts in conventional forces promised by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the International Institute for Strategic Studies said today.

LEAD: You get the feeling here - once again - that the Los Angeles Rams are going places, big places. Last Sunday they topped the glitzy San Francisco 49ers at Candlestick Park, 13-12, in the final seconds, championship-caliber fashion. The Rams now have a dangerous passing attack to complement their longtime running ways.

LEAD: A fundamental tenet of Buddhism is that the path to salvation runs between the extremes of self-denial and self-indulgence. Therein lies a hint of the path by which the Dalai Lama, spiritual and temporal leader of Tibetan Buddhists, eventually hopes to return from exile.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Stocks ended narrowly mixed yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average rose modestly to yet another high.

LEAD: The entertainment division of NBC has commissioned five hourlong health specials from MacNeil/Lehrer Productions, the network announced yesterday. The series, which is to feature Dr. C. Everett Koop, the former Surgeon General of the United States, will address such issues as AIDS, the escalating cost of health care, and care for the elderly, the network said.
LEAD: Martha Graham, speaking of her work, has said she does not want to be understood but to be felt. Her dances, in fact, are at their best when they are at their most mysterious.

LEAD: Harry A. LaBurt, a doctor and former director of Creedmoor State Hospital in Queens for 26 years, died on Monday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I., after being struck by a car. He was 91 years old and lived in Bellerose, Queens.

LEAD: Ever since a rogue program created by a graduate student jammed a nationwide computer network last year, the rapid spread of such disruptive software, known as viruses, has caused growing alarm among computer users. Now, to fight fire with fire, some companies, individuals and even a Government research laboratory are crafting a new breed of what have been called anti-viruses to hunt down intruders.

LEAD: Although Donald J. Trump arouses considerable skepticism among Wall Street stock traders, a minority is starting to take seriously his offer to buy the AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, for $7.5 billion in cash.

LEAD: Congress's decision to drastically cut back on valuable benefits of the 1988 catastrophic-health insurance program generated cheers from the well-to-do elderly who opposed the law. They didn't want to pay the surtax that finances it. But curtailing the program also means that millions will lose. In the wake of the defeat, those losers deserve attention.

''I think the record will show that there was never a chance to have him handed over to us,'' the President said of the Panamanian leader.

LEAD: The personal essay is a dangerous form, prone to banality or overreaching. Fred Marx's ''Dreams From China'' and Ralph Arlyck's ''Current Events,'' the first-person films that will be shown at the New York Film Festival tonight at 6:30, show traces of both problems. They are extremely sincere but slight films, not cogent enough to deal with the huge subjects they tackle, and not formally innovative enough to make up for that lack of substance.

LEAD: With the arrival of autumn, the herb garden begins to lose life, and many cooks rely on dried herbs from now until spring. The flavor of some dried herbs is more intense, so they should be substituted in smaller quantities. Other dried herbs lose much of their character. Basil, chervil, coriander leaves and parsley are much better fresh than dried.

It's the kind of uneasy existence that can drive a good man to chewing tobacco, which

LEAD: Closing out the dozen years in which he guided New York City's independent and home-brewed foreign policy, Mayor Edward I. Koch yesterday issued one of those communiques for which his tenure was renowned.
LEAD: Louisiana lawyers went to Federal court here today to try to revive an old Louisiana law banning all abortions.

LEAD: The tax and mail fraud conspiracy conviction of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. was challenged today in a Federal appellate court as resulting from a rush prosecution that violated his right to due process.

''Dancing for Mr. B: Six Balanchine Ballerinas'' is as graceful, taut and fiercely controlled as the dancers who are its subjects. In the opening scene, Darci Kistler - at 25 years of age the youngest of them - recalls that as an adolescent she read that Balanchine selected a perfume for each of his dancers. ''I thought it was wonderful that there was a man who cared that much,'' she says, setting the tone for Anne Belle's and Deborah Dickson's documentary. This is not a study of the great choreographer and the guiding spirit behind the New York City Ballet, but a portrait of women who feel privileged to have been shaped by him. Balanchine formed everything from the trajectory of their careers to the elongation of the leg muscles that helped create his dancers' characteristic lithe bodies. And though he died in 1983, at the age of 79, he hovers over this film like some omnipotent ghost, still choreographing his dancers' responses, still hindering any impulse to chafe against his control.
LEAD: The Toronto Blue Jays finally found a way tonight to live with Rickey Henderson: outscore him.

LEAD: * Banister Continental Ltd., Edmonton, Alberta, a pipeline, civil, marine and industrial construction company, said a joint venture in which its Foundation Co. of Canada Ltd. unit has a 45 percent interest had won a $100 million (Canadian) contract from Marathon Realty Co. for the construction of a waterfront project in Vancouver, British Columbia.

LEAD: Two months after Justice Department budget officials limited official travel to conventions, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh and five aides flew to a Bar Association convention in Honolulu in August aboard an otherwise empty Government Boeing 727.

LEAD: Simple inventions are not always simple. Witness Robert G. Merrick's Personal Punch, a finger-sized device that punches holes in calling cards so they can be put on a Rolodex.

LEAD: Spurning the lead of the House, the Senate tonight voted against repealing a program providing expanded health benefits to 33 million Medicare beneficiaries. It then voted unanimously to scale back the plan significantly and eliminate the surtax that finances it.

LEAD: Lounging in a bathrobe and speaking conversationally, the actress Mary Shultz recalls the story of David and Bathsheba. She tells it as her own story, as the victim of a king who seduced her and had her husband killed. As she explains in David Greenspan's ''II Samuel ll, Etc.'' (at Home for Contemporary Theater and Art), she was a woman completely without choice.

Santella Jr., a financial planner at the Price Waterhouse accounting firm in New York. The Rev. James Flynn officiated at St. Mary's Chapel of SS. Philip and James Roman Catholic Church.

LEAD: Arnold Shaw, a writer about popular music and the founder of the Popular Music Research Center at the University of Nevada at Las Vegas, died of cancer on Sept. 26 at his home in Las Vegas. He was 80 years old.

LEAD: Busy parents with busy children too often live life on a treadmill. The children need to be transported between home and school and after-school programs in a seemingly never-ending cycle of daily activities that often compete with the parents' own obligations.
LEAD: Leftist protesters ended a takeover of the Costa Rican Embassy today, releasing the 12 hostages they had held for a day to protest the rightist Government of President Alfredo Cristiani.

LEAD: A jury in Chicago ruled yesterday that Seymour M. Hersh, the investigative journalist, did not libel former Prime Minister Morarji Desai of India when he described him as a paid informer for the Central Intelligence Agency.

''Your lungs are about as bad as they can get,'' the nurse explains to the 83-year-old man. ''Your lungs aren't going to get better, and so the act of putting you on the machine is almost a futile effort.'' In a long conversation, the nurse lets this patient know what his options are and tries to determine his wishes, as kindly as possible but with the suggestion that she has done this many times before. ''I want to help you, but I only want to help you in the manner in which you want to be helped,'' she says. ''I don't want to keep you alive unless you like living.'' A half-dozen young medical professionals gather around the bed of an old woman, a stroke victim who cannot speak and can communicate only by means of the faintest movements. They want to discuss the possibility of removing her breathing tube and the machine to which it is connected. Does she understand what the consequences of this may be? Is she prepared for the worst? Is she worried about the way her death may affect her devoted husband? The woman attempts to answer this barrage of difficult questions by weakly signaling yes or no, but she is soon exhausted. She indicates that she would like the conversation to stop.
LEAD: The Douglaston and Little Neck sections of Queens look and sound more like New England villages than New York City neighborhoods.

LEAD: Policy makers at the Federal Reserve decided to leave interest rates unchanged in late August, after a period earlier in the summer when they were nudging rates lower, according to minutes of the meeting released today.

LEAD: The AMR Corporation's most likely response to a $7.5 billion takeover bid by Donald J. Trump would be to move about a fifth of its stock into an employee stock ownership plan, investment bankers and lawyers said yesterday.

LEAD: TENNIS U.S. Gains Semifinals: The top-seeded United States team will meet Czechoslovakia and Spain will face Australia today in the semifinals of the Federation Cup tournament in Tokyo. The United States beat eighth-seeded Austria, 3-0, and No. 3 Czechoslovakia defeated fifth-seeded West Germany, 2-1, yesterday in the quarterfinals.(AP)

LEAD: N. Elizabeth Landshof and John J. Fath were married yesterday at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. J. Seymour Flinn performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Daniel Brady, a Roman Catholic priest.

LEAD: Craig Biggio, the rookie starting catcher for the Houston Astros, was convicted in Houston yesterday of driving while intoxicated. He was placed on two years' probation, fined $350 and ordered to perform 50 hours of community service. (AP)

LEAD: Despite the success the Devils had with the 20 players they used in Philadelphia on opening night, look for changes in the lineup for the home opener Saturday night.

LEAD: Nine store chains, including some of the most glittering names in American retailing, have been put up for sale in recent months in what is proving to be a powerful lesson on what can happen when companies with high expectations enter a volatile industry on the verge of a slowdown.
LEAD: Will Morton 8th blew into town from Colorado about three weeks ago to give Brooklyn back a piece of its own lost magic. He came to restore the carousel in Prospect Park.

LEAD: Murray Altman, owner of a Jacuzzi manufacturing company in Sylmar, Calif., has patented a self-cleaning hot tub. The tub contains a perforated tube that can spray water down the sides. Controlled by a microprocessor, which starts a cleaning cycle after the tub has been drained, the tube first sprays cold water for 30 seconds, then sprays water containing a mixture of detergent, disinfectant and anti-spotting agents for 75 seconds.

LEAD: While cocaine has dominated public concern about drug use, alcohol remains the drug of choice among suburban teen-agers, like those in Westchester County.

LEAD: The new contract settlement negotiated between New York City hospitals and the hospital workers' union is costly to the industry, but fair to the workers. It provides 7.5 percent increases in each of the first two years and 5 percent in the third, with a $500 cash bonus to each worker in 1991. That's a generous wage package, so generous that the leaders of the city's municipal unions will inevitably try to use it as the model for their negotiations with City Hall next year.

LEAD: The MGM/UA Communications Company said the Qintex Group of Australia, which has agreed to acquire MGM/UA for $1.45 billion, was late delivering a $50 million deposit. The announcement creates new uncertainty about Qintex's ability to raise money for the deal. According to the purchase agreement, MGM/UA, a motion picture producer and distributor, was supposed to receive a nonrefundable $50 million letter of credit from Qintex on Sept.
LEAD: Federal futures regulators voted down a proposal today that would have allowed them to force dishonest brokers and traders to pay restitution to the customers they had cheated.
LEAD: 1. These jubilant East Germans reached their destination after a circuitous journey from Prague. What detour did they take and why was it necessary?

LEAD: Now that Kevin Mack, their chief running back, has been sentenced to six months in jail after pleading guilty to a drug-abuse charge, the Cleveland Browns are in the market for a quality runner. They would take someone like Herschel Walker of the Dallas Cowboys, the All-Pro whom they admit to having made inquiries about.

LEAD: Four members of the Yonkers City Council voted last year to defy the city's agreement to obey a court order remedying 40 years of deliberate housing segregation. They were heavily fined, and have now approached the United States Supreme Court with the argument that a Federal court may not order them to vote a certain way ''at the price of their conscience.

LEAD: Owners of condominium units in the Southeast and the Caribbean were among those hit hard by Hurricane Hugo. The total damage to insured property came to a record $4.5 billion, and the storm's devastation holds an important insurance lesson for condominium owners in coastal areas.
LEAD: Detectors, No Sprinklers The nursing home fire that killed nine people in Norfolk, Va., was started by a cigarette or match that ignited a foam mattress, the fire chief said.

LEAD: The five commodity exchanges in New York, outgrowing their space in the World Trade Center, are considering moving to Jersey City and are talking to municipal officials on both sides of the Hudson River to see which could provide a better package of tax breaks and other inducements.
LEAD: A law barring horse-drawn carriages from most of midtown Manhattan was vetoed yesterday by Mayor Edward I. Koch, who said the legislation ''goes too far.''
LEAD: Japan In the Land of the Brokenhearted By Michael Shapiro 245 pages. Henry Holt & Company. $19.95.
LEAD: Members of a jury here say they acquitted a man of rape because the woman's clothing suggested she had ''asked for it.''

LEAD: Frederic de Hoffmann, a nuclear physicist who worked on the Manhattan Project, helped develop the hydrogen bomb and later directed the Salk Institute for Biological Studies for 18 years, died of complications of AIDS Wednesday in La Jolla, Calif. He was 65 years old.

LEAD: An article in SportsMonday on the success of the Oakland Athletics this season omitted one of the teams on which four pitchers won at least 20 games each in the same season. The Chicago White Sox accomplished it in 1920.

LEAD: Before the second game of the National League pennant playoff with the San Francisco Giants, someone asked Andre Dawson if it was correct that he was the father figure to the younger players in the Chicago Cubs' clubhouse.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Enough plutonium to cause an accidental nuclear reaction escaped unnoticed into an air duct at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant, according to an independent study of the plant released yesterday. The report said such a reaction could have occurred under certain circumstances.

LEAD: Poland's new Government announced detailed plans today to convert the country to a market economy, warning of tight money, bankruptcy and unemployment along the way but promising to soften the pain with unemployment benefits.

LEAD: Prices of Treasury and corporate securities soared and yields fell yesterday as the Government's latest employment data indicated a further weakening of the economy. Unemployment rose by one-tenth of 1 percent, to 5.2 percent of the labor force in September, and there was a decline in factory jobs in a broad range of industries.

LEAD: Irving Newman, a retired hat manufacturer who served as a neighborhood aide to three New York City mayors, died of a heart attack Thursday at Edward White Hospital in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 74 years old and lived in Tampa, Fla.

LEAD: The Mets acknowledged yesterday that Davey Johnson had kept his job as manager of the team on a split vote that embroiled senior officials of the club. But they said the deciding vote had been cast by Frank Cashen, the general manager, after he consulted the owners and informed Johnson that ''some things have to change.

LEAD: A 15-month-old Brooklyn boy died last night from injuries suffered when his father backed over him with the family car, the police said. The child, Joseph Mandel, was apparently playing in the driveway of his home at 736 East Third Street in the Borough Park section. His father, Samson, did not see him as he was backing his 1977 Pontiac station wagon out of the driveway, a police spokesman, Sgt.

LEAD: Judge John M. Walker Jr. of Federal District Court in Manhattan is perhaps best known for his most recent role: the cool-headed handling of Leona Helmsley's tax-fraud trial last summer. But he is also President Bush's first cousin, and the President's nominee to fill one of the 13 judgeships on the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, the
LEAD: The dollar rose slightly yesterday, despite efforts once again by the United States and its economic allies to rein the currency in.

LEAD: Enough is enough in this Deep Throat business. A few days ago a rumor spread like fire through a straw rick that Deep Throat, world's most famous news source, was none other than Alexander Haig.
LEAD: Buoyed by an unexpected increase in unemployment for September and a sharp decline in factory jobs, blue-chip stocks rose to another record yesterday.

LEAD: Olian Small, 36 years old, has been charged with attempting a murder last April by tying a knot in the oxygen tube of Helen Ada Potter, an 81-year-old patient at a nursing home where he worked. She died four days later, the authorities said, and Mr. Small was arrested Wednesday evening after he was indicted.

LEAD: Here in the remote Narmada River valley, in hamlets that most Indians have never heard of, a new and growing national environmental movement has drawn its battle line against large-scale development in India.
LEAD: Two Swiss serving with the International Committee of the Red Cross were kidnapped today by gunmen in the southern port city of Sidon, the police said.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a Florida Supreme Court decision striking down an abortion law incorrectly reported that the teen-ager who was the subject of the case had obtained her father's permission to have an abortion.
LEAD: Americans took out $3.48 billion more in consumer debt than they retired in August, the Government reported today.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: 1. East Germans who had taken refuge in Prague were required to return to East Germany before going on to West Germany. The device enabled East Berlin to contend that the refugees had first come home, as it had repeatedly demanded of them.

LEAD: Robert T. Ashmore, a former member of the House of Representatives from South Carolina, died Wednesday at St. Francis Hospital in Greenville, S.C., where he lived. He had undergone open heart surgery last summer and was suffering from pneumonia and kidney failure. He was 85 years old.

LEAD: Rudolph W. Giuliani has borrowed $200,000 from the Republican State Committee to pay for television commercials, according to his latest financial report filed yesterday with the city Campaign Finance Board.

LEAD: The 3Com Corporation said today that Digital Communications Associates Inc. intends to purchase 3Com common stock valued in excess of $15 million, but less than 15 percent of the company's outstanding shares.

LEAD: An article in Sports Pages on Thursday about university presidents asking for limitations on college sports misidentified the co-sponsor of a bill that would require all colleges to disclose graduation rates for athletes. Representative Ed Towns, Democrat of Brooklyn, was the co-sponsor with Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New
LEAD: The Federal Government may soon approve airline advertising practices that many state officials and consumer advocates say are deceptive or misleading.

LEAD: Diana Bliss Schwab, a daughter of Mrs. Julian S. Stein Jr. of Union Bridge, Md., and Oquossoc, Me., and Walter P. B. Schwab of Providence, R.I., was married yesterday at the Iron Horse Farm in Union Bridge to Marc Tyson Kennedy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Tyson Kennedy of Pittsburgh. Judge Lawrence Shipley of the Carroll County Circuit Court in Westminster, Md., officiated.

LEAD: Tracey Elizabeth Braun and Christopher Clark McIsaac were married yesterday at the First Congregational Church in West Tisbury, Mass., in a ceremony performed by the Rev. James Martin. The bride is the daughter of Howard William Braun of St. Michael's, Md., and Mrs. Richard Roberts Spillman of Berwyn, Pa.

LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson may have found the ideal interim occupation for a once and future Presidential candidate -being host of a television talk show. Mr. Jackson, who sought the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1984 and 1988 and is considered likely to run again in 1992, said last week that the debut of his hourlong weekly show, ''Voices of America With Jesse Jackson,'' was planned for fall 1990.

LEAD: The marriage of Dorian Margaret Wiggin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Mitchell Wiggin 3d of Short Hills, N.J., to James Patrick Maguire Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Maguire of Short Hills, took place there yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church. The Rev. Charles A. Cesaretti performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev.

LEAD: JIM KNUTZON IS SITTING IN THE restaurant of the Hilton Hotel in Pleas-anton, Calif., near Oakland, solemnly regarding the plate of swordfish smothered in sauteed vegetables just set before him. With his head bowed, he delivers what might be construed as a modern-day meditation. Knutzon, a former pesticide salesman who now advises farmers on pesticide alternatives, expresses the hope that people across America will soon be able to sit down to meals that are free of toxic pesticide residues.

LEAD: A potentially potent computer virus, known variously as Datacrime or the Columbus Day Virus, is programmed to activate itself Thursday in a large number of computer systems in North America, computer security experts say.

LEAD: Six months after the Department of Education began requiring college students receiving financial aid to sign oaths that the money would not be used to buy drugs, many university officials say they have no plans to enforce compliance with the oath.

LEAD: The drive for convenience may soon make microwave dinners, videotapes and french fries standard fare in vending machines. The developments stem from the desire of several new companies to cash in on the vending craze. And to keep sales from growing stale, several existing companies have moved upscale.

LEAD: A panel of United States Olympic Committee officials will interview the last of six finalists for the job of executive director tomorrow. The leading candidate is a man who had the job two years ago and quit after 17 days.
LEAD: Apple- and ginger-flavored chicken with noodles is a dish of great versatility.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Camilla MacFadyen and Montgomery M. Lewis Jr. were married yesterday in Small Point, Me. The Rev. John Ineson, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Small Point Baptist Church.
LEAD: Huzzahs to Maggie McCool for not losing her ''cool'' about repercussions on her distaste of brutifying biology.

LEAD: The United States turns out to be fortunate indeed that President Bush decided against strong U.S. military intervention in Tuesday's Panamanian coup attempt. But the way he reached that decision now looks like a model of incompetence.
LEAD: LARRY GELBART IS SIT-ting in a Manhattan rehearsal studio, watching some actors run through a scene from his new play, ''Mastergate,'' and he's laughing.

LEAD: MOST cigarette smokers quit on their own, but a third of them seek help from programs like the Stop Smoking Clinic at the Institute for Better Health in New Haven. James A. Schlueter, the executive director of the institute, a nonprofit health information service, says the best programs combine several approaches with follow-up support for struggling ex-smokers.
LEAD: SARA COLERIDGE, A VICTORIAN DAUGHTER Her Life and Essays. By Bradford Keyes Mudge. Illustrated. 287 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $30.
LEAD: It was not Kevin Mitchell who delivered the Giants to their moment of triumph tonight. It was not Will Clark.
LEAD: Police killings of citizens in New York City dropped sharply under Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward, bucking a national trend, a survey has found.
LEAD: It is tough to forget the past when everything you do requires you to explain it all over again. So for John Ogrodnick, every success brings another encounter with past failures.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Sandra Jennings said that she and William Hurt (below, second from right) were married ''in the eyes of God,'' but the law looks at things differently. A Manhattan Civil Court judge ruled last week that the weeks Ms. Jennings spent living with the actor while he was filming ''The Big Chill'' (below) in South Carolina seven years ago did not constitute a legal marriage.

LEAD: New York City's troubled private hospitals will not, as hospital representatives predict, be driven into bankruptcy by last week's $250 million settlement with their union workers, financial analysts, state and union officials say.
LEAD: A FRIEND'S WIFE RE-cently persuaded him to buy a memory book, one that would help counteract his lifelong absent-mindedness. The next day, going in to the office, he left it on the train.

John J.
LEAD: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.
LEAD: THE REMAINS OF THE DAY By Kazuo Ishiguro. tr,br1245 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

LEAD: In their relentless quest for a decent apartment in Manhattan, New Yorkers sometimes resort to UNORTHODOX PRACTICES (Pocket Books, Paper, $3.50), an apt title for this hilarious first mystery by Marissa Piesman, co-author of ''The Yuppie Handbook'' and, more to the point, a practicing real estate attorney.
LEAD: BENNETT'S NEW YORK HERALD AND THE RISE OF THE POPULAR PRESS By James L. Crouthamel. 202 pp. Syracuse, N.Y.: Syracuse University Press. $27.95.

Msgr. John Keilty and the Rev. Margaret Gunness, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St.
LEAD: America's farmers are growing safer foods, using toxin-free sprays and other new techniques. By Susan Gilbert.
LEAD: Under a Tent on Park Ave.
LEAD: China expressed ''utmost regret and indignation'' today over the awarding of the Nobel Peace Prize to the Dalai Lama, saying the exiled Tibetan leader was working to undermine national unity.

LEAD: I was enjoying Harrison E. Salisbury's ''A Love Affair With Walking'' (April 16) until I came upon his derisive comments on Los Angeles, a place he says ''no one of right mind'' would consider walking in. I invite Mr. Salisbury to walk among the hipsters who crowd Melrose Avenue, the Orthodox Jews who patronize the kosher shops on Fairfax Avenue and the culturally minded standing in line for the latest exhibit at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.

LEAD: SOME PEOPLE LOVE IT, OTHERS HATE IT, BUT FEW would dispute that Harrods is the world's most famous department store. Its size, its style, its history and mystique combine to place Harrods in a class apart. By night, the hulking Edwardian emporium, with its terra cotta exterior illuminated by 11,000 lights, resembles some giant ocean liner beached, oddly but proudly, in the midst of London's Knightsbridge district.

LEAD: MY LIFE AS A freelance radio reporter from Paris began when I was 51, so it's no wonder that my fellow female journalists are all 20 or 30 years younger than I am. What disconcerts me about this age difference is not, for instance, the fact that the French cabinet ministers who try to seduce them during interviews are younger and more virile than the shambling old fonctionnaires who make the occasional pass at me.

LEAD: YESTERDAY, while going through a stack of outdated newspapers, I ran across an etiquette column in which Miss Manners castigated insensitive clods who would drop in unannounced, likening them to boorish know-nothings, unversed in the subtleties of proper social behavior.
LEAD: Even though the George Washington Trojans are the defending Public Schools Athletic League B Division champions, they have had to scratch just to stay alive.

LEAD: Paul Ranheim, Joey Mullen and Gary Roberts scored goals in a 2-minute-16-second span late in the third period to break open a close game tonight as the Calgary Flames kept the Islanders winless at the Olympic Saddledome with a 6-3 victory.

LEAD: In one of her best recent songs, ''Didn't Expect It to Go Down This Way,'' the country singer and songwriter K. T. Oslin laments being overworked, overweight, undesired and alone. ''I knew life would be hard, but I didn't know how hard,'' she declares. ''How in the world did I end up lonely?''

LEAD: The Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Nancy Williams Rees and Thomas R. Wall 4th. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. G. Rees of Watch Hill, R.I., and New York. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wall 3d of Warwick, Bermuda.
LEAD: I was shocked and dismayed by a patronizing Opinion page piece, ''Touched by an Angel,'' on Aug. 27.

LEAD: MEERA, Stamford's latest Indian restaurant, is another winning newcomer. Its look is as cool as its cuisine is hot, and the diverse menu is demystified by careful translations and by a friendly, expeditious Indian staff adroit in English.

LEAD: THE ITALIANS ARE THE FIRST TO SHOW ready-to-wear collections for 1990, and this weekend spring comes to Milan. As usual, the Milanese are expert at tailoring. But they have given up their crispness in favor of a new fluidity. ''You have to risk,'' says Giorgio Armani. ''It's a feminine collection, for the sophisticated woman who likes to have fun with clothes.

LEAD: PEOPLE ALWAYS ASK ME HOW I can do these crazy things - climbing mountains,'' says Dr. Donald B. Levy, 40, an internist and an instructor at Harvard Medical School. ''But it's not really crazy. Lots of people walk for exercise. I'm just a walker who walks uphill.''

LEAD: ''THIS garage is the inside of my brain,'' said Mundy Hepburn, gliding his arm through the air. Standing in the bed of a Chevy pickup, his frame backlighted by one of his neon sculptures, ''The Wave,'' he described with reverence the ''mystical beauty'' of neon.
LEAD: Just before dawn a couple of weeks ago, peasants in this languid town in Angola's central highlands were awakened by singing and chanting. Then, without warning, the shooting began.

LEAD: Michigan's offense, scoreless in the first half, got touchdowns on its first two possessions in the third quarter today and the Wolverines beat Wisconsin, 24-0, in their Big Ten Conference opener.
LEAD: An audit has uncovered widespread Government mismanagement of an Indian trust fund, including an unexplained disappearance of $17 million because of sloppy bookkeeping, officials said Friday.

LEAD: Squarely in the path of a real-estate development juggernaut, Oglethorpe University has put 15 acres of property, including the school's Greek row, up for sale - and at least a few students are upset about it.

LEAD: For convenience stores, these should be the golden years. First, supermarkets all but killed off corner groceries. Then the supermarkets themselves consolidated into sprawling, remote megastores. The convenience store chains, the field wide open, eagerly expanded across the nation.

LEAD: Chances are that there has never been a survey on this subject, and this oversight could be for a number of reasons. The principal one might be that the answers would be ''Who cares?'' It is perfectly true that this is not something that will change the world. In point of fact, most people have never even thought about it.
LEAD: A pilot program run by the Federal Housing Administration that could spur the use of reverse mortgages is just now getting under way around the country.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Rick Kaplan, the executive producer of ''Prime Time Live,'' the highly conspicuous new ABC News program starring Sam Donaldson and Diane Sawyer, has been wearing a soft cast on his right arm to protect a chronically sore elbow. He did not injure the arm trying to pat himself on the back. LEAD: What is a Morris chair? Which came first - the spindle-back designs of Gustav Stickley or those of Frank Lloyd Wright? How affordable were Arts and Crafts furnishings originally?
LEAD: Taken a good look at your favorite vending machine lately?

Creamer Jr., an Episcopal priest and a cousin of the bride, and Rabbi Abraham Weisman officiated at the Lotos Club in New
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: With the mayoral election, changes in the new York City charter and a wave of commercial development under way in Manhattan, many experts are questioning whether the city has struck a proper balance beetween economic development, construction and historic preservation. Do architects, builders and neighborhood advocates share a vision of the urban environment?
