LEAD: Citing widespread disagreement on campus, Tufts University last week suspended indefinitely a new policy that many students said interfered with their right to free speech.

LEAD: AS Arabs and Israelis have traded talk of peace in recent months, United States diplomacy has seemed to move in the wings, half-player, half-prompter, offering a phrase here, a word there, sometimes a whole chunk of the script. Now, inexorably, a reluctant Washington is being beckoned on stage.
LEAD: A wrongful death case under New York law is treated differently from a similar case under Connecticut law and from the way cases are treated in other states.
LEAD: Home ownership declined in the 1980's for the first time since World War II, Senator Lloyd Bentsen said today, citing high prices and high interest rates.
LEAD: The president of the University of Virginia will resign next year to take a new post as director of a center for the protection of freedom of expression.

LEAD: Senators Cite Progress In Tax Discussions Republicans and Democrats in the Senate report progress in bargaining over a date to vote on reduction of the capital gains tax. Both sides were seeking tactical advantages and avoiding a filibuster. Page 28. Strength Despite Scandal By some measures, religious broadcasting is more powerful now than before Jim Bakker's resignation from the PTL Ministry.

LEAD: IN Ireland the harp is better known as an icon than as a musical instrument. The earliest surviving Irish harp, a 14th-century instrument displayed in the Trinity College Library in Dublin, is depicted on every coin minted in the republic - and even appears on bottles of Guinness stout.

LEAD: AT first glance, the modern office buildings and an expanding mammoth retail center set amid grazing cattle and cornfields that edge this prairie city seem inappropriate investments for such a setting.

LEAD: The University of Massachusetts at Amherst, a focal point for racial unrest in recent years, has turned a residence hall with a history of bias incidents into a place with a support system for minority students.

LEAD: AS trees in the rest of Westchester begin to display their fall colors, the trees on Kenilworth Lane here remain leafless, their stark limbs an eerie black. The swimming pools and tennis courts once shaded by the trees are empty, and the gardens under them sprout shriveled zucchini and brown string beans.

LEAD: Two members of Congress from New Jersey and a water delivery expert warned today that the proposed development of 19,000 acres of Sterling Forest in southeastern Orange County could imperil the drinking water for two million residents of northern New Jersey and make them more vulnerable to floods.

LEAD: The new chief of the Communist Party in the Ukraine has offered to curb the official harassment of his republic's growing nationalist movement and to begin a period of cooperation, provided the nationalists do not advocate secession from the Soviet Union.

LEAD: There was a crimson bloodstain the size of a quarter yesterday on the asphalt in front of the Friendly bodega near the Redfern Houses in Far Rockaway, Queens. An orange police tape twisted in the sea breeze, and teen-age boys whispered about the shooting Friday night of a young girl caught in the path of a bullet fired by a youth as he argued with other youths over a game of dice.

LEAD: AFTER YOU'VE GONE By Alice Adams. 229 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

LEAD: We haven't heard much about dance in Sweden since 1982, when a dancer in that country's foremost experimental troupe, the Cullberg Ballet, bared her breasts onstage in front of some other visitors at the Brooklyn Academy of Music - the King and Queen of Sweden.
LEAD: Dressing for success in the New York City Police Department doesn't necessarily require the familiar blue.

LEAD: TAKE a look around you. Are you an ''Everything Out''? Are papers strewn about your desk haphazardly, each related to a different project, each demanding immediate attention, and each destined to end up somewhere other than where you will eventually look for it?

LEAD: THERE are two ways to buy chicken livers. The expedient method is to purchase the necessary quantity from the butcher or supermarket. The other way is to collect them from the whole chickens you buy, freezing them until you have enough for a recipe.

LEAD: For Patrick J. O'Connor's information (''No Innocent Victims of Direct Mail,'' letters, Aug. 20) I wrote over two months ago to the Direct Marketing Association to ask that my and my husband's names be removed from mailing lists.

LEAD: A HIKER in the woods accustomed to rounding a corner and coming upon a deer or other wild animal is just as likely these days to confront a rusting Ford or a rotting La-Z-Boy. Across the state, many of the remaining unspoiled areas are fast becoming spoiled by the illegal dumping of automobiles, tire, furniture and major appliances.

LEAD: London Christmas Question: We will be in London Dec. 24, 25 and 26 this year. We have heard that historical sites and stores are closed. Please advise as to what do at that time. - P. W. G., Baldwin Harbor, L.I. Answer: Most stores, museums and historical sites are closed Dec. 25 and 26, Boxing Day.
LEAD: A peace conference in the Saudi city of Taif was deadlocked today over a timetable for the withdrawal of Syrian troops from Lebanon.
LEAD: FEDERICO GARCIA LORCA A Life. By Ian Gibson. Illustrated. 551 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $29.95.

LEAD: On Friday, Nov. 13, 1868, Gioacchino Rossini died at his home in Paris at the age of 76. Four days later, Giuseppe Verdi, a sincere admirer if not a close personal friend of the great Italian composer, wrote his own publisher, Tito Ricordi: ''In order to honor the memory of Rossini I should like the most outstanding composers of Italy to write a requiem which shall be performed on the anniversary of his death.
LEAD: Resistance to the hydroelectric dam known as the Basin Mills project, on the Penobscot River in Maine, continues to gain momentum.

LEAD: Every culture has its puppets (in our case, they're muppets), and in some of those cultures puppet plays achieve the status of high art. Often, like Shakespeare's plays and Mozart's operas, they mix noble legend and raucous low comedy in blissful equilibrium.

LEAD: COLLECTED POEMS, 1937-1971 By John Berryman. Edited by Charles Thornbury. 348 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $25.
LEAD: The Jets and the Raiders, two powerful symbols of the genre, tomorrow play their final Monday night game of the 1980's, a sports decade often described as cynical and avaricious.

LEAD: New Jersey has long considered itself the ''medicine chest to the nation'' because of the large number of pharmaceutical companies based there. Schering-Plough Corporation, with headquarters in Madison, is one of them, and the expansion of its research facility in Kenilworth will no doubt help the state hold the title.

LEAD: Has New York ever been so innocent a place as the grimy but effervescent city depicted in the 1953 musical ''Wonderful Town''? That question pertains crucially to the Equity Library Theater's revival of the show, in which the director Adrienne Weiss has unwisely cast members of the ensemble as homeless people and punks in the street scenes.

LEAD: With the season finished for New York Mets players, it was up to Mets management to serve up one final cliffhanger last week. It began with a lot of front-office grumbling about the team's disappointing second-place finish this year, and soon the whole world just knew Davey Johnson was finished as manager.

LEAD: Martin J. Knorr, a Republican-Conservative who served in the New York State Senate for 23 years, died of congestive heart failure yesterday at his daughter's home in Long Beach, L.I. He was 83 years old and lived in Little Neck, L.I.

LEAD: THE 1989 grape harvest is under way on the North and South Forks and in Nassau County, and the aroma of fermentation drenches the air around wineries as the must from chardonnay, merlot and other grapes churns and froths in stainless-steel tanks and oak barrels.

LEAD: FEARING the loss of millions of dollars and of incalculable political power as the result of another undercount in the Federal census, New York City officials have begun mapping the demographic terrain over which they will have to travel to insure that the most invisible and reluctant New Yorkers are enumerated next year.

LEAD: I did not find ''Touched by an Angel'' touching in the least. In fact, I found it very disturbing. According to the author, after a short visit with her family, Angel is transformed from a ''street-wise kid with no understanding of our family's values or rules'' into ''just another boy'' - just one ''of our own kids.

LEAD: Anyone who compares the quirky first issue of Vanity Fair - which included the Garcia Marquez novella ''Chronicle of a Death Foretold'' - with the glossy vapidity now on the newsstand can only mourn the loss of a potentially great magazine. What happened to that first vision?

LEAD: Stephane Grappelli's concert at Carnegie Hall Wednesday night was an odd mixture of the beautiful - Mr. Grappelli's violin playing is still an example of an unfettered imagination at work - and the badly planned and thoroughly banal. Mr. Grappelli also played with a flat-footed group, including the cellist Yo-Yo Ma, put together by Roger Kellaway; the grouphad the jazz sensibility of a brick wall and the marketing sensiblity of Madison Avenue.

LEAD: It may not be a busman's holiday, but for Mike Tyson, it's going to be hard to tell where training camp leaves off and community service begins. Tyson, who is preparing to take on the Canadian champion, Razor Ruddock, moved his training camp temporarily from Las Vegas, Nev., to Albany, where he was sentenced to perform community service after pleading guilty to speeding in two incidents last summer.

Since the 1920's, a range of housing types, from detached single-family houses to midrise elevator buildings, has been developed in the neighborhood.

LEAD: I feel that Bart Giamatti was and is this year's m.v.p. This is not based on his untimely and tragic death, but rather on what he wished to address while he was alive: the integrity of the game and, in part, society. He addressed the question of gambling in baseball, and indirectly all that ills society, with honesty, fairness and open-mindedness.

LEAD: EARLIER this year, the Practical Traveler discussed some ways to circumvent the distasteful single supplement, the extra charge a traveler must often pay to occupy a room alone at a hotel or on a tour.

LEAD: IT is hard to pinpoint exactly what is special about the old houses on the south side of East 17th Street between Union Square and Irving Place. The individual buildings are not outstanding and most are a bit neglected, even shabby.

LEAD: When Mia Dillon, wearing a voluminous dress, makes her first entrance in ''The Aunts,'' it is immediately clear to everyone in the theater that her character is supposed to be pregnant - to everyone, that is, except the other characters on stage. For unexplained reasons, the young woman's two aunts are oblivious to her condition.

LEAD: I am writing in response to Robert McDonald's article, ''Giving Special Workers a Chance'' (Opinion page, Sept. 3). Robert worked as a summer residential counselor at our agency, the Kennedy Center of Bridgeport. Student employees and volunteers have proved to be an invaluable resource to organizations like ours that serve adults with disabilities.

LEAD: Georges-Francois Hirsch, the general director of the Theatre des Champs-Elysees in Paris, has been named general administrator of the Opera Bastille, the administrative council of the opera has announced. Mr. Hirsch, whose nomination was proposed by Pierre Berge, the council's president, is to take over the post immediately, but will remain as head of the Champ-Elysees theater until the end of the 1989-90 season.

LEAD: All things considered, this was not exactly a banner week for Kansas City spirits. People were just beginning to deal with the bankruptcy filing by Braniff, the city's main provider of air service, when they learned that they would soon also lose their venerable evening newspaper.

LEAD: IT started out as a fortress in the 14th century; then, when the times became less dangerous, it was converted into a palace; finally, with the fall of the monarchy, it became a museum, the first of its kind in Europe. Now, at the behest of a President with a passion for building, it is going through yet another series of radical changes: enlarged, reorganized, with a new entrance pavilion, it has become in many ways a new museum.

LEAD: As an Amerian sociologist who studied in South Africa and practiced medicine there for 15 years, I can bear witness to the veracity of Jean Hey's observations in her article ''Just Two Women'' (Hers, Sept. 10). Interpersonal tolerance generally does overshadow the ''stench of South Africa's oppressive politics.

LEAD: THE 68-YEAR-OLD CON-gressman was frantic. His memory clearly wasn't what it used to be. Devastated, he sought help at a memory clinic near Washington.

LEAD: MISS AMERICA CONTESTANTS wear them with bathing suits. Playboy Playmates wear them with little else. The Rockettes kick up a storm in them. And Barbie's slender plastic feet are permanently poised to be slipped into them. They, of course, are high heels: instruments of torture, symbols of sexuality and fodder for fetishists.

He enrolls in a school for the blind and finds the physical adaptations surprisingly easy; warned that it might take two years to become proficient in Braille, he masters it in two weeks.

LEAD: AS A HEART MONITOR BEEPED AT MY side and an automatic blood-pressure machine quietly inflated and deflated, the nurse started the infusion. Doctors and more nurses hovered nearby. The drug dripping into my vein was dideoxyinosine, or DDI. Thus, on July 22 of this year, I became one of about 100 people in the United States to receive what was being described in the press as a ''promising'' new AIDS drug.

LEAD: My mother, too, was shot by a deer hunter - while clearing brush outside her house in Kent, Conn., in 1976. That particular Nimrod left her to bleed to death in her backyard, then fled to his lawyer's office. She managed to crawl to a phone - and help. She, too, was an ''outsider'' and was told that criminal prosecution was impossible.

LEAD: As a parent of three school-age children, I read with trepidation Irving Gerber's Opinion article. Too often I've heard the when-I-was-young-I-walked-five-miles-to-school-and-sat-in-a-class-of-45 refrain as a response to our requests for better student services and smaller class sizes. While districts may be top-heavy with administrators, budget cuts go right to the children.

LEAD: The Big Apple Circus celebrates the Wild West, from Oct. 26 to Jan 7 in Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center. The show includes feats on the trapeze and on horseback, calf-roping, gun-slinging and whip-cracking. Tickets are $40 to $10. Information: 391-0767.

LEAD: This is the time of year, the High Holy Days, when Jews are supposed to look into themselves, reflect on what has been and commit themselves to what should be. In 1989 it should be a time also for honest thinking about the future of Israel.

LEAD: Jeannine E. Davis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald M. Davis of Burr Ridge, Ill., was married yesterday in Nantucket, Mass., to Richard B. Harris, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. Harris of Chatham, N.J. The Rev. Douglas Tompkins officiated at St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

LEAD: THE hotel scene in Rome used to be simple. If you wanted luxury and pampering, you paid a lot of money and, in most cases, you got them; if charm and atmosphere counted more than recapturing abroad all the comforts of home, you could find that too (and at a price that was affordable), and if you just wanted a clean place to spend a night, which you never expected to come back to again, that too was an uncomplicated affair.

LEAD: The excellent article ''A Lesson Refused and a Lesson Learned'' revealed the problems faced by a student who objects to using animals as classroom tools. Sadly, the academic status quo often penalizes those who show the most sensitivity and insight. Rather than teaching respect for all creatures, classroom dissection and vivisection desensitize students to animal suffering.

LEAD: IN SEPTEMBER OF 1984 DR. RON-ald H. Spiro told Robert A. Pfeiffer that he had a large tumor at the base of his tongue, right next to the vocal cords in his larynx, that had already spread to some lymph nodes in his neck. The standard treatment for such tumors was an extensive operation that involved removing the entire larynx, or voice box.

LEAD: OFFICERS of cooperative corporations, condominiums and homeowner associations are feeling increasing pressure to become more knowledgeable about investing their reserve funds. The funds are ballooning while the need to tap them becomes increasingly unpredictable as structures age.

LEAD: One University of Mississippi student was expelled and four others were suspended Friday for their involvement in a fraternity prank. The incident occurred Sept. 18, when a Beta Theta Pi member and a pledge were stripped, blindfolded, painted with racial slurs and dropped off at Rust College, a predominantly black school about 25 miles to the north.

LEAD: Sam and Libby Edelman fell in love at a 1979 shoe fair. He was there as a salesman for his father's business, she as footwear fashion editor for Seventeen magazine. Now they own Sam & Libby California, which offers a popular line of leather flats.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. John W. Spurdle Jr. of New York and Rumson, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sarah Stuart Spurdle to David Rorick Stack, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. William Stack Jr. of New Canaan, Conn. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: Bette Davis, who won two Academy Awards and cut a swath through Hollywood trailing cigarette smoke and delivering drop-dead barbs, died of breast cancer Friday night at the American Hospital in Neuilly-sur-Seine, France. She was 81 years old and lived in West Hollywood, Calif.

LEAD: ONCE upon a time there was an ordinary housewife who had three children. She liked the wife part and the mother part must have been pretty good since she had two babies and then adopted a third one.

LEAD: To The Editor:

LEAD: Alternative commercial cinema lives. Among other things, the box-office success of Steven Soderbergh's independently produced ''Sex, Lies and Videotape'' is proof that there is vibrant life outside of the Hollywood establishment.
LEAD: Sunday is the eve of Yom Kippur, the beginning of the traditional day of fasting and holiest day of the Jewish year. After the fasting, there is the break fast, a hearty family meal.

LEAD: Ruben Sierra doesn't walk enough. What else can you say about a man who led the American League in runs batted in (119), total bases (344) and slugging percentage (.541) while finishing third in runs scored (101), eighth in doubles (35), first in triples (14), sixth in homers (29) and tenth in average (.304)?

LEAD: DURING the last two years, the Soviet Union has carried out changes in the practice of psychiatry, hoping to persuade the World Psychiatric Association to allow it to rejoin the organization. It left the group in 1983 to avoid almost certain expulsion because of charges that political and religious dissidents were being confined in mental hospitals.

LEAD: FOR an American music lover, the main problem with planning trips abroad specifically for musical purposes is a dearth of reliable, sophisticated information. Getting tickets can be a problem, too, of course, although - apart from nearly impossible-to-get-into festivals -that's sometimes solvable through a friendly travel agent or a local concierge or an imploring letter to the organizations in question, which sometimes hold seats aside for foreign visitors.

Rabbi Morris Friedman officiated.
LEAD: Ansel Adams, who died in 1984 at the age of 82, is still an inspiration for the Friends of Photography, the group of artists and scholars he helped establish 22 years ago in Carmel, Calif.

LEAD: They're the movies' equivalent of national historic places: 25 classic American films of cultural or esthetic significance to be preserved in trust as part of a National Film Registry overseen by the Librarian of Congress. The films - 50 more titles will be added to the list over the next two years - were chosen last month by the Librarian and the National Preservation Board, comprising representatives of the film industry and related endeavors.
LEAD: The Indian authorities say they have uncovered child-smuggling gangs that send children as young as 5 years old to Persian Gulf countries to be used as human sirens in camel races.

LEAD: Cape Breton, Nova Scotia, is a scenic place. Every summer, Canadian tourists descend by the thousands to camp along its beaches and hike its winding trails. There are souvenir shops everywhere, and the gifts they carry - tartan tams, bright plaid ties, bagpiper key chains -proudly advertise the island's
LEAD: High Reserve Fund

LEAD: I was truly impressed with Maggie McCool's pro-animal position until I read of her 16 cats (''A Lesson Refused and a Lesson Learned,'' Aug. 27). The photograph of her with one of her cats showed no evidence of a bell or other device that would warn prey of a cat's presence. Apparently, Ms. McCool's animal advocacy extends only to creatures she favors, e.g., frogs, but not to those whose deaths she may not notice.

LEAD: Barbara Hey has some uneducated theories about psychotherapy (''The Shrink on the Couch,'' April 16). First of all, a good therapy depends as much on the patient as it does on the therapist. A brilliant therapist cannot ''cure'' a resistant patient, and a patient who wants to be cured more than anything else could probably do so with a less-than-brilliant therapist.

LEAD: Much has been written recently about the adverse impact on American industry and society of skyrocketing verdicts (and settlements in fear of such verdicts) for personal injuries and deaths in tort cases.
LEAD: An obituary on Sunday about the composer and critic Virgil Thomson misidentified a performer whose repertory was dismissed by Mr. Thomson as ''silk-underwear music.''

LEAD: ROBERT SOUTHEY, the early-19th-century Poet Laureate of England, was forever haunted by a memory of his youth. ''If I had Aladdin's lamp, the genius should transport me, my household and my books to Cintra. . . . Cintra, the most blessed spot in the habitable globe, will almost bring tears to my eyes.
LEAD: Armchair detectives will spot some dramatic changes when PBS-TV's ''Mystery!'' begins its 10th season this week (Thursday on WNYC-TV, Channel 31; Saturday on WNET-TV, Channel 13).

LEAD: For This Week: Bulb planting begins as catalogue orders start to arrive; if the bulbs cannot be put in the ground for several days, store in a cool, dry place so they do not start to sprout in warm temperatures. If the lawn is becoming covered with leaves, begin raking, but also keep mowing; use rakings to make the first layer of the new compost pile.

LEAD: Tennis Lendl Wins Final: Ivan Lendl overcame problems with his first serve yesterday and defeated Miroslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia, 6-3, 4-6, 4-6, 6-1, 6-4, to win the Stuttgart tournament in West Germany. The match took 3 hours 14 minutes. Lendl, the world's top-ranked player, broke Mecir twice to win the first set, then started missing his first serves.

LEAD: BAD INTENTIONS: The Mike Tyson Story. By Peter Heller (NAL Books, $18.95.) A biography of Mike Tyson should offer some insight into the heavyweight champion's effectively brutal behavior in the ring and puzzlingly erratic behavior outside it. It should, at least, provide some entertainment, as the tabloid headlines of the past couple of years are stitched into a juicy narrative.

LEAD: He may be the most gifted player in the history of pro football: big, fast, intense, incredibly quick, incredibly explosive. He may be the best outside linebacker ever, and his pass-rushing skills have redefined the position.

LEAD: With the weight of 49 losses in Columbia's last 51 games resting on its shoulders, the Lions' defense lined up for a fourth-down play yesterday with the ball inches from its goal line and less than two minutes remaining in the game. If Columbia could hold, it would mean a victory over Penn, an Ivy League co-champion last year.

LEAD: Joseph J. Hazelwood, the captain of the tanker that caused the worst oil spill in the nation's history, has won state prosecutors' agreement to have his trial moved out of the south Alaskan port city of Valdez.
LEAD: TO THOSE WHO HAVE TROUBLE hearing a doorbell ring or a baby cry, the computer has become as significant as the hearing aid itself.
LEAD: LIGHT By Seymour Epstein. 282 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $18.95.

LEAD: SHEILA is the generic name for domestic workers in South Africa, and Thursday is their traditional day off. On that day, the women come together for songs and prayer - and for the healing of the spirit.

LEAD: UNTIL last month, Albert Mejia was one of more than 100 men, mostly undocumented Salvadoran refugees, who congregated every morning in front of Carmen's Deli in Glen Cove, waiting there for the landscaping trucks to come by and hoping to get a job for the day.

LEAD: On a recent autumn night, Anne Bogart sat on the stage of the Trinity Repertory Company, facing a small but lively audience. Ms. Bogart had just assumed the theater's artistic directorship and was conducting her first post-performance discussion - a conversation about that night's production of ''No Plays, No Poetry,'' her drama based on the theoretical writings of the German playwright Bertolt Brecht.

LEAD: I HAVE a terrible sense of direction. Having lived in Westchester County now for nearly 13 years I go by rote to most of my accustomed destinations: the supermarkets, library, mall, even to New York City. I have, I suppose, more or less memorized my way to these places, but this accomplishment was slow and painstaking in coming.

LEAD: AMONG the amenities under the Louvre's new pyramid is an oasis, a place of calm and repose, of good food and fine wines. Called Le Grand Louvre, it is the flagship of the underground restaurant complex that has been installed in the museum's new entrance area.

LEAD: Incidenls like a mock slave auction at the University of Wisconsin at Madison and the broadcast of racial slurs on a University of Michigan radio station have made race relations a top issue on college campuses nationwide, interviews with about 300 students at 20 universities show.

LEAD: Dave Pelland's engaging piece on geese and their ''smarts'' (''There's No Way to Outwit the Geese,'' Opinion page, Sept. 3) reminded me of my experience when I lived in Fort Collins, Colo., some years ago.

LEAD: Katherine Margaret Holihan, a daughter of Margaret Katherine Holihan of Piermont, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Joseph Aloysius Burke, a son of Mary Helen Burke of Buffalo and the late Howard Vincent Burke. LEAD: Last season, for the first time in 32 years, Bill Fitch did not coach basketball. He played golf. He traveled. He read books. He spent more time with his friends.

LEAD: THE JOYS OF YINGLISH. By Leo Rosten. (McGraw-Hill, $29.95.) Your strict lexicographer may question whether there is a real need for ''The Joys of Yinglish,'' the newest opus - one is tempted to say eppes - from the prolific Leo Rosten. Mr. Rosten's earlier lexicons, ''The Joys of Yiddish'' and ''Hooray for Yiddish,'' covered Mom-and-Pop Yiddish.

LEAD: A week after being promoted from sixth man to starter, Roy Tarpley has gotten a contract worthy of his new status with the Dallas Mavericks. Tarpley, who had two years to go on a contract scheduled to pay him $560,000 this season and $660,000 the next, signed a three-year extension that will bring him a bit more, an average of $2.6 million a year for the last three years, The Dallas Morning News reported.

LEAD: AFTER an erratic six-month decline that brought mortgage rates down more than a percentage point since last spring, much of the nation is experiencing a minirevival of demand for home loans, most of it in plain vanilla fixed-rate financing.

LEAD: AFTER Washington stops arguing about the extent to which President Bush fumbled last week's attempt by Panamanian troops to oust Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Administration will have to think about where American policy goes from here.

LEAD: Working Girl 1988. CBS/Fox Home Video. $89.98. 1 hour, 53 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Offering its heroine one of the best opportunities for wish fulfillment this side of ''Cinderella,'' Mike Nichols's film ''derives a lot of its charm from the performance of Melanie Griffith, the baby-voiced bombshell who gives Tess an unbeatable mixture of street smarts, business sense and sex appeal.

LEAD: Right on, Mr. Gerber! (''Trim the Fat From High Cost of Education,'' Opinion, Sept. 24). I am a founder of the East Northport-Northport School Tax Watch and believe he hit the target. Our district still has 10 schools and half the students of a decade ago. We have one superintendent and three assistant supers.

LEAD: Q. The family room in our house is directly above the basement. In warm weather, this room has a musty odor, especially when the humidity is high. We use a dehumidifier and ventilate the room, but it has not helped much. We had the carpet shampooed, and this relieved the problem temporarily. How can we get rid of the odor?

LEAD: Visitors to London this fall will be forgiven if they feel a bit confused about what year this is. The place looks contemporary enough, with its sleekly gentrified buildings, smartly dressed young people, streets lined with Range Rovers and controversial new glass and metal telephone booths, which have uprooted many of the beloved red boxes of yore.

LEAD: In the family of jazz, parents have insulted children nearly as often as embraced them. For every Coleman Hawkins playing sideman to Thelonious Monk, there was Louis Armstrong denouncing be-bop as ''Chinese music.'' For every Duke Ellington recording duets with John Coltrane, there was Roy Eldridge branding Ornette Coleman a fake.
LEAD: What do the Napa County Jail in northern California, Coca-Cola's headquarters in Atlanta and the United States Mint in Denver all have in common?

LEAD: SINCE HER DAUGHTER, CARMEN, was born, Jasmine Gazzarato of Royal Oak, Mich., says she has taken on three jobs. She works full time developing training programs for the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers, takes care of her daughter and caters to her husband, Melvin Winkler.

LEAD: THIS will be another week of beginnings, with the Eastern Connecticut Symphony Orchestra opening its season on Thursday and Orchestra New England and the Greater Bridgeport, Greenwich and Waterbury Symphonies opening theirs on Saturday.

Meanwhile, as hunting season begins, many of us in the Bangor, Me., area will be especially cautious as we venture outdoors near our homes, lest we, too, be mistaken for an animal by some overzealous hunter.
LEAD: Television has provided the world with many remarkable images over the years, but none more beautiful than that of a horse named Secretariat winning the Belmont Stakes.

LEAD: Gay rights protesters held a demonstration today at a hotel where a conservative church group was running a symposium in which speakers warned that homosexuals are a threat to American culture.

LEAD: With apologies to Pedro Guerrero, can a New Yorker not but imagine one of their outfielders with around 50 home runs and 130 runs batted in! National League most valuable player: Kevin Mitchell.
LEAD: Scene one: Day, interior. The prosecutor taps his pen nervously on his files during a Senate hearing. His language may be American legalese, but his pen taps a 6/8 Latin beat.

LEAD: Those around the world, who value the traditions of the game are mourning the demise of the world's oldest bridge periodical, Bridge International. The English publishers have announced that, for financial reasons, the current issue will be the last.

LEAD: After a year and a half of negotiations, representatives of the newsstand business and the newspaper industry announced last week their general support for proposed regulations that would govern the size, location and operation of sidewalk newsstands in New York City.

LEAD: MY person is in need of mending along with my house and car. We're running neck and neck, falling apart simultaneously. My old Buick-friend is no more. It has spluttered, squeaked and coughed its way to its dotage; it has hiccupped, wheezed and sometimes purred its way to decrepitude. For a car 26 years old it is over the hill in spades.

LEAD: Nine months after the United States-Canada free-trade agreement began chipping away at tariffs and trade barriers, trade relations between the world's two busiest trading partners have slipped once again to their accustomed place on the policy makers' back burner.
LEAD: While Jim Bakker ponders the possiblity of prison, Mother Mary Angelica sits at Our Lady of the Angels monastery in Birmingham, Ala., planning to broadcast to the world.

LEAD: The United States soccer team, two victories and a tie from qualifying for a World Cup tournament for the first time, faces a key test in Guatemala today without two Latin American-born stars. Missing will be Hugo Perez, a Salvadoran-born midfielder and forward who is out with a torn groin muscle, and Tab Ramos, a native of Uruguay who will be serving an automatic one-game suspension for committing two major penalties in the team's previous game, a 1-0 victory over El

LEAD: Columbus Day will be observed on Monday. Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Main post office at 33d St. and Eighth Ave. open. Banks: Option to close. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended.

LEAD: THE struggle in Congress over how much control it should have over the National Endowment for the Arts seems as unlikely to reach a quick resolution as a Wagnerian opera. Although the endowment appears to have avoided being saddled with the Helms amendment, which would have prohibited the financing of ''obscene or indecent'' art as well as that which ''denigrates the objects or beliefs of the adherents of a particular religion or nonreligion,'' the debate over publicly financed art has just begun.
LEAD: The heart of this year's Penn State team is its defense, which shut down Rutgers today at Giants Stadium and helped the Nittany Lions win, 17-0, before a crowd of 52,688.

LEAD: THE IDEA OF HEALTH-ful holiday food is something of an oxymoron. Holidays, after all, are times of feasting, and feasting connotes an embarrassment of food -plates piled high with succulent meats, larded puddings and wedges of buttery pie. These are, of course, precisely the kinds of foods that we should eat only in moderation.

LEAD: George Abbott believes a director wastes his time in rehearsal when he talks endlessly to an actor about who his mother was, what did she want, what does he want and why it has led him up to this moment when he asks for the salt. Instead he prefers that the director get on with it and tell the actor, ''C'mon, Johnny, just pass the salt.

LEAD: FALL in Bantam is not the same this year. People here have put aside such customary pursuits as apple gathering and leaf peeping as they continue to rebuild from the wreckage of a tornado in July. Residents still have leaves to rake, but they also have piles of downed trees and uprooted stumps to clear.

LEAD: Bannisters, or staircase posts and railings, are as much a safety feature as they are a decorative element. This makes repairing loose or broken bannisters important, but also somewhat complicated, because fasteners are usually hidden.

LEAD: FOR decades, musical-comedy aficionados have waited for a first-class revival of ''Kiss Me, Kate.'' The Darien Dinner Theater is having its way with the 1948 classic of Cole Porter and Bella and Samuel Spewack, with a little help from Shakespeare, but we're still waiting.
LEAD: Uncertainty concerning Rick Reuschel and Don Robinson cast a shadow over the Giants' hopes even before they were to resume play tonight in the National League playoff against the Cubs.

LEAD: Representatives of the vending industry have recently found themselves vigorously lobbying Congress to pass a measure that would mint a new dollar coin. ''It's really vending that's carrying this thing,'' said James C. Benfi, but can give change only in coins, not currency.

LEAD: The Prospects column on Sept. 24 about the Ford Motor Company's proposed acquisition of a stake in Jaguar referred incorrectly to a comment from Charles M. MacDonald, an executive of the Jaguar Clubs of North America, on the status of Jaguar's racing team. He said Jaguar sponsors two racing teams, one in the United States and another in Europe.

LEAD: As I read James Barron's article ''Unnecessary Surgery'' (April 16), I wondered whether my initial reaction qualified me for a Hostile Persons Award from Daniel Goleman, author of ''Agreeableness vs. Anger,'' appearing in the same issue. The problem is far more complex than Mr. Barron allows. Neither medical nor surgical management is an exact science.

LEAD: There are many things wrong with the American Civil Liberties Union, and Jeffrey T. Leeds has pointed to some of them, as well as to what is right about its policies (''The A.C.L.U. - Impeccable Judgments or Tainted Policies?'' Sept. 10). But its chief weakness, as I see it, is its insistence that a general principle, whether it deals with free speech or due process, should be applied to all cases - without regard for the consequences.

LEAD: An air of serenity pervades 3000 Sand Hill Road, a campus-like cluster of office buildings that is the venture capital business's equivalent of Wall Street. LEAD: Four days ago the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden unceremoniously passed its 15th anniversary. But whatever might be said against the architect Gordon Bunshaft's design - and curators struggling to hang paintings on curved walls have had things to say over the years - his conception underscored one essential characteristic of the museum.

LEAD: In the days before income taxes - yes, there was such a time - the United States Government raised money through a wide range of excise taxes and collected the money by selling revenue stamps. Just as postage stamps show payment for a government service, so revenue stamps show payment for a tax.

LEAD: Gunnar Johansen is not one of the headliners, but he is a highly respected pianist whose lack of public appearance has been a matter of choice. In 1939 he was named artist-in-residence at the University of Wisconsin, the first musician in any American university to be so honored. He settled in. In his home he installed a battery of the most up-to-date recording equipment, and instead of giving concerts he made a series of records that has put most of his contemporaries to shame.

Gorbachev has loosed in the land. More draconian proposals are in store, as the country sweats out the unnerving side effects of a little liberty.

Alas, they are not as beautiful as their names; the fruit is small, irregular - all right, it must be said - just plain quirky.

It did the same with the second acorn and was working on a third when a pair of poodles came along and chased it up a tree.

LEAD: We live in an age of image-building - an age in which it is increasingly difficult to distinguish appearance from reality. Since most people cannot determine where the truth lies, they believe noble intentions.
LEAD: Credit market analysts predict that the Federal Reserve Board will not move quickly to lower interest rates, despite fresh signs of economic weakness.

LEAD: The Rudolph W. Giuliani mayoral campaign spent much of yesterday courting the Hispanic vote from East Harlem to the canyons of Fifth Avenue. It was not an easy day. What the campaign had promised would be an endorsement from the ''oldest Latino club'' in New York City turned into a confusing non-endorsement.

LEAD: Reversing at least part of the message they sent in a spring election, Louisiana voters on Saturday overwhelmingly approved a gasoline tax increase intended to finance a costly building program and breathe life into the state's dismal economy.

LEAD: The Treasury's schedule of new issues this week includes the weekly auction of new three-month and six-month bills, which will be tomorrow because of the holiday today, and Wednesday's auction of new seven-year notes.

LEAD: One way or another, New Yorkers will vote Nov. 7 on a referendum to amend their City Charter. One way is better than the other, though: the way that allows New York City voters to know, before Election Day, what the United States Justice Department thinks about the charter proposal.

LEAD: Marsha A. Rich and Steven V. Camerino, both graduates of Dartmouth College, were married yesterday in Woodstock, N.H., at the Moosilauke Ravine Lodge of the Dartmouth Outing Club. Peter B. Rotch, a lawyer and a New Hampshire justice of the peace, performed the civil ceremony.
LEAD: Goldman, Sachs & Company has adopted a policy to charge retail investors for holding their securities.

LEAD: A 15-year-old girl was killed in a hit-and-run accident early Saturday morning as she was trying to cross a street in front of a discotheque for teen-agers near East Farmingdale, L.I., the Suffolk County police said.

LEAD: Even if there were such a thing as a typical Wall Street investment banker, Ivan Obolensky, the senior vice president of research for Josephthal & Company, would not be it. LEAD: Faced with calls for increased economic cooperation with Poland and Hungary, the Bush Administration is under growing pressure from its European allies, led by West Germany, to allow the export of sophisticated machine tools to Communist countries.

LEAD: Bobby Humphrey, rushing for 102 yards in the first start of his pro career, scored a tackle-breaking touchdown with 1 minute 3 seconds left as the sluggish Denver Broncos beat the San Diego Chargers, 16-10, today.
LEAD: The United States missed a chance to improve its World Cup qualifying hopes today when it had to settle for a scoreless tie with Guatemala.

LEAD: The 27th New York Film Festival rolls effortlessly to its conclusion tonight with the 9 o'clock showing of Bill Forsyth's halcyon new comedy, ''Breaking In,'' at Avery Fisher Hall.

LEAD: William J. Fischer, a New York auctioneer of furnishings, decorations and art, died yesterday in a nursing home in Burbank, Calif. He was 91 years and lived in Manhattan until he moved to California 18 months ago.
LEAD: They can exhibit the strut of a group that knows its business, but they also possess the willingness to attend to the details that can close a deal.
LEAD: MTV, the cable television rock-music network, is having a profound influence on the way products are advertised on television, advertising professionals say.
LEAD: A dispute over a Government plan to let private developers build profit-making attractions in a Queens park has spurred a drive for public financing to upgrade Gateway National Recreation Area.

LEAD: Mookie Wilson, who opened the season sitting on the bench with the Mets, ended it today as the regular left fielder for the Toronto Blue Jays. He expressed his gratitude to the Blue Jays for giving him a showcase for the last two months, but said he was going to consider all his options as a free agent before deciding where to play next season.

LEAD: Galen Hall resigned as football coach at the University of Florida today amid charges that he made unauthorized payments to a player and to his assistant coaches in violation of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules, the university's interim president said.

LEAD: On a vast plaza designed to be turned into a military airfield should North and South Korea go to war again, Pope John Paul II prayed today for the reunification of a people torn by seemingly implacable hatred.

LEAD: On June 7, 1973, a 50-year-old homeless man named Quenton Brown walked into a bread store in Louisiana and, at gunpoint, stole $100 and a 15 cent pie. He then crawled under a nearby house where he remained until the police arrived. After his arrest, the state found that Mr. Brown had an I.Q. of 51 - the intelligence of a three and one-half year old child.
LEAD: The 1,100 Army troops sent to restore civil order after Hurricane Hugo devastated St. Croix three weeks ago are still needed to insure the peace, local officials acknowledge.

LEAD: The recent withdrawal of Vietnamese troops from Cambodia and the threat of the return of the infamous Khmer Rouge lend immediacy to ''Cambodia: The Prince and the Prophecy,'' a political history of that much beset land. LEAD: * Cookie-Crisp, a children's cereal made by the Ralston Purina Co., to Avrett, Free & Ginsberg, with an undisclosed budget.

LEAD: The thousands of people who have left East Germany in recent weeks have seized opportunities for escape as they arose, first through Hungary and then through Czechoslovakia. Seen from afar, their flight seemed to be a mass exodus. LEAD: BREAKING legal ground, a Federal court has decided that a law firm could avoid a conflict of interest charge by ousting a partner.

LEAD: Azerbaijani railroad crews defied a national ban on transport strikes today and again stemmed the flow of desperately needed supplies to Armenia, the official Soviet press agency, Tass, said. LEAD: Emanuel Ax played the best of Arnold Schoenberg's piano music and a rousing selection of Beethoven's most animated, Saturday evening at the 92d Street Y. It was an exhilarating recital and something of a surprise even to a listener who has always admired Mr. Ax. Here, more than I can recall from other occasions, he seemed to have something close to the ideal combination of qualities for the material at hand.

LEAD: The Milwaukee Symphony was on the stage of Carnegie Hall Saturday night, but these visitors from the Midwest seemed almost bit players in the larger drama of Carnegie Hall's acoustics. The plot has arrived at Act III, Scene 1 - from the celebrated sound of this historical space, to the much criticized acoustical changes that accompanied a major renovation several years ago, and now to August's further modifications, which have included absorbent material applied above and behind the playing area and at the back of the hall.

LEAD: As a child, Midori Kashiwagi trained in traditional Japanese dance but went on to become a jazz dancer, establishing what is said to be the first jazz dance studio in Japan. In her New York debut, in a Saturday matinee at Gould Hall, Miss Kashiwagi presented two pieces that fused traditional and jazz dance.
LEAD: A cyst removed from the middle finger of President Bush's right hand was not cancerous, a spokesman said today.

LEAD: The newly named Hungarian Socialist Party, which as the Communist Party over the weekend abandoned hard-line Marxist dogma, today elected Rezso Nyers, a once and present Socialist, as its President.

LEAD: President Bush has informed Congressional leaders that he will veto a foreign aid bill that includes renewed support for the United Nations Population Fund, a group that has been criticized by anti-abortion groups.
LEAD: Teams from China, the Soviet Union and the United States will attempt to scale Mount Everest together next year to draw attention to international cooperation and problems of the environment.

LEAD: WHEN Zaro Bakeries, Farberware Inc., Empire Glass and other companies opened operations in the South Bronx several years ago, they were viewed as risk takers in an area that had come to represent urban decline.
LEAD: The Supreme Court let stand a ruling that anti-abortion protesters are liable under racketeering law for damage to a clinic. Page A23.

LEAD: To head off expected criticism from Panamanian rebels who have just arrived in Miami, the Pentagon sought today to portray the leaders of the failed coup as hopelessly divided over what to do with Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega when he was in their custody.

LEAD: In the face of tremendous fiscal problems, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo this year proposed the tightest state spending plan in a decade and reproached many of his critics for demanding more money. ''I would put the emphasis on tighter management and spending discipline,'' he said.

LEAD: Eleven-year-old Danielle Findley of Lee's Summit, Mo., can stick out her chin and grin today: she was chosen yesterday from among almost 400 young girls to play the role of Annie in the new musical ''Annie 2: Miss Hannigan's Revenge.''

LEAD: In 1974 New Jersey became the first state to enact a law providing public financing for gubernatorial candidates. The limit on spending has been raised several times, and in 1980 the law was extended to cover primary elections for governor as well as the general election.

LEAD: In a move that has as much to do with California politics as the environment, an alliance of politicians and environmentalists today offered a ballot measure that they called the broadest effort ever mounted to protect air, food and water against chemical contamination.

LEAD: Mayor Sue Myrick today swamped her opponent in a Republican primary that was delayed two weeks by Hurricane Hugo. Ms. Myrick's victory sets the stage for a Nov. 7 battle with Craig Madans, a Democrat, to lead North Carolina's largest city.

LEAD: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company is offering $300 million in notes due 1996 through Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in sluggish trading yesterday, as dealers used comments by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve Board chairman, as an excuse to take some profits.

LEAD: Long before there were any Oakland Athletics or a Bay Area Rapid Transit, Dave Stewart was a San Francisco Giants fan. And that was plenty good for a young man from the hard-times section of Oakland.

LEAD: ''Roseanne'' and the season premiere of ''The Wonder Years'' both had their highest ratings ever last week, helping to bring ABC within eight-tenths of a point of first-place NBC in the prime-time ratings. NBC squeaked by with an average prime-time rating of 15.2, winning the week for the 68th time.

LEAD: With Wayne Gretzky on the verge of breaking Gordie Howe's National Hockey League career scoring record, there were reports the past two days that the 61-year-old Howe, a member of the Hockey Hall of Fame, was planning to come out of retirement for one game after Jan. 1 in order to push his career into the 1990's, For Howe, who began his N.H.L.

LEAD: The Belgian central bank raised short-term interest rates today for the fourth time in two weeks. Belgium's three-month treasury bill rate, considered the key rate, was raised by a quarter of a point, to 9.55 percent. The one- and two-month rates were raised to 9.55 percent each from 9.2 and 9.25 percent, respectively.

LEAD: Just about every front-runner ducks debates, so it comes as no surprise that David Dinkins is reluctant to debate Rudolph Giuliani one-on-one. He obviously prefers including Ronald Lauder, the Conservative Party's choice, and Henry Hewes, the Right to Life candidate. New Yorkers should certainly hear all four.

LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The World Boxing Association has put Mike Tyson on notice that if he beats Donovan (Razor) Ruddock on Nov. 18, he must fight Evander Holyfield within 120 days.

LEAD: Spurred in part by comments from Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, the dollar rose sharply yesterday, passing the important 1.90-mark level again and breaching 144 yen. The British pound also fell sharply against the dollar and other currencies.
LEAD: A new class of specialized computers is becoming the next area of opportunity in the computer business, and a host of new companies are staking their claims to it.

LEAD: The Dallas Cowboys had an open ''fire sale'' on Herschel Walker today. Walker's agents, Peter Johnson and Ralph Cindrich, were considering a restructuring of the running back's $1 million-a-year contract as part of the price for Walker leaving the Cowboys.
LEAD: The Supreme Court, which rarely examines Federal patent law, agreed today to decide a patent issue of considerable importance to the growing medical technology industry.

LEAD: AIDS patients have many needs, and not the least of them is for legal advice they may be unable to afford. Now trust and estate lawyers from some of New York City's top law firms are volunteering to help out. The project deserves praise and replication elsewhere.

LEAD: To press the Palestinian uprising, the people of this town have refused for months to pay their taxes. In response, Israel has begun to confiscate their goods. The raids, Aysa Hanna Khier says, have produced some incongruities.
LEAD: Like most colleges, the University of Southern California has a computer that sends out ''personalized'' recruiting letters to prospective freshmen.

LEAD: The unemployment rate in the 12-nation European Community stood at 9.2 percent in August, unchanged from July, the European Community's statistical agency, Eurostat, said today. In the eight-month period between January and August, the rate fell to 9.2 percent from 10.1 percent. Eurostat did not give a figure for the total number of unemployed in August because the Netherlands had not yet sent its data.

LEAD: Investigators have identified an 18-year-old Brooklyn man as a suspect in the beating of three Jewish students near Brooklyn College early Sunday by a gang that shouted anti-Semitic slurs, the police said yesterday.

LEAD: MIPS Computer Systems Inc., a maker of microprocessors and computers based in Sunnyvale, Calif., reached agreements on technology and marketing with Nixdorf Computer A. G. of West Germany, and Groupe Bull of France. MIPS's products are based on RISC, or reduced instruction set computing, which speeds data processing by limiting nonessential tasks.

LEAD: The Unisys Corporation announced yesterday that it had named David M. Pomerance, a 44-year-old entrepreneur, as president of its Unisys Healthcare Systems unit. Mr. Pomerance joined Unisys earlier this year as vice president and general manager of the division.
LEAD: Mary Alice Rice, a retired producer of fashion shows and former showgirl, died Monday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N,J., after a long illness. She was 78 years old and lived in Summit.

LEAD: In a surprise announcement, the chairman and chief executive of the Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that he plans to step down from those posts on Jan. 2, nearly three years before mandatory retirement.

LEAD: Residents here are regarding the current mayoral contest in New York with a gloomy pride. Pride because we have had a black mayor for 16 1/2 years; gloom because that Mayor, Tom Bradley, is now in a bit of a pinch. And it is hard to find anybody - left, right or center, black or white, politician or civilian - who is happy about that.

LEAD: Two former leftist guerrilla leaders accused of murder and other crimes in the 1970's returned to Argentina today after receiving presidential pardons and said they regretted ''the errors committed in the past.''
LEAD: * Albert Fisher Group P.L.C., London, a diversified food supplier, named Keith Brackpool chief executive of its North American operations.
LEAD: The first regular-season confrontation between National Hockey League teams with Soviet players went the way of the Calgary Flames, the defending Stanley Cup champions.
LEAD: The high school here was shaken by a bomb explosion today for the second time in two days, and bomb threats have been received by at least four other high schools in central Indiana.

LEAD: With less than a month to go before the Nov. 7 election, the candidates for governor have reached or are close to reaching the limit on campaign contributions set by New Jersey's public-financing law.
LEAD: Stocks fell moderately yesterday as some futures-related trading ended a six-day surge that had carried the Dow Jones industrial average to a gain of nearly 100 points.
LEAD: Paula Melhado Gilpatric, a real-estate broker, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 55 years old.
LEAD: Dave Dravecky re-fractured his left arm when he was bumped from behind during the on-field celebration Monday after San Francisco won the National League pennant, the Giants said today.

LEAD: A New York City Housing Authority manager was singled out for retaliation after he warned authority officials about suspected corruption in the agency, the city's Department of Investigation has determined.

LEAD: The future of the Saatchi & Saatchi Company became cloudier yesterday when its largest shareholder said it had been contacted by other parties interested in an overhaul of the world's largest marketing communications company.

LEAD: ''In matters of grave importance, style, not sincerity, is the vital thing,'' says Gwendolen, one of the perceptive if frivolous dilettantes in Oscar Wilde's ''Importance of Being Earnest.'' In his new production of the play at the Hartford Stage, Mark Lamos has taken Gwendolen's dictum to heart, staging an ''Earnest'' that delivers the bon mots born of boredom in turn-of-the-century British drawing rooms and country estates.
LEAD: Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday the poor ''will suffer the most'' without a strong city economy, as his mayoral campaign continued its strategy of making a policy statement each day.

LEAD: A man whose 8-year-old granddaughter shot herself in the thumb may be the first person charged under a new Florida law intended to keep loaded guns out of children's hands, the authorities said today.

LEAD: Given the nature of Salvador Dali's output in recent years, the last thing on earth that this critic wanted to do was to go halfway across Europe to see a mammoth exhibition - more than 300 works, it was said - by the Spanish Surrealist. But then the word went round that in all kinds of unexpected ways this was a show that had to be seen.
LEAD: The Phoenix Cardinals placed the defensive tackle Shawn Knight on the injured-reserve list yesterday and signed the free-agent wide receiver, Phil McConkey, to replace the ailing Roy Green.

LEAD: INVESTORS looking for a pure play in the growing trend toward stricter automotive emissions controls will not look at Sun Electric at first, but it could prove to be one of the biggest winners in the field.

LEAD: Switzerland's annual inflation rate rose to 3.4 percent last month, the highest since July 1985, the Federal Statistics Office announced today. Higher prices for heating oil and vegetables were leading factors in the increase, a news statement said. The annual inflation rate had remained stable at 3 percent from May through August.
LEAD: LONG before Rambo was a muscle-bound hero, he was an apple.

LEAD: THE folks who persuaded Ronald Reagan that deficits do not matter have an idea or two for the Kremlin. Surprisingly, perhaps, Mikhail Gorbachev's economic advisers are giving these ideas a respectful hearing: They were reportedly even discussed at last month's mini-summit meeting in Jackson Hole, Wyo.
LEAD: A blown fuse in an alarm system delayed the response of firefighters to a nursing home fire that killed 11 people, a city official said Monday.

LEAD: While edging toward coma during the endless years of baseball this week I suddenly realized I didn't know what a slider was.
LEAD: An obscure chapter of World War II history is emerging from beneath the cold, clear waters off the Aleutian Islands, where divers using sonar have made a survey of Japanese wrecks.

LEAD: In response to requests from other unions affected by the strike of the New York City Opera orchestra, the company announced yesterday that it was postponing by 48 hours its final decision on whether to cancel the remainder of its fall season, which is scheduled to run until Nov. 19.

LEAD: In the last few years, there has been a quiet but undisputed economic revolution in Indonesia, which is moving away from the traditional economy - planned, dominated and often owned by the state - toward more deregulation and private enterprise.
LEAD: Interest rates at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper fell sharply yesterday, to their lowest levels since mid-August.

LEAD: The last time Paul Fussell wrote about war, it was World War I, and his book, ''The Great War and Modern Memory,'' won two major book awards and became something of a classic. Mr. Fussell has now returned to the subject of war, this time World War II, and the critical response has, he admits, taken him by surprise with its intensity and, at times, its ferocity.

LEAD: In an effort to revive the faltering Middle East peace process, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d is seeking to organize a meeting in Washington between the Foreign Ministers of Egypt and Israel to pave the way for negotiations between Israelis and Palestinians.

LEAD: Supporters of a lower tax on capital gains are waging a bidding war in the Senate, offering ever more generous tax breaks in an effort to find the 60 votes they need to overcome parliamentary obstacles.

LEAD: The much heralded sale of the Denver Nuggets to two black businessmen has fallen through.

LEAD: Arnold M. Picker, former head of international operations for United Artists Pictures Inc. who was a prominent fund-raiser for Democratic political candidates, died of pneumonia on Sunday at New England Deaconess Hospital in Boston. He was 76 years old.

LEAD: Iberia Air Lines of Spain has agreed to purchase eight Airbus A340 commercial jets with an option to buy four others, the European consortium Airbus Industrie said. Iberia said the deal was worth $700 million.

LEAD: Adults are not as impressed with how well colleges and universities are performing as younger Americans are, according to a recent Gallup Poll. The poll also found that most minority students feel they do not have equal access to college because of their race.
LEAD: On Thursday, Douglass College here will dedicate a dormitory for 110 women as part of an innovative program to address the national shortage of female scientists and engineers.

LEAD: An article on Aug. 20 about the Soviet reaction to Poland's new Government misstated a remark by Fyodor M. Burlatsky, a Soviet newspaper commentator and member of the Supreme Soviet. As Mr. Burlatsky has since pointed out, he said the clash of forces from the right and the left could lead to the danger of a military government in the Soviet Union similar to the one installed in Poland in 1981, not to a military government in Poland now.

LEAD: Tonight's edition of ''The Other Side of the News'' brings us coaches, college presidents, sports writers and others acquainted with what Eamon Kelly, the president of Tulane University, who ended the men's basketball program in 1985 after a point-shaving scandal, calls the systemic mess of intercollegiate sports.

LEAD: ECONOMY Supporters of a lower capital gains tax are bidding for votes in the Senate, offering ever more generous packages of tax breaks. The latest offering would cut capital gains taxes for individual taxpayers and corporations. It would also provide tax breaks for small high-risk businesses and would restore the deductibility of individual retirement account contributions.
LEAD: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo nominated six people today to the State University board of trustees, including the chairwoman of the state chapter of the N.A.A.C.P., Hazel N. Dukes.

LEAD: A water main burst at the intersection of Eighth Avenue and West 43d Street yesterday, sending asbestos-laden mud gurgling up the avenue and cascading down onto the IND subway tracks below, officials said.

LEAD: J.P. Morgan Securities Inc., the investment banking subsidiary of J.P. Morgan & Company, became the first bank securities subsidiary to act as sole lead manager on a corporate underwriting yesterday, when it won a $30 million issue at competitive bid.

LEAD: Seeking to capitalize on the fragmentation of media outlets, Group W has started a venture to represent six regional cable sports networks to national advertisers. The company has retained Earle Palmer Brown/New York to promote the effort with a trade advertising campaign.

LEAD: A Federal district judge this evening denied a motion by environmentalists to delay the launching of the space shuttle Atlantis on Thursday because of concerns over a nuclear power supply.

LEAD: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator continued falling in September as United States semiconductor shipments rose, but orders declined, a trade group reported today.

LEAD: FETA, the tart, salty white cheese associated with Greek cuisine, can add a lively, sharp edge to all kinds of dishes.

LEAD: Margaret Groos, winner of the 1988 United States Olympic women's marathon trials, and Zoya Ivanova, the biggest winner among Soviet marathoners, have entered the New York City Marathon on Nov. 5.
LEAD: Thanks to two World Series-bound baseball teams, the Bay Area finally has a chance to even old scores.

LEAD: There's an Oldsmobile, this year's vintage, in the driveway of a suburban New Jersey condominium so new that the air around it remains tinged by the smell of sawdust. On the front step is a bright-hued coleus, a standard welcome-to-the-neighborhood gift. In the foyer, a vigilant gray poodle is pacing, uncertain whether to receive guests who speak English instead of his accustomed Russian with a wag of his tail or a worried growl.
LEAD: About 90 percent of the 6,240 pilots at United Airlines voted yesterday to put up $200 million in equity as part of a deal to buy the UAL Corporation, United's parent, for $300 a share.

LEAD: Five people, including three high-level executives of Donald J. Trump's three casinos in Atlantic City, were killed yesterday when their helicopter crashed in pine woodlands on the Garden State Parkway near Forked River, N.J.

LEAD: Lack of cash has shut down one of the city's three Spanish-language dailies, the newspaper's lawyer said today. Mr. Castillo said El Diario's owners, Inmobiliaria America Latina Inc., hoped to revive the newspaper, which was begun in May 1987 and had been losing about $80,000 a month.

In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Atalanta Sosnoff gave no reason for the sale.

LEAD: Dorothy McConnell, an editor, author and former chief executive of the Women's Division of the Methodist Church, died Friday at her home in Lucasville, Ohio. She had moved to Ohio from Manhattan last year and recently celebrated her 90th birthday.

Next they say polyunsaturated fat should be substituted for saturated fat; then they change their minds. Use monounsaturated fat instead, they say, and it is all right to eat a little saturated fat.

LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about Dow Jones & Company misstated the performance of the company's business publications in the third quarter of the year. That division of the company reported a slight gain in operating income compared with the third quarter of 1988, not a sharp drop. The article also misstated the quarter in which Dow Jones reported one-time gains; those gains were in the third quarter of last year, not the current year.

LEAD: Attila Agh, until last weekend a leading ''reform Communist,'' was asked today what party members should be called now that their organization has become the Socialist Party. ''Radical Socialists,'' he replied. For the first time in a Communist country, a ruling party has formally abandoned Communism.

LEAD: Saying he feels like ''a free man,'' Olin C. Robison has announced he will resign as president of Middlebury College, effective next summer, ending a 15-year tenure as leader of the liberal arts school.

LEAD: A proposed worldwide ban on ivory trading to save Africa's remaining elephants from poaching, widely thought to be the foregone conclusion of an international meeting here, is being vigorously opposed by some southern African nations.

LEAD: Private exporting companies have sold an additional 150,000 metric tons of United States soybean meal to the Soviet Union for delivery in 1989-90 under a long-term supply agreement, the Agriculture Department said today. The latest sales increased the purchases of United States soybean meal by Moscow to 250,000 tons for 1989-90.

LEAD: Grace Bellezza Liotta, a community leader in Brooklyn for almost 50 years, died Monday at Woodhull Hospital. She was 86 years old and had suffered a stroke months ago.

He took 10 days off before reporting to the Raiders for his third National Football League season.

LEAD: Few players realize that there are considerable opportunities for effective deceptive plays in the trump suit. There is, for example, a whole family of doubleton tenaces: jack-nine, queen-ten, king-jack and ace-queen. LEAD: Baby-kissing is an old political tradition, but lobbyists for the babies have historically had a rough time translating photo opportunities into money and support.

LEAD: CalFed Inc. agreed to sell its British property-casualty insurance business to an affiliate of John Head & Partners, a New York merchant banking firm, for about $100 million. The sale of the Anglo American Insurance Company is part of CalFed's strategy to sell its less profitable operations. CalFed has already sold a number of insurance businesses and its $125 million credit-card portfolio.

LEAD: When a new musical score is introduced to an audience, the accompanying pieces on the program are generally chosen without much concern for historical context. The audience is seldom encouraged to hear connections between the new piece and anything composed before it. The Juilliard String Quartet's program on Tuesday evening at the Juilliard Theater may or may not have been so casually planned, but it managed to set off interesting resonances.

LEAD: Two things have happened to Congressional Democrats in the 1980's: They have lost their identity; their campaign funds have swollen. There's a single story here.

LEAD: WE were up in an attic, three women, opening trunks and tearing the tape off boxes that had been sealed two years earlier. LEAD: Stocks ended lower yesterday as a weaker bond market and the selling of blue-chip issues pushed equities down for the second day.

LEAD: Within hours after the abortive coup attempt last week, soldiers had plastered over the bullet holes at army headquarters and touched up the paint. Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's base of power never looked better.

LEAD: A Baptist minister, a doorman walking home and a printer who planned to be married on Saturday were among 11 people slain in New York City during the 12 hours between sundown Wednesday and the following dawn. The police said it was one of the bloodiest nights the city has seen this year.

LEAD: GOLF Beck Advances in Match Play: Chip Beck trounced Aki Ohmachi of Japan, 8 and 6, yesterday to advance to the second round of the world match-play championship at Virginia Water, England. The reminders of Rickey Henderson's youth are scattered all across north Oakland, not so much in the places he played as in the minds of those who watched him.

LEAD: Photographing the spectacular colors of autumn requires no secret techniques, only a modicum of knowledge about cameras and films. Even a simple camera that does all the focusing and exposure calculations for you is sufficient, provided its idea of the perfect picture coincides with yours. And off-the-shelf amateur films are fully capable of rendering all the bright hues and subtle shades of fall, although some do it better than others.

LEAD: ''Fight for Us,'' opening today at the Paris Theater, is as much a political gesture as it is a political film. LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said it would move the production of its full-size vans to Flint, Mich., from plants in Lordstown, Ohio, and Scarborough, Ontario. G.M. and union officials said the move would be completed in late 1991. The shift will affect about 2,500 workers at the Lordstown plant, which employs a total of 11,500.

LEAD: David N. Dinkins's campaign has failed to provide adequate documentation for a number of expenses, including three payments totaling $9,500 for a ''get out the vote'' drive led by a community organizer, Robert (Sonny) Carson, New York City campaign finance records show.

LEAD: Technicians perched on a platform worked round the clock today to remove a faulty engine computer and get the space shuttle Atlantis and its Galileo space probe prepared for launching next Tuesday.

LEAD: On Sept. 23 the obituary of Irving Berlin misstated the number of Academy Awards he won. As a letter from a reader has pointed out, his only Oscar was for the song ''White Christmas'' from the 1942 film ''Holiday Inn.'' The song ''Cheek to Cheek'' from the 1935 film ''Top Hat'' was nominated for an Oscar, but did not win.

LEAD: There is a feeling abroad that pieces like Beethoven's ''Eroica'' symphony, which the San Francisco Symphony brought to Carnegie Hall Tuesday evening, are all but played out - that they have been interpreted so much, played so often, heard so repeatedly that somehow they just don't work any more. Skipping all the intermediary steps, he threw away shoulder pads, all kinds of inner construction and extraneous details like collars and made clothes that slither over the body in gossamer fabrics.

LEAD: Stephen C. Hartigan, a retired correction officer and former president of the Correction Officers Benevolent Association, died of congestive heart failure on Monday at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in the City Island section of the Bronx.

The assets of the 141 institutional funds decreased by $21.3 million, to $83.14 billion. The assets of the 233 general-purpose funds were up by $436.7 million, to $114 billion.
