LEAD: Yehudi Menuhin will conduct the Warsaw Sinfonia in Mendelssohn's Overture to ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' Lutoslawski's ''Funeral Music,'' the Haydn Symphony No. 104 and the Bruch Violin Concerto at 7:30 P.M. tomorrow at Avery Fisher Hall. Robert McDuffie is to be the soloist in the Bruch. Tickets are $11 to $20.

LEAD: It is only the second week of competition in the Big Ten Conference, but there have already been suggestions the title may be decided today when Michigan State is the host team in East Lansing, Mich., to Coach Bo Schembechler's Michigan Wolverines.
LEAD: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 9.95 percent, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.

LEAD: David N. Dinkins assembled more than 1,000 leaders of Jewish congregations and community groups at breakfast Thursday to repeat - this time ''as candidly and as plainly as I can'' -a message that has underscored much of his campaign for mayor of New York City.

LEAD: The Central Intelligence Agency and other Federal groups have begun using satellites to spy on the maze of clandestine airstrips, roads and factories run by the illicit drug industry in South America.

LEAD: International 2-6 South Korea will pay more of the cost of stationing U.S. forces on its soil as its economy grows stronger, but a U.S. cutback should not be considered now, President Roh said. Page 3 U.S. envoy in Seoul recalls raid 3 Pope ending Indonesia visit 6
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Ken O'Brien, distressed at losing his job as the Jets' starting quarterback, conceded today that ''the thought of being traded had crossed my mind.'' But he also said he was willing to wait to see how the situation was resolved.
LEAD: The highest-ranking Chinese leader to visit India in nearly 30 years met with Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi today and declared that a new era of friendship had begun between the two Asian giants.

LEAD: A New York City police officer testified yesterday that the police were about to release five youths who had been arrested after reports of marauding in Central Park last April, but changed their minds when they learned that a jogger had been beaten and raped in the park.
LEAD: This is a tale of principles, survival, love, art and, in the most recent chapter, rock music videos and a tire commercial. But it is especially about love.
LEAD: F.B.I. Is Given Leeway To Seize Fugitives Abroad

LEAD: It is clear from her debut as artistic director of the Trinity Repertory Company that Anne Bogart is not satisfied with halfway measures. Her unorthodox production of Gorky's ''Summerfolk,'' which opened Wednesday night, is an ambitious attempt to reinvent the play as a radical and relevant comedy about the complacency and ennui of the new Russian bourgeoisie.
LEAD: A brief review in the Sounds Around Town column of Weekend yesterday, about the Fred Hersch Trio, gave an incorrect address for Town Hall. It is at 123 West 43d Street.

LEAD: Though her Conservative Party's popularity is in a slump and her Government's policies are in a mess, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher showed no self-doubt and brooked none from her followers at a party conference here that ended today.
LEAD: With the overhaul of the nation's tax laws in recent years, many people have rearranged trust funds and shifted assets but failed to update their wills or or have new ones written.
LEAD: Peter MacDonald, the suspended tribal Navajo chairman charged with taking more than $400,000 in bribes and kickbacks, says he will ''stand up and fight'' the allegations.
LEAD: Because of Succoth, the Jewish Feast of Tabernacles, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.
LEAD: February 1980
LEAD: Inmates at the Hudson County Jail in Jersey City set fires in their cells last night and confronted guards and firefighters when they arrived to extinguish them, a prison spokesman said.
LEAD: Joe Foy, a third baseman with the 1967 American League champion Boston Red Sox and later a member of the Mets, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in New York. He was 46 years old.

LEAD: While Japanese companies are buying up Hollywood studios and financing American producers, a group of Japanese businessmen is hoping to invigorate Japan's sluggish film industry by grafting American rhythms and plot structure onto a Japanese movie.

LEAD: The New York City Board of Estimate has voted to extend the South Street Seaport Historic District by one block, reversing a 1977 decision and confounding the development plans of five major banks.

LEAD: Cito Gaston, who took over as manager of the Toronto Blue Jays 36 games into the season and turned a 12-24 team into the winner of the American League Eastern Division title, agreed to a one-year contract yesterday.
LEAD: Rudolph W. Giuliani turned up the heat on David N. Dinkins yesterday, both on the air and on the stump.
LEAD: Now that cooler weather is here and children are spending more time indoors it is a good time to see that pull cords for window coverings are safely secured.
LEAD: A Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday and charged with breaking into a church where a minister was found slain, the police said.

LEAD: The Los Angeles Raiders placed their former All-Pro running back Marcus Allen on injured reserve yesterday because of a torn knee ligament, and he will not be eligible to return until late November.(AP)

LEAD: The Senate approved a $14 billion plan to reduce the deficit tonight, stripping from it hundreds of extraneous measures including child care assistance and Medicare changes, and putting off a battle over cutting the capital gains tax.
LEAD: Football

Once again, Loomis is in pursuit of Michael Myers, the seemingly indestructible killer of teen-agers, who materializes in Haddonville, Ill., on
LEAD: Joseph A. Fernandez visited New York yesterday to start setting up shop as the new schools chancellor, and he immediately offered some blunt challenges to the city's way of running its schools.
LEAD: Market Turmoil

LEAD: Col. C. Emil Nelson, the former national chief secretary of the Salvation Army, died of complications of heart disease Thursday at Jersey Shore Medical Center in Asbury Park, N.J. He was 83 years old and lived in Asbury Park.

LEAD: The parallels were almost eerie: a Friday afternoon in October, the 13th no less, and the stock market suddenly goes into a free fall. In less than an hour, the Dow Jones index had declined by nearly 200 points.

LEAD: An investigation by the Department of Housing and Urban Development has found that its former New York administrator, Geraldine McGann, violated Federal ethical standards in connection with a subsidized housing program in her hometown of Island Park, L.I., but did not use her position to enrich her family or political allies.

LEAD: The Yankees yesterday named Harding (Pete) Peterson, a former executive vice president of the Pittsburgh Pirates, vice president and general manager after Bob Quinn resigned, as expected. Quinn accepted a similar position with the Cincinnati Reds.

LEAD: The jury in the bribery trial of Representative Robert Garcia and his wife, Jane Lee, began its first day of deliberations yesterday by requesting copies of evidence and asking to hear a reading of key testimony against the Garcias. At 5:20 P.M., the jurors sent out a note which said they could go no further, and Judge Leonard B.

LEAD: Institutional investors behaved yesterday as if the takeover craze had ended. Mindful of recent turmoil in the ''junk bond'' market, they grew concerned that corporate acquisitions, which have done much to drive up stock prices in recent years, would grind to a halt because of a lack of credit.

LEAD: Against odds and expectations, what seems like a serious peace plan for Lebanon is being tacked together by aging politicians meeting in the Saudi Arabian resort town of Taif. Arab League mediators have diligently promoted marathon talks among the surviving members of the Lebanese Parliament, elected in 1972.

LEAD: The ''Messa per Rossini'' that the New York Philharmonic presented under Helmuth Rilling's baton on Thursday evening is a musical camel, an improbable animal designed by a committee. A collaboration by 13 Italian composers in memory of Rossini, it is a Requiem Mass of gangling proportions instigated by Verdi, who wrote the final section.
LEAD: Oncogen, a Seattle-based division of the Bristol-Myers SquibbCompany, received a patent this week for a monoclonal antibody that company officials believe could treat lung and breast cancer.

LEAD: Walk into a store, and a security guard looks you over. Try to enter the lobby of an apartment building and a doorman blocks the way. Arrive for an appointment at a company office and a receptionist politely but firmly checks to see if the appointment really exists.

LEAD: Richard J. Koehler, the Correction Commissioner of New York City, announced yesterday that he is retiring as commissioner effective Dec. 22. Mayor Edward I. Koch praised Commissioner Koehler, who began as a police foot patrolman in 1967 for changing the Department of Correction ''all for the better in a quantum way.

LEAD: As she spoke, Janice Sorenson flashed the broad smile she has worn since Wednesday, the day her harvesting combine bumped into the long-sought fan disk suspected of causing the crash of a United Airlines DC-10 at Sioux City in July.

LEAD: Grateful Dead concerts are as iffy as blind dates, but the band had a good night tonight, the second concert of a five-night stand at the Brendan Byrne Arena. In two sets that added up to about two-and-a-half hours of music, the Dead concentrated on songs rather than its famous free-form jamming.
LEAD: After three straight declines, prices at the producer level surged nine-tenths of 1 percent in September, mainly because of increases for energy and motor vehicles.
LEAD: The Government was reported today to have moved Walter Sisulu and some other political prisoners to jails near their homes amid speculation that they would be released this weekend.
LEAD: Two school board members have resigned and seven athletes have quit an all-white private school's football team after it forfeited a game with a school that has a black player.
LEAD: ''I think this could be the end of the game.'' - Barbara L. Kenworthy, a portfolio manager, referring to the corporate takeover frenzy. [ 33:3. ]

LEAD: The group seeking to acquire the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, said yesterday that it had failed to complete the financing of its $6.75 billion buyout. But the group said its banks had advised that the deal could be financed ''on revised terms.''

LEAD: Tass, the Soviet press agency, has reported the landing of an extraterrestrial vehicle in the Russian city of Voronezh. The creatures who emerged were nine feet tall, with little knobby heads and three eyes. They had a small robot in tow and went for a ''short promenade about the park,'' Tass reports.

LEAD: The Campaign Matters column on Oct. 5, about the issue of ethnic slurs in the campaign for New Jersey governor, referred incorrectly to a 1986 Federal indictment of a union that had contributed money to some campaigns of Representative James J. Florio. The indictment accused leaders of roofers Local 30-30B, based in Philadelphia, of having made payments to a number of public officials, including state judges in Pennsylvania.

LEAD: The Los Angeles Lakers ran out of patience with Quintin Dailey yesterday and released the veteran guard. Dailey, signed as a free agent on Sept. 12, began training camp by missing a flight to the team's camp in Honolulu and then dropped out of the first practice early. On Thursday, he overslept and missed a practice.(

LEAD: Jay Ward, the creator of Bullwinkle and other popular television cartoon characters, died of kidney cancer on Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 69 years old. Mr. Ward, whose innovative work contributed sophistication and wit to television cartoons for more than three decades, was best known for his series about a bumbling, deep-voiced moose - Bullwinkle - and his sprightly companion, Rocky, the flying squirrel.
LEAD: To the Editor:

Huettner, a former president and director of Selchow & Righter, the Long Island company that manufactured Scrabble, Parchesi and Trivial Pursuit before being bought by Coleco Industries, died Thursday at University Hospital in Stony Brook, L.I., after a long illness. He was 86 years old and lived in Brightwaters, L
LEAD: After failing to win creditors' support for a 90-day financing agreement, Alcott & Andrews, the retail chain that specializes in career apparel for women, said it would go out of business.

LEAD: Dr. Beatrice Greenwald Kresky, a pediatrician and proponent of prenatal care for pregnant teen-agers, died of cancer Thursday at South Nassau Communities Hospital in Oceanside, L.I. She was 73 years old and lived in Rockville Center, L.I.

LEAD: I am summoned to deepest Washington. The summoner says he represents the most powerful man imaginable. I tell him sure he does and I am the ghost of the late Henry James and am, therefore, repelled by the vulgar social situation in which we find ourselves.

LEAD: An opening no-trump bid with a hand containing a singleton is frowned on by theory and avoided in practice by all but a few eccentrics. But an overcall of one no-trump is another matter, as on the diagramed deal reported by David Berah from a rubber bridge game at the Cavendish Club.

LEAD: A late wave of selling swept the stock market yesterday, sending the Dow Jones industrial average down 190.58 points, or 6.9 percent, to 2,569.26. In terms of points, the decline was the second largest in history, exceeded only by the 508-point plunge of Oct. 19, 1987, but the decline in percentage terms was not nearly so bad.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Selfishness, the players' failure to give up the ball, was one of the biggest complaints about the Knicks last season, and Stu Jackson witnessed that fault repeatedly as an assistant coach under Rick Pitino.
LEAD: A financing failure helped set off the drop in stock prices.
LEAD: The Auctions column in Weekend yesterday gave an incorrect date for the sale of 19th- and 20th-century prints at Sotheby's in Tokyo. It took place yesterday; it is not next Friday.

LEAD: Nearly any lapse from good health, with a few exceptions like the early stages of malignant tumors, will show up in one of the basic blood tests that can be performed in a routine physical. Such a blood test is diagnostic; it examines proteins that may not be detrimental to health but that indicate imminent health problems.
LEAD: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 16.

LEAD: One of the four main overhead rotors on the helicopter that crashed on Tuesday in central New Jersey, killing three senior Atlantic City casino executives and two crew members, broke in half in flight because of a series of cracks, Federal investigators said yesterday.

LEAD: Ana Luisa Behrens-Pacanins, a daughter of Mrs. Reinaldo Herrera of New York and a stepdaughter of Mr. Herrera, was married in New York yesterday to Luis Felipe Paraud-Carpena, the son of Maj. Gen. Fernando Paraud and Mrs. Paraud of Madrid. The Rev. Damian Myett performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St.

LEAD: Will Clark has been labeled racially ''prejudiced'' by Jeffrey Leonard, whom the Giants' first baseman labeled a ''tumor'' when they were teammates. Kevin Mitchell has apologized and agreed to pay what was described as a ''stiff fine'' by Roger Craig, the Giants' manager, for having missed Wednesday's workout.

LEAD: Mahler's progress from his Fourth Symphony to his Ninth tells us that life teaches much but not always what we want to know. The two works are joined by a number of similarities - the delicate employment of elephantine orchestral resources, for one, also the persistent references to the land: horns call from the hills beyond, naive folk songs are sung,
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A long-feared electronic virus set to cripple personal computers today created high anxiety but caused very little actual damage.
LEAD: Technicians replaced a defective computer in the space shuttle Atlantis today as they worked toward a launching scheduled for Tuesday.

LEAD: An osprey with a fish in its talons languidly flaps by, well above a stream of acrid smoke belching from a power plant - a juxtaposition of industry and nature that is common here where the Ohio River flows around a string of unspoiled islands.

LEAD: Christian insistence on guarantees of a Syrian withdrawal from Lebanon continued to hold up an agreement among Lebanon's factions today, but Arab officials expressed optimism that the sides would agree on a new charter for their nation.

LEAD: Along with the moose and the maple leaf, the scarlet-jacketed Mountie in his light-brown ranger hat has been a Canadian totem. Now, guardians of the country's traditions are being asked to accept a new image within the force that tamed the Canadian west: the Mountie in a turban.

LEAD: The seasons of the year flowed gently by on Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall. The 88 Seoul Art Troupe evoked the passage of time and the beneficence of nature in ''Dance, Voice of the Earth.''
LEAD: In her first visit to Japan as the United States special trade representative, Carla A. Hills faced off today against Japan's hard-nosed bureaucrats. They argued about baby bottles.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A group of lawyers is calling on its members to become whistle-blowers who bring dangerous products to the attention of state and Federal safety officials.

LEAD: Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole announced today that the leaders of both sides in the Pittston coal strike had agreed to meet with her on Saturday in the first face-to-face negotiations since the walkout began six months ago.

LEAD: Carl E. Newton, a New York lawyer for more than half a century who served as Deputy Coal Administrator in Washington during World War II, died Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 91 years old.

LEAD: TENNIS Fernandez Beats Seles: Mary Joe Fernandez outlasted Monica Seles, 6-4, 4-6, 7-6, yesterday to earn a semifinal berth at the International tournament in Filderstadt, West Germany. In other quarterfinal matches, Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina beat Hana Mandlikova of Australia, 6-3, 6-0; Zina Garrison beat Gigi Fernandez, 6-4, 6-2, and Laura Gildermeister of Peru beat Radka Zrubakova of Czechoslovakia, 6-4, 2-6, 7-5.(AP)

LEAD: Three weeks after a hurricane battered the Carolina coast, this inland city remains so littered with downed magnolias and willow oaks that officials are asking parents to keep children at home on Halloween.

LEAD: The Canadian Government today told Institut Merieux S.A. of France that its takeover bid of $943.5 million (Canadian) for Connaught Biosciences Inc. of Toronto was unacceptable under rules that require foreign buyouts of Canadian companies to be of ''net benefit'' to Canada.
LEAD: Whatever happened to the old standard soil recipe (1-1-1) used for potting house plants and growing seedlings?
LEAD: The scoring siren went off so often tonight behind John Vanbiesbrouck that by the end of the third period it sounded like one long scream.
LEAD: For people who think Rubik's Cube is too easy to solve, two graduate students patented a new cube puzzle this week that makes the original seem as simple as a picture puzzle.

LEAD: Summit Technology Inc., a small manufacturer of laser systems in Watertown, Mass., has developed a mask the size of a contact lens that the company believes could make eye surgery easier and more reliable.

LEAD: Prime Minister Ante Markovic of Yugoslavia met with President Bush today, seeking United States assistance in making economic and political changes opposed by hard-liners in the Communist Party.

LEAD: Warner Brothers Inc., the Hollywood studio owned by Time Warner Inc., filed a $1 billion lawsuit today against the Sony Corporation. The suit contends that Sony induced two Hollywood producers, Peter Guber and Jon Peters, to breach their five-year contract with Warner to become co-chairmen of Columbia Pictures, the studio

LEAD: The Turner Broadcasting System is considering starting a book publishing operation, possibly with one or more foreign partners. It is also looking into establishing a prize for works of fiction about the environment, according to Turner executives in Atlanta.

LEAD: The Resolution Trust Corporation said today that it had sold the assets and deposits of four insolvent savings institutions in transactions requiring $7.1 billion in Government assistance. These were the first large deals since Congress approved a $50 billion taxpayer bailout package in August.

LEAD: The Syrian fighter pilot who defected to Israel in a Soviet jet fighter on Wednesday said today that his flight was ''a very difficult mission'' since he flew at about 800 miles an hour and was only about 100 to 150 feet off the ground.

LEAD: In the last five years, Rutgers University, long regarded as one of the foremost research centers for alcohol abuse, has also become a model for colleges seeking innovative ideas to help reduce drinking among students.

LEAD: A special look into the ornithology collection of the American Museum of Natural History, at Central Park West and 79th Street, will be offered this weekend as part of the 50th anniversary of the opening of the Whitney Wing. Staff members will demonstrate how an exhibition is mounted, using the guano island case in the Hall of Oceanic Birds.

LEAD: The Flying Dutchmen of Hofstra took off against Wagner tonight and upset the Seahawks, 42-24. Wagner had been undefeated after five games and was ranked first among the East's 87 Division III teams.

LEAD: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, facing his most serious political crisis since coming to office in 1984, lost important votes in Parliament tonight, prompting speculation that he may call snap elections or try to postpone the voting while he rebuilds his political strength.

LEAD: Janice M. Baker, a daughter of Jack Baker of Central Square, N.Y., and the late Janet M. Baker, was married yesterday to Christopher G. Benedetto, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Benedetto of Huntington Bay, L.I. The Rev. James Morrison, a Baptist minister, and the Rev. David Baehr, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the First Baptist Church in Central

LEAD: Though it has been nearly two weekssince Newsweek magazine reported that four senior members of its staff had been present when Jackie Mason described David N. Dinkins as a ''shvartzer,'' the magazine's handling of the information has continued to be a center of controversy.

LEAD: After a six year intermission, the curtain has gone up on Act II of the long-running show at Times Square called the 42d Street Development Project. The latest revised production hit the boards in August.

LEAD: Although Coach Jim Schoenfeld made three significant changes tonight, the Devils failed to find the right combination for a third consecutive game. The result was a 4-3 overtime loss to the Montreal Canadiens, the second successive setback for the Devils, who have one victory in four games (1-2-1) this season.

LEAD: Pope John Paul II wound up a long trek across Indonesia today, telling Roman Catholic bishops to speak out against human rights abuses but trying to reassure the Government that Catholics present no threat.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The public has been well informed, by now, that this World Series between the San Francisco Giants and Oakland Athletics, which begins tonight in Oakland, is the first confined to a single metropolitan area since 1956, when the New York Yankees faced the Brooklyn Dodgers. But what about the first one?

LEAD: Gerard Gallant of the Detroit Red Wings has been suspended for five games by the National Hockey League for deliberately attempting to injure Garth Butcher, a defenseman for Vancouver, while going out of his way to retaliate in a game last Saturday. The Red Wings said they would not appeal.(AP)
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Oakland Athletics are still being chased by the failure of 1988. They say it is a forgotten part of their past, that last year has no bearing on this year, that there are no dark clouds hanging over them. But the clouds are there, seen or unseen.
LEAD: As the markets raced out of control yesterday, a series of emergency actions was initiated at the major stock, futures and options exchanges in an effort to limit price declines.
LEAD: Erich Honecker, the East German leader, met today with leaders of normally pliant minority parties and spoke of the need to change economic and social policies, East German reports said.
LEAD: Sales of American-built cars fell 12.6 percent in early October after two months of steep discounts by auto makers seeking to clear year-end inventories of 1989 models.

LEAD: The Golden State Foods Corporation, a privately held food processor and distributor that supplies only McDonald's restaurants, retained Goldman, Sachs & Company to help it explore merger possibilities. Howard Hansen, an analyst with Kidder, Peabody & Company, said the McDonald's Corporation was an unlikely suitor because it had a policy of not selling supplies or equipment to franchisees.
LEAD: Paul Trotman, a 19-year-old Brooklyn man, was mourned at his funeral yesterday as another victim of New York City's racial and ethnic violence.
LEAD: Mi Selecto led a parade of long shots under the wire tonight in the $500,000 Meadowlands Cup at Meadowlands Race Track, while Blushing John finished a distant seventh as the 3-to-5 favorite.

LEAD: Herbert M. Weed, a former vice president of the Anaconda Company, a leading producer of nonferrous metals and uranium, died of a heart attack Tuesday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Denver. He was 68 years old and lived in Cherry Hills Village, a Denver suburb.

LEAD: A ''flight to quality'' sent prices of Treasury securities soaring and yields plunging yesterday. Dealers said the demand for all Treasury securities surged as stock prices began tumbling in the last 45 minutes of trading on the New York Stock Exchange. But a sharp decline in the dollar tended to take the edge off the price advances.
LEAD: Following is the transcript of President Bush's news conference here today as provided by the Federal News Service: OPENING STATEMENT

LEAD: Reversing a nine-year-old policy, the Justice Department has advised the Federal Bureau of Investigation that it may legally seize United States fugitives in foreign countries without the consent of foreign governments, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: Ambassador Donald Gregg described today how he and his wife listened from their locked bedroom while militant students broke into their residence and caused about $30,000 damage in the living room early this morning.

LEAD: It was like a return to his pro football glory days for Herschel Walker today. Here he was, just one day into his Minnesota Vikings career, and he felt comfortable in an offense for the first time this season.

LEAD: Martha Graham has invited several of her dancers to create works for the Martha Graham Dance Company's current season at City Center (131 West 55th Street), through Oct. 22. On Wednesday night, Thea Nerissa Barnes and Lyndon Branaugh presented dances that suggested these neophyte choreographers have learned from the committed, professional atmosphere of this major American modern dance company.
LEAD: Emma Goldman in Exile From the Russian Revolution to the Spanish Civil War By Alice Wexler Illustrated. 301 pages. Beacon Press. $24.95.
LEAD: Questions appear on page 15.

LEAD: The Lockheed Corporation, in the early stages of competing for a $2 billion Air Force training jet program, said it would use an Italian jet design if it won the contract. Lockheed said it had an agreement with Aermacchi S.p.A. of Varese, Italy, to use the MB-339 jet tandem-trainer for the United States Air Force's Primary Aircraft Training System program.

LEAD: NBC is expected to announce early next week that Jane Pauley, the co-anchor of ''Today,'' will leave the program to become part of a new weekly prime-time news program or series of programs next summer.

LEAD: William A. Kottmeyer, an educator and a prolific author of textbooks, died of an aneurysm Wednesday during abdominal surgery at St. Mary's Health Center in Richmond Heights, Mo. He was 79 years old and lived in Town and Country, Mo.

LEAD: Citing ''total educational failure,'' the state of New Jersey assumed full responsibility for all 37 schools in Jersey City - the first state takeover of a local school district in memory. Coming on the heels of a summit meeting where the nation's governors promised improvements in education, the move demonstrates just how far some states will have to go to meet that obligation.

LEAD: New York's State Insurance Fund, founded 75 years ago by a socially inventive, farsighted Legislature, now writes 45 percent of all workers' compensation insurance in the state. To mark its anniversary, the fund recently sent its policyholders a handsome financial statement complete with a message of congratulation from Gov.

LEAD: Talks between Renault of France and Volvo of Sweden about possible joint efforts are the latest sign of growing concern about increased competition in Europe when trade barriers fall in 1992, the rise of Japanese auto makers as a global force and the soaring cost of research and development.

LEAD: President Bush encouraged White House aides and Republican Congressional leaders today to continue negotiations to avoid a confrontation over Federal financing for abortions for victims of rape and incest.
LEAD: Bobby Brown, the president of the American League, said today that the Dennis Eckersley emery-board issue is not an issue with him.

LEAD: The Senate and the House of Representatives have moved to repeal all or part of the Federal program of expanded health insurance for older Americans. A new measure to replace the 1988 Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act has still to be shaped by a Congressional conference committee, but there seems to be little doubt at this point that most of the benefits will end shortly, along with the income-tax surtax that was to pay for them.

LEAD: Harry Edwards, a sociology professor with a reputation for bluntly criticizing racism in professional sports, has been accused of being insensitive to Jewish students in an introductory sociology class at the University of California at Berkeley.

LEAD: A Federal appeals court ruled today that Richard W. Miller is not likely to flee and ordered a judge to set bail for the former Federal agent whose conviction for espionage in 1986 was overturned this year.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Thursday about an increase in the Japanese discount rate misidentified the person who said that while the strength of the dollar was a factor in the increase, other factors were equally important. He was Satoshi Sumita, governor of the Bank of Japan, not Susumo Saito of the Credit Suisse Investment Advisory Company.
LEAD: Richard F. Uhlmann, a grain dealer who served as president of the Chicago Board of Trade in 1948, died at Highland Park (Ill.) Hospital on Monday after a brief illness. He was 91 years old.

LEAD: Philip Glass, Frank Corsaro, Maurice Sendak, Christopher Keene, Erie Mills, John Cheek and others will take part in a series of four seminars on ''Opera in the 20th Century,'' presented by the New York City Opera Guild at the Guggenheim Museum on four successive Mondays at 6 P.M.

LEAD: Federal researchers plan to use 15 injured golden eagles in an experiment that could lead to the renewed use of Compound 1080, a highly toxic coyote poison. The plan is meeting strong opposition from supporters of animal rights.

LEAD: Gaston's chief managing rival, Frank Robinson, whose Baltimore Orioles went from last place to second place and improved by 33 games, was named manager of the year by The Associated Press yesterday. Robinson received 69 points and Don Zimmer of the Chicago Cubs received 51 in voting by sportswriters and broadcasters.

LEAD: * Arby's 42 largest franchisees formed a group, A. P. Association Inc., to oppose the continued control of the roast-beef sandwich chain by Victor Posner, chairman of DWG Corp., which controls Arby's.

LEAD: Sidney Moncrief, an All-Star in the National Basketball Association five times who was dropped by the Milwaukee Bucks this summer because of knee problems, said yesterday he was retiring to become a broadcaster for the Dallas Mavericks.
LEAD: Two years after extensive water damage silenced its pipes, a vintage Wurlitzer organ that was a permanent fixture at the Brooklyn Paramount Theater can be heard again this weekend.

LEAD: Although Wall Street was stunned by the selling wave that swept the stock market in the last hour of trading yesterday, it was not devastated. Some market participants attributed the 190-point, or 6.9 percent, plunge in the Dow Jones industrial average to overspeculation.
LEAD: Using a rare earth metal, a metallurgist has developed a high-energy flexible magnet that he said could easily be shaped into electronic components.

LEAD: Retail sales rose a moderate five-tenths of 1 percent last month, the Government said today. Analysts said the report showed consumer spending was still fairly strong, despite a slowing economy.
LEAD: Hyman Solniker, a retired New York City Criminal Court judge, died Thursday at Beth Israel Hospital after a long illness. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: President Roh Tae Woo says that South Korea will increase its share of the cost of stationing American military forces here as it grows stronger economically, but that a cutback of those forces should not be considered now.

LEAD: Centrust Bank of Miami said yesterday that it had been ordered to stop paying dividends on its preferred stock because of financial problems including losses in its holdings of ''junk bonds.'' The order to stop paying dividends came from Federal regulators at the Office of Thrift Supervision. Federal and state regulators are considering a proposal by Centrust to sell 63 of its branches for $150 million to the Great Western Financial Corporation of Beverly Hills, Calif.

LEAD: The departure of Roger Rosenblatt as editor of U.S. News & World Report, officially announced yesterday, signals the end of five years of turmoil at the top echelon of the weekly magazine, its owner, Mortimer B. Zuckerman, said yesterday.

LEAD: On Thursday night, television news viewers finally saw Rudolph W. Giuliani in a flattering light. Entering a ballroom full of cheering supporters, the Republican mayoral candidate was escorted to a dais by the President of the United States.

LEAD: Bob Lurie remembers the day 13 years ago when he bought the San Francisco Giants for $8 million because they were more interesting than real estate and because they had their bags packed and were ready to skip town for Toronto. He was cheered as a great civic hero for saving the ball club by the Bay.
LEAD: CARDINAL BERNARDIN Easing Conflicts - and Battling for the Soul of American Catholicism. By Eugene Kennedy. 316 pp. Chicago: Bonus Books. $19.95.

LEAD: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez says he will argue that Nicaragua's coming elections offer an opportunity to break the current Central American deadlock when he meets President Bush at the White House on Thursday.

LEAD: If it is no surprise anymore to find, say, a Japanese motor under the hood of an American car, perhaps it is not surprising to find a Honda in America's Automotive Hall of Fame. Last week, Soichiro Honda, whose company was the first to use American workers to build Japanese cars, took his place with the likes of Henry Ford, Walter Chrysler and Alfred Sloane of General Motors in the Automotive Hall of Fame, which opened 50 years ago in Midland, Mich.

LEAD: AFTER swirling through the Soviet Union, Poland and Hungary, the Gorbachevian winds of change have turned to huffing and puffing at the formidable bastion of East Germany. They haven't blown the house down, to be sure, but after a remarkable month of mass flight and mass protest, the Communist leadership is feeling the heat.

LEAD: SOME YEARS AGO, I SPENT A LOT of time knocking around as a judge at wine competitions. It seemed like the thing to do - a chance to learn something, to taste a lot of wines and see the country. That's pretty much the way it worked out, too.

LEAD: A Federal appeals court in Manhattan last week upheld the 1987 convictions of 15 men in the ''pizza connection'' narcotics trial, but overturned another defendant's guilty verdict on racketeering and conspiracy charges.

LEAD: Shawon Dunston is best known as a fine-fielding, hard-throwing shortstop of the Chicago Cubs, but during the recent National League playoff, he stood in the middle of the Cubs' clubhouse and played baseball philosopher, raising a series of interesting questions.

LEAD: THOUGH the surroundings at Doc's are minimal - a small frame house with plain pine floors, mismatched chairs painted apple green, framed posters and butcher-paper table covers - the pizzeria has head-on views of scenic Lake Waramaug and classical music as a backdrop to dinner.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Rose of New York and East Hampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Emily Rose, to Prof. James H. Marrow, the son of Helen C. Marrow of Miami Beach and the late Jerome Marrow of New York. A November wedding is planned.

LEAD: The marriage of Stacy Elise Silk, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Mark Silk of West Hartford, Conn., to Michael Alan Feldman, a son of Dr. Richard N. Feldman of Rocky Hill, Conn., and the late Bonnie Wood Feldman, took place in Hartford last evening. Rabbi Harold Silver officiated at the Hartford Club.

LEAD: FOR the Maori (rhymes with ''dowry'') people of New Zealand, woodcarving is the highest form of art, embodying spiritual concepts that can only be brought to it by craftsmen who have been specially trained: tohunga (skilled man-priest-teacher) whakairo (carver).
LEAD: ''It's total emotional and psychological chaos. People are dumping everything.'' Eugene Peroni, analyst at Janey Montgomery Scott, on Friday's action.

LEAD: The Giants and the Athletics are two of the oldest franchises and hallowed names in baseball history, but as San Francisco and Oakland they are 3,000 miles away from their origins and are meeting in a World Series for the first time since thier transcontinental migration.
LEAD: Michigan's defense, led by Tripp Welborne, twice held off fourth-quarter Michigan State scoring threats today and the Wolverines beat the Spartans, 10-7.

LEAD: Lise Lotte Andersen, an associate at the New York law firm of Rosenman & Colin, and David Meister, an associate at Obermaier, Morvillo & Abramowitz, also a New York law firm, were married last evening at the Loft in New York. Rabbi Robert Lippman officiated.
LEAD: Because of the Autumn Jubilee, Second Avenue between 14th and 34th Streets will be closed today from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.

LEAD: The Dow Jones industrial average fell 190.58 points, to 2569.26, on Friday, the largest decline since the Oct. 19, 1987, crash. The market began to fall on news that the big United Airlines buyout deal had fallen through. This 6.91 percent decline in the value of the Dow came just four days after the market hit new highs.

LEAD: Senior officers in the Honduran armed forces contend that their commander misappropriated millions of dollars in military aid sent by the United States.

LEAD: As a reaction to the cluttered English country-house style so popular five years ago, a new breed of traditionalists is making news with their pared-down interiors. While firmly rooted in the foundations of good design, their rooms are surprisingly restrained. Sparsely furnished and without a myriad of patterned fabrics and wallpapers, they are at once tailored and elegant.

LEAD: As the new Solidarity-led Government moves into its second month, there is no triumphalism in Poland. Is is as though winning the long struggle to wrest power from the Communist monopoly were a cold bath, an uneasy awakening from the heady if harsh days of confrontation.

LEAD: In the interview with Bishop John McGann, your reporter asked the question: ''What about those who express a belief in a woman's right to abort as part of control over her own body?''

''You have to check out the markets a lot in this business,'' said Mr. Hocutt, the vice president of sales for Flowers Industries' Atlanta Baking Company.

LEAD: THE eldest of my three daughters, a 19-year-old with a cheerful outlook, attended her first bridal shower on a recent Sunday. The round trip to Manchester encompassed four hours. She arrived home tired and slightly disappointed.

Clearly, they realized the power of medicine to shock life back into a stopped heart and the power of language to make that same heart stop, for a few seconds, to feel the power of the written word.

After leaving the White House, he became (with Truman) an honorary co-chairman of the Planned Parenthood Association, at a time when it was no less controversial than it is today.

LEAD: PUPPET shows and theater are being used to lure children and adults to 45 libraries to learn more about AIDS.

LEAD: The warden of the Louisiana State Penitentiary has been dismissed because he operated a cockfighting business at the prison and failed to maintain security and to report escapes, the head of the state's corrections department said on Wednesday.

LEAD: A question-and-answer article on Sept. 3 about the selling of medical practices misstated the subject area in which Dr. Madeleine Pelner Cosman earned her doctorate. It was in English and comparative literature, not medical law.

LEAD: THE slimy salamander, a North American variety of salamander that has long been considered to be rare in Connecticut, may not be as uncommon here as once thought, according to a survey of Fairfield County by the Nature Conservancy.

LEAD: THE battle over strengthening the Clean Air Act is placing enormous strain on the industry coalition that has worked together in the 1980's to lobby successfully against stronger air pollution laws.

LEAD: ROEMER: Man Against the Mob. By William F. Roemer Jr. (Donald I. Fine, $19.95.) Of his many awards and commendations, the former Federal Bureau of Investigation agent William F. Roemer Jr. writes that ''the best testament'' came from the organized-crime boss Jackie Cerone, who crowned Mr. Roemer ''the nemesis of Chicago organized crime.

LEAD: MANY Americans have only recently begun to learn the full story of Japanese-American internment by the United States Government during World War II. Scattered in the county are Japanese-American residents who were among the 110,000 people - the majority American citizens - forced from their West Coast homes into makeshift barracks and confined behind barbed wire for periods up to three years.

LEAD: The Bush Administration is preparing to ask Congress to expand use of the death penalty significantly by permitting execution of drug kingpins whether or not they are involved in a killing, Justice Department officials say.

LEAD: RAYMOND CHANDLER'S LOS ANGELES. By Elizabeth Ward and Alain Silver. (Overlook, Cloth, $25; Paper, $19.95.) Perhaps no detective in fiction is so indelibly associated with a city as is Philip Marlowe with Los Angeles. In the variegated communities that make up the West Coast metropolis, Marlowe walked those ''mean streets .

LEAD: A Federal appeals court, calling body-cavity searches ''dehumanizing and humiliating,'' has ruled unconstitutional the Los Angeles police's policy of conducting such a search on anyone arrested on felony charges.

LEAD: I've been a big fan of one of baseball's greatest showmen, Rickey Henderson, for many years, and I'd like to explain why. I had the opportunity to watch him for about six hours one day at a baseball card show. Also present were Jim Kaat, Don Mattingly and Pete Rose. It was mobbed, and lines were endless.

LEAD: An engine computer to replace the one that developed problems on the space shuttle Atlantis passed its tests today, and the space agency said preparations were being made to launch the shuttle on Tuesday.

LEAD: The Texas A&I tailback Johnny Bailey broke Tony Dorsett's 13-year-old National Collegiate Athletic Association career rushing record tonight with a 4-yard carry against Central State. The run gave Bailey 6,085 yards, eclipsing the mark of 6,082 set by Dorsett at Pitt in 1973-76.

LEAD: Veronica Louise Schaaf, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bradford Perkins Schaaf of Ridgewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Wayne Michael Bloom, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Myron Bloom of Taunton, Mass. Judge Steven M. Honeg of Municipal Court in Upper Saddle River, N.J., officiated at the Central Unitarian Church in Paramus, N

LEAD: CBS announced on Friday that ''The Pat Sajak Show'' would be shortened to one hour beginning on Oct. 30. The 90-minute program, which was introduced nine months ago to compete with NBC's ''Tonight'' show with Johnny Carson, is currently broadcast weeknights from 11:30 P.M. to 1 A.M. In its new format, it will end at 12:30 A.M.

LEAD: To the Editor: I enjoyed your excellent and informative article on Palladio in the Veneto (''A Palladian Journey in Vicenza,'' Travel, Aug. 13). Your readers might want to pack along Caroline Constant's ''Palladio Guide,'' which covers all of his built works. This compact book is an ideal traveling companion for Palladio buffs, and includes maps as well as architectural drawings.

LEAD: NEARLY everyone in this long-established commuter village recognizes the local dependence on the railroad, which has rolled through the center of town since 1844. But now some angry residents say the railroad has gone too far - 170 feet too far.

LEAD: TRACEY ULLMAN, THE PUCKISH 29-year-old British star of her own Sunday night television variety show, has played girls half her age and matrons twice her age; she's played a psychologist and a postal worker, a bitter Beverly Hills divorcee and a suicidal chorine.

LEAD: The leader of India's political opposition, fearing electronic vote fraud in the coming national election, said today that he would oppose the use of computerized voting machines unless their design and programming could be checked by independent experts.

LEAD: Susan J. Israel and Daniel R. Scherlis, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Scherlis of Baltimore, were married last evening in Chestnut Hill, Mass., at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. David Israel. Rabbi Roland Gittelsohn officiated.

LEAD: Assemblyman David C. Kronick's article, ''The Trashing of New Jersey'' (Opinion page, Sept. 17), is another in a series from many sources that improperly accuse New Jerseyites of being addicted to littering and other bad habits related to solid-waste control. It is a cover-up for poor performance by New Jersey politicians who call themselves leaders.

LEAD: A SERIES of bitter state-by-state battles over abortion has barely begun, but already advocates of abortion rights have proclaimed a watershed. Never before, they argued last week, had political attitudes and behavior shifted so far, so fast, in their favor.
LEAD: A young campaign organizer just back from the northern region of Kavango burst into the office of the South-West Africa People's Organization here.

LEAD: Twenty-nine House members voted one way in a vote relaxing restrictions on Federal financing of abortion on Sept. 9, 1988, then voted the opposite way on a virtually identical proposal on Wednesday.

LEAD: Violent thunderstorms ripped across a wide swath of upstate New York this evening, bringing winds that reached 85 miles an hour, heavy rain and hail and leaving at least one person dead and five others injured. Power was cut off to thousands of residents.
LEAD: Jean Dursee does not think of herself as a pivotal person in this year's nip-and-tuck race for governor.

LEAD: MUSEUMS get critical attention for their temporary shows but not for their permanent collections. Though this is but a symptom of art's show-business condition, the Montclair Museum, for one, is not taking it lying down.

LEAD: John F. X. Condon, the resonant voice of Madison Square Garden and the New York Knicks basketball team for 42 seasons, died of cancer Friday night at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Queens.
LEAD: Dartmouth College officials suspended recognition of one of its 31 fraternities last week following an investigation into alcohol abuse at initiation activities two years ago.

LEAD: Janet Wilson Rich and Mark Adrian Edwards, graduates of Harvard University, were married in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday at Memorial Church on the Harvard campus. The Rev. Daniel Morrissey, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

LEAD: BLACK GIRL, WHITE GIRL. By Patricia Moyes. (Holt, $15.95.) In her 18th novel featuring Detective Chief Superintendent Henry Tibbett, the veteran mystery writer Patricia Moyes moves her urban hero from the dreariness of winter in London to the decidedly sunnier island of Tampica, the languid, imaginary Caribbean paradise that also served as the setting for her 1977 novel, ''The Coconut Killings.

LEAD: GARY M. YOUNG'S portrait of the state of the arts in Connecticut would excite even the most jaded listener. Last year alone, said Mr. Young, the executive director of the Connecticut Commission on the Arts, the nonprofit arts industry generated $354 million. In addition, the arts employed 12,300 people and attracted an audience of more than 8.5 million people.

LEAD: This time, the Oakland Athletics were not bitten by a ninth-inning home run. Kirk Gibson did not grab a bat, did not hobble out of the dugout and did not break the A's hearts with one dramatic swing. This time, they held on.
LEAD: THE WOODCHIPPER MURDER By Arthur Herzog. Illustrated. 274 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $18.95.

LEAD: The commander of the Christian forces in Lebanon, Gen. Michel Aoun, threatened retribution against Christian Lebanese negotiators today to try to keep them from making concessions to their Muslim counterparts in talks here on ending the 14-year civil war.

Are Working at Home'' (Aug. 27) in which myself and my organization, The Long Island Freelance Exchange, were mentioned. Urstadt of Bronxville, N.Y., and Willing Legendre Biddle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Biddle of Princeton, N.J., took place yesterday at the Reformed Church of Bronxville. The Rev. Frank Goodwin, an English Baptist minister, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Lisa Rachel Bardack, a medical student at New York University, and Dr. Mitchell S. Nobler, a resident in psychiatry at the New York State Psychiatric Institute at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, were married last evening at Larchmont (N.Y.) Temple. Rabbi H. Leonard Poller officiated.

LEAD: FOR just about as long as they have been around, bed and breakfast inns have been synonymous with modesty in lodging. For a small sum of, say, $25 to $50 a night, even in the early 80's a couple could get the basics: a firm bed, perhaps a shared bath, a hearty meal the next morning and the company of an innkeeper who lived on the premises.

LEAD: For This Week: Christmas cactus, jade plant and any other house plants that are lingering outdoors should be moved in, pronto; frost can be expected any time now and these plants could be ruined. In the garden, continue planting, especially bulbs. Rake leaves or blow them off the lawn and add to compost.

Ginkel of Muskogee, Okla., have announced. Miss Ginkel, 34 years old, graduated cum laude from Bucknell University.

LEAD: What baseball needs today is a clean-cut look. Getting rid of the long-haired and bearded image of the players would automatically remove the ''showy'' aspect of the game.

LEAD: GOOD jobs are going begging. And the shortage of workers needed to fill them is expected to become even more severe in the next decade, because the number of 18-year-olds entering the job market will drop by 8 percent, according to Census Bureau projections.

LEAD: Samuel G. Freedman is right; teachers and administrators do work long hours in buildings that are often crumbling from within and under siege by lawless elements from without (''Snapshots of Hope and Hopelessness,'' Sept. 17).

LEAD: The body of a 52-year-old high school science teacher was found in his home Friday night, the Nassau County police said today. He had been stabbed to death. The teacher, Edward Slater, had been reported missing by officials of Great Neck North High School on Wednesday.
LEAD: IT is apparent that real estate is in a slump when a new two-bedroom house in Ocean County is advertised at $16,000 for four months and does not sell.
LEAD: When Bill Fitch became the Nets' coach in August, he knew the team was far from being a contender. Now Fitch is finding out exactly how far away the Nets are.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo's promise of Canadian electricity for Long Island is as phony as his promise of ''power cheap as Freeport'' and lower taxes. A recent news item indicates that lack of rainfall and high local demand have reduced Hydro-Quebec export capacity.

LEAD: I can't think what possessed Margaret Truman, a woman I much admire (''He Didn't Like Ike,'' by Harry S. Truman, Sept. 17). Her article reveals much more about Truman than about Eisenhower. Truman has always been known as a hothead, given to instant reactions, but these papers show him to be bitter and censorious as he played armchair quarterback during his retirement.

LEAD: For members of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, meetings involving John D. Dingell, Henry A. Waxman and clean air have often been as uncomfortable as listening to parents quarrel at dinner.

LEAD: The former president of the Jewish Student Union at the State University of New York at Binghamton, who is awaiting trial on charges of painting anti-Semitic slurs at his own organization's headquarters, has been elected to the academic governing board of the university's undergraduate division.

LEAD: In their first face-to-face visit with Nicaraguan rebel troops, a special commission of international officials came to this rugged mountain camp today to urge the fighters to accept a recent regional agreement calling for the disbanding of their army.

LEAD: FREQUENT FLYER. By Kinky Friedman. (Morrow, $16.95.) Perhaps because a marketing gimmick can be one of the keys to success in writing a series of mysteries, Kinky Friedman is at once the author and the protagonist of his detective novels. In ''Frequent Flyer,'' his fourth whodunit, Mr. Friedman's hero, Kinky, a rock musician turned occasional snooper and constant smart mouth, is once again a sort of urban Indiana Jones, operating out of a lower Manhattan loft where he lives in a perpetual haze of cigar smoke with his cat.
LEAD: ''WE had to make friends with the wild creatures in the camp, especially the spiders, mice and rats, because we were outnumbered.''

LEAD: DEAD BY MORNING. By Dorothy Simpson. (Scribners, $16.95.) The ninth mystery in this British writer's Luke Thanet detective series has classic ingredients: a dead body discovered in curious circumstances, lots of suspects and a tight-lipped village guarding its secrets. Two days after his return to the English hamlet where he grew up, the Martindale family's long-absent black sheep, Leo, lies dead in a ditch, the ostensible victim of a hit-and-run accident.

LEAD: Sandra Joy Horbach, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Horbach of Bellevue, Wash., was married in New York last evening to Steven Frederick Skoler, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Skoler of White Plains. Rabbi Charles G. Agin officiated at the Pierre.

LEAD: An article on Sept. 17 about the British theatrical producer Cameron Mackintosh incorrectly stated that he was associated with ''Evita.'' The Andrew Lloyd Webber-Tim Rice musical was directed by Harold Prince and produced by Robert Stigwood.

LEAD: In this poor rural town near the Rhode Island border, officials say they have found a solution to their financial woes that would also help clean up much of the Northeast: a power plant that burns 10 million discarded tires a year.

LEAD: ''You can believe i'm nervous. Who wouldn't be? I'm starting my tenure here as only the second music director ever for the society, after 20 years of success.'' Fred Sherry is a big man with a broad smile and a shock of prematurely gray hair. He fills the smallish office of the director of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center with the nervous, edgy energy proverbially associated with New Yorkers.

LEAD: CONTEMPORARY tapestries by seven internationally known weavers looks surprisingly at home in a 100-year-old house and a bank in Port Washington. The hues, patterns and textures of woven yarns enliven these plaster and concrete walls, just as the threads of medieval tapestries warmed the stones of ancient castles.
LEAD: Babe Ruth is at the World Series, and so is Pete Rose, and so is Jackie Robinson, and so is A. Bartlett Giamatti.
LEAD: OUT ON THE CUTTING EDGE By Lawrence Block. 260 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $17.95.

LEAD: He may have been forced to resign as basketball coach at the University of Kentucky after it was found that his program was riddled with rules violations, but that doesn't mean that Eddie Sutton is no longer a welcome figure in the world of college basketball.

LEAD: A WOMAN in Middlesex County has worked for her company 10 years. Over the last two years, she has spent much of her time caring for her widowed mother, who is partly paralyzed from a stroke. Her mother has become confused, and she fears being left alone in the house they share.
LEAD: The rightist Nicaraguan rebels encamped in Honduras are selling their American-supplied arms and ammunition to leftist rebels in El Salvador, diplomats here say.

LEAD: LAST SUMMER, FRANCIS Fukuyama, a deputy director of the U.S. State Department, asserted that history is dead and that class struggle had been quashed by the ideological - and technological - triumph of the West. The idea of an end to progress, though provocative, may have seemed less naive if Fukuyama had limited his analysis to home-office electronics.

LEAD: LIKE many Africans, the Zimbabwean farmers in the Nyami Nyami district on the shores of the Zambesi River long regarded the local elephants as a nuisance that trampled crops or as an easy source of meat and ivory.

LEAD: Years from now, purveyors of style will easily be able to date rooms decorated in the 1980's. Indeed, in every decade, certain design trends become not simply signatures of their time but veritable cliches. The ubiquitous English country style, for example, ushered in an overabundance of clutter and chintz, while the post-modern interior brought back neo-classical columns and busts.

LEAD: The showmanship so prevalent in baseball and other professional sports today is symptomatic of the pervasive influence of television, which has greatly inspired the ''styling'' as well as the myriad of congratulatory gestures at home plate. Fans, reacting to an unfolding soap opera instead of a sporting event, clamor for curtain calls when their heroes save the day.

LEAD: I WONDER where they are and what they are thinking now, the two men we shared a table with on May Day in East Berlin in 1959. I looked for them these last weeks in the faces of the young families making their passage from Eastern Europe to the West, but it would be unlikely that I would recognize them on a television screen or in a newspaper photograph after 30 years.

LEAD: MOST major cities are dotted with restaurants where the locals go when they want something ethnic. In Helsinki, Russian restaurants provide exotic cuisine for natives when they're looking for a change from the tame and often prosaic

LEAD: IT HAS BEEN SAID THAT THE field of electronics is emblematic of our age. It reflects the technical imagination of our era and determines our mode of life, just as steam engines did in Victorian times. Radio, recordings and television have become principal shapers of public consciousness, and during the 1980's, technical developments in these media both broadened and intensified their cultural role.

LEAD: REIGNING INDIANAPOLIS 500 champion Emerson Fittipaldi is cruising past the farmhouses that dot the Irish Hills of Michigan. It is a lazy Thursday afternoon in August, three days before the running of the Marlboro 500, and the Brazilian driver is making his leisurely way to the lake house he rents for the week of the race.

LEAD: Having endured the ignominy last season of being the first team to lose to Columbia over a 5-year span encompassing 48 games, Princeton had a score to settle with the Lions today. And the Tigers got even decisively, beating Columbia, 24-8, before 11,140 at Palmer Stadium.
LEAD: Four young men who pulled crab traps from the St. Johns River on Memorial Day weekend began paying their debt to society today - by parading on a bridge with signs admitting their acts.

LEAD: It has taken some years for history to recognize that Mr. Truman stepped into a position for which he was ill prepared but grew well into it. It does his image no good to present the petty-minded picture that Ms. Truman does of her father. I would prefer to believe that he was capable of, and did rise to the demands of, the office admirably.

LEAD: ''From the evidence coming across our desk, this is the Year of the Serial Killer.''

LEAD: The American software industry finds itself at the crest of what can only be termed a golden age - it accounts for 52 percent of the world's software consumption and holds roughly 70 percent of a $50 billion world market. By the year 2000, the world software market will be worth $1 trillion a year.
LEAD: Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole said today that she would soon appoint a special mediator in a new effort to end the United Mine Workers' six-month-old strike against the Pittston Coal Group.
LEAD: A 17-year-old youth was sentenced to 30 years in prison today for fatally shooting a rafter on the Rio Grande last year.

LEAD: As any number of disabled jockeys and exercise riders can attest, riding thoroughbreds is a dangerous occupation fraught with potental injuries requiring expensive rehabilitation programs and equipment. That's why as soon as the ninth race has been run at Santa Anita race track in California today, the track's jockeys will assemble for a softball game.

LEAD: A front-page article in the Arts and Leisure section today about the new television season refers incorrectly in some copies to the network on which the television series ''Doogie Howser, M.D.'' appears. It is ABC, not NBC.

LEAD: TO PEOPLE who ''see'' Europe by hopping from one major art city to another, northern Italy's Friuli-Venezia Giulia region is nothing but a blurred landscape - flat at first, then mountainous - on the road or rail line from Venice to Vienna. Yet this multiethnic district, about three-fifths the size of Connecticut, is one of the most interesting of the country's 21 regions.

LEAD: One of the prosecution's last witnesses at the bribery trial of Representative Robert Garcia and his wife, Jane Lee, was a Harvard Law School student who worked a few years ago as an intern in the Congressman's South Bronx office.

LEAD: The majority of hardy bulbs that home gardeners are planting this fall can be bought without guilt. Tulip, hyacinth and daffodil bulbs that provide the spring splendor are raised by the billions as a crop, mainly in the Netherlands, and shipped to markets worldwide.

LEAD: A revived market for initial public offerings has yielded scant benefit for biotechnology companies. Investors perceive biotech as a high-risk business where young companies, lacking revenues and earnings from products, are difficult to evaluate by conventional means.

LEAD: The Trio Doppler - two flutists and one pianist - come from Italy and played for the first time in New York on Thursday night at Weill Recital Hall. Their music was understandably esoteric and understandably of limited quality. The great composers, needless to say, have not expended a great deal of their time on such an unusual and limited combination of instruments.

LEAD: November wedding plans for Susan H. Shagrin and Daniel J. Pitkowsky, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Pitkowsky of Berkeley Heights, N.J., have been made known by the prospective bride's parents, Sandra Zahn-Oreck of Washington and Don M. Shagrin of Los Angeles. Miss Shagrin, 26 years old, is an associate at the New York law firm of Guazzo, Perelson, Rushfield & Guazzo.

LEAD: SITTING in a yellow wheelchair outside Pathmark in the K-Mart Shopping Plaza on Route 10 here, Pat Fletcher was engrossed in conversation. As shopping carts bounced over cracks in the sidewalk and automobiles coasted by, Ms. Fletcher talked above the noise about why she spends so much time at this shopping center.

LEAD: Dr. Natalie Suzanne Bigelow, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Bradley Bigelow of New York, was married yesterday to Courtlandt Dixon Gates, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Parker McNair Gates of New York. The Rev. Frederick Hoesli officiated at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York.

LEAD: WITH the birth of our son, Nicky, we said goodbye to our yearly trips to France. There would be no more lingering over cups of cafe noir, no more walking along the Seine at 4 A.M., holding hands. Under the heading of what our travel agent calls family vacations, Martin, Nicky and I have danced the Bunny Hop with Roger Rabbit, wrenched our backs on Tilt-a-Whirls, fed smelts to Shamu and been photographed in sepia tones dressed up like Belle Starr and the James gang.

LEAD: ANY evaluation of Roslyn Estates's Classico is a tug-of-war between fine food and slack service. The food is a marvelous mix of exciting regional specialties and well-prepared Italian-American standards.

LEAD: It might not have taken Estelle M. Guzik seven years to trace her family tree if there had been a guide to genealogical resources. Now, she has edited one. The guide, Genealogical Resources in the New York Metropolitan Area, was published by the Jewish Genealogical Society and offers information on more than 100 research centers in and around New York, including libraries, archives, government agencies and courts.

LEAD: Bucking a trend, the Borland International Corporation says it can write a spreadsheet program that has more features than Lotus 1-2-3 Release 3 or Microsoft Excel and can also run nicely on a low-end office personal computer. Borland's program, Quattro Pro, was announced this month, although it will not be ready for sale until the end of the year.
LEAD: EVERYBODY is talking garbage. Conversations on this delicate topic were once limited to direct dealers, but with recycling, it's everyone down to the dump.

LEAD: A informal but festive opening was held Wednesday evening for the new and enlarged Children's Museum of Manhattan. Bette Korman, the museum's founder and executive director, thought it all up. Laurie Tisch Sussman, chairman of the museum, raised the money, and her family gave and renovated the four-story building at 212 West 83d Street.

LEAD: Anne Carmichael Childs, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Coffin Childs of Norfolk, Conn., was married in Norfolk yesterday to Charles H. Collins, a son of Nancy C. Collins of Easton, Md., and the late Francis Howard Collins 2d. The Rev. Bruce Anderson officiated at the Congregational Church of Christ.

LEAD: The marriage of Felicia Constance Pfeiffer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Pfeiffer Jr. of Glen Rock, N.J., to Michael David Angus, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Angus of Woodbridge, Ontario, took place yesterday at St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Stone Harbor, N.J. The Rev. Eugene Kernan officiated.

LEAD: ON A HOLIDAY MONDAY, THE large, labyrinthine headquarters of the Arkansas Department of Public Health, in Little Rock, is virtually empty. On call in the basement are a pair of communications specialists, whose job it is to dispatch trained personnel in the event of a medical emergency, toxic chemical spill or other threat to the commonweal.

LEAD: Streets crowded with new cars and restaurants crowded with new rich, foreign capital pouring in and stock markets taking off, luxury apartments at Fifth Avenue prices and stylish young people in the latest designs.
LEAD: Wimbledon

LEAD: Dorian Gray kept his portrait in the attic where only he could see it. The rest of us aren't as lucky. We walk around wearing ours. In this respect movie stars as fine-tuned and long-lived as Bette Davis are both blessed and damned.

LEAD: The Martha Graham Dance Company offered two quite different performances last Sunday afternoon and Tuesday night at City Center (131 West 55th Street), where the troupe is now in the second week of its three-week season.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The Justice Department has obtained a delay of at least another month in the Iran-contra trial of a former intelligence agent, Joseph F. Fernandez.

LEAD: You just never know what will pop up on jackets nowadays. A bright young New York designer named Christian Roth has adopted a Warholian approach for his creations, decorating them with giant appliques of clothespins and three-dimensional bottle caps.

LEAD: As a sociologist and alumna of Seward Park High School, I was particularly interested in Samuel G. Freedman's article. It led me to take down my copy of the yearbook for my graduating class and look at the snapshots of me and my classmates.

LEAD: FED UP with drug abuse and the crimes associated with it, DeForest Smith, a Milford real estate broker, has declared ''all-out war'' against drugs in his city. He has enlisted the aid of the police department, the schools and the business community, and his efforts have led to a drug-tip hot line that will offer callers cash rewards.
LEAD: If Ike was as bad as Truman says, why did he try to persuade him to be the Democratic candidate for President? THEODORE R. KUPFERMAN New York, N.Y.
LEAD: There is no happier sound to the merchant's ear than that of a constantly ringing cash register.

LEAD: Seeking to maintain calm in the nation's financial system, the Federal Reserve Board intends to meet any sudden demands for money that might result from the stock market's sharp plunge Friday, a top official of the nation's central bank said today.

LEAD: IT could have been in the Guinness Book of World Records, a 300 by 600 feet dropped ceiling, perhaps the world's largest. The only trouble was it was planned for the vast drill shed of the Eighth Coastal Artillery Armory, in the Bronx, completed in 1917 and now a city landmark.

LEAD: The American public as a whole views New York, San Francisco and Los Angeles as the best large cities in the country, but frequent visitors are most enthusiastic about Seattle, Boston and San Diego in addition to San Francisco and New York, according to a Gallup Poll.

LEAD: Members of the American Stock Exchange no longer conduct their business al fresco, but they still know which way the wind is blowing. Last week the Amex acted on the longstanding dictum of weapons manufacturers, housing developers and others whose prosperity is tied to national policy: If you want something from Washington, hire somebody from Washington.

LEAD: Six men whose fishing boat had sunk 40 hours earlier were rescued by a Coast Guard cutter about 50 miles northwest of Maui on Friday. The men survived by clinging to a makeshift raft of buoys and nets from their boat, which had sailed from Honolulu on Oct. 3. They suffered only bruises and dehydration, the Coast Guard said.

LEAD: Truman was squarely on target. I was a member of the regular Army and a World War II combat medic in the European Theater of Operation, twice wounded and much decorated. I revered George C. Marshall and liked Ike, until the McCarthy incident.

LEAD: The sun had barely risen, and there was still a chill in the desert air; but already cameramen, actors and prop people were scurrying about the dusty set, a small shack and lone 100-foot tower built amid the arid wasteland of northern Durango. As he waited for his crew to prepare the first shot of the day, the director, Roland Joffe, gently balanced a shiny metal hemisphere in each hand and ruminated.

LEAD: In the rarefied atmosphere of a jammed Falcon Stadium at the United States Air Force Academy tonight, the Notre Dame sophomore nicknamed Rocket explored the reaches of his personal wild blue yonder.

LEAD: Homicide cops get a pension, and hard-boiled private eyes don't expect to live long enough to retire. But amateur detectives who hope to survive in their competitive genre find it helps to have a steady day job.

LEAD: There are plenty of loaves at the bread aisle at the Food Emporium at 68th Street and Broadway in New York: Wonder Bread, Pepperidge Farm, Arnold, Taystee, Home Pride, Country Hearth, Oatmeal Goodness.

LEAD: There is something slightly incongruous about a rock band from Scotland that calls itself Texas. But that is the name adopted by the young Glasgow-based group that appeared at the Bottom Line on Wednesday evening. Like Deacon Blue, another promising young Scottish band with a growing reputation, Texas puts a Celtic stamp on American rock-and-roll forms, even while trying to sound as

LEAD: Those who cherish New York City's architectural treasures have long bemoaned the deterioration of buildings like the former P.S. 9 in Brooklyn, a Renaissance Revival edifice on Vanderbilt Avenue and Sterling Place in Prospect Heights.

LEAD: Cameron Colket Adams and John Jeming Soroko are planning a November wedding, the prospective bride's parents, David Adams 4th of Bethlehem, Pa., and Mrs. Robert John Connell of Buck Hill Falls, Pa., have announced. Mr. Soroko is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur M. Soroko of Philadelphia.
LEAD: Football
LEAD: A strange symbol of hope has been flowering in some of New York City's most troubled neighborhoods. Sculpture.

LEAD: The sunsets are sometimes a little redder and the great craggy walls are sometimes a little bluer when the particles of smog drift into the Grand Canyon from industries scattered across the American West and from polluted cities as far away as Los Angeles.

LEAD: Ever since a ''Today'' dawned last August with a new female cast member, the show's longtime co-anchor, Jane Pauley, has been rumored variously to be miffed to the point of quitting or just making a mid-career reassessment. For weeks, Ms. Pauley said little to dampen the speculation that she would be moving on after she suddenly found herself sharing the set with Deborah Norville, a 31-year-old, million-dollar-a-year newsreader.

LEAD: The recent death of a 14-year-old Mexican boy, run over by a United States Border Patrol jeep, dramatized the chaotic and sometimes violent situation that has developed as more and more illegal aliens try to enter the United States through one narrow section of the California border.

LEAD: After his team lost to Pitt and was crushed by Florida State in the last two games, the Syracuse head coach, Dick Mac Pherson, said he was glad the Orangemen's game with Penn State was here in the Carrier Dome.
