LEAD: Wonderful Harry S. Truman. Reading his private writings, I couldn't help smiling. How splendidly refreshing!

LEAD: ''When i first read 'Up Against It!' I was terrified at the thought of trying to put it on the stage,'' said Kenneth Elliott of the film script Joe Orton wrote for the Beatles in 1967. Misgivings behind him, Mr. Elliott will be directing the first professional stage performances of ''Up Against It!

LEAD: Of all the American photographers of the 1920's and 30's who were profoundly influenced by the spirit of modern art, Berenice Abbott remains one of the most underappreciated. She also has been one of the most enduring; now 91, she has lived to see the esthetic principles she adopted more than 60 years ago rise and fall with a regular historical cadence.

LEAD: As the starting pitchers in last night's World Series opener, Dave Stewart of the Athletics and Scott Garrelts of the Giants were up on a platform Friday answering questions behind a microphone in the Oakland Coliseum interview area. Their photos and quotes were in all the newspapers. Their video and audio tapes were on television and radio.
LEAD: PEEPER By Loren D. Estleman. 215 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $16.95.
LEAD: Bread has looked like bread for centuries. But the bakeries that make it have changed substantially to speed up production and reduce labor costs.

LEAD: Late in the 18th century, members of the Pierson family acquired a large chunk of what is now Sterlington in Rockland County, N.Y. They used the streams of the Ramapo Mountains to power their forges to make nails and hardwood from the forests to fire their charcoal kilns.
LEAD: In response to your ''Recycling Recipe: Easy as Pie'' (Opinion, Oct. 1), may I offer our family's recipe. Composting Kitchen Waste
LEAD: An article on Oct. 1 about the New Rochelle Art Association referred incorrectly to the illustrator of a 1923 sign, ''When a Feller Needs a Friend.'' He was Clare Briggs.

LEAD: ACCORDING to the stereotypes Westerners hold dear, Mikhail S. Gorbachev should now be apoplectic over the hemorrhage of Communist power in Europe. Poland falls into the clutches of Solidarity. The Hungarian Communist Party shuns the word Communist, then fractures and quarrels over who gets to keep the bank account.

LEAD: When Episcopal Bishop Richard F. Grein ceremonially pounded on the great bronze doors of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday, the Episcopal Church in New York was hearing the sound of a new kind of leadership.

LEAD: ''I've been walking the edge for a long time,'' William Hurt says, ''thinking about whether acting is the right thing for me to be doing. Sometimes things happen in my personal life which really make me question whether what I do is right for me. It's not right that my privacy is invaded to the extent that it is.

LEAD: THE race for County Executive entered the homestretch last week with the major-party challengers tangling repeatedly over two issues: the rising taxes needed to balance the county budget and the county's role in providing affordable housing.

LEAD: With the peak of the fall foliage season in the metropolitan region about a week away, leaf peepers who are stuck in New York City do not have to turn green with envy (or red or orange) when friends tell them about their excursions into the country to view the splendors of autumn.

LEAD: How many times have you dialed the telephone, heard a response from the other end, paused, laughed ruefully and said, ''Who is this? I forgot whom I'm calling''? The odds are that it has happened more than once. And more than likely the reverse has also occurred: you've picked up the phone and heard someone else's rueful voice with the same query.

LEAD: When Martha Graham's superb dancers begin a season on a high, and then proceed to better that exceptionally fine level of execution, it is all too easy to pay more attention to the dancing than the repertory. Nonetheless, this depth of artistry would not be possible without profound works to perform.

LEAD: Four decades after its first application for membership in the United Nations, South Korea has begun a major diplomatic effort at the current session of the General Assembly to secure support for its admission.

LEAD: With some of the nutritional myths about the empty calories in white bread dispelled, white bread has staged a mild comeback since the 70's. ''Last year, we had a slight increase in our white bread sales after years of going down,'' said a spokesman for Interstate Bakeries. ''That's significant, because you still build the brand with white bread.

LEAD: THE MOST IMPORTANT legacy of the 1980's in architecture may not be a design at all, but a book. It is a slim book, and unlike many other important works, it did not transform the thinking of an age. Rather, it summed up a whole set of impulses, and gave coherence to a time.
LEAD: When stock prices crashed two years ago, hot young technology companies suffered some of the steepest declines. The market for initial public offerings, particularly in technology, vanished.

LEAD: U.S.-Soviet differences over verification have long stalled ratification of two treaties to limit the size of underground nuclear explosions. But Moscow proposed a reasonable compromise, leaving each side free to use its own preferred method of monitoring and allowing more on-site visits. President Bush's acceptance of the offer has broken the deadlock.

Unfortunately, the Board of Examiners does not have the authority to decide if an examination should be given. That, by law, is the Chancellor's responsibility.

LEAD: FLUORESCENT lights are thrifty. They use less electricity than incandescent lights, and because they also generate less heat, their tubes last longer than incandescent bulbs.

LEAD: IF I had immigrated to New Jersey from a foreign-speaking country, I would have anticipated the need to learn a new language to make myself understood. But after my moving here from Boston, which is, after all, part of the same country - no border check, no passport - it comes as a shock that I still need an occasional interpreter after nearly 30 years.

LEAD: A growing number of women are doubling their leisure comfort - and time - by ordering their at-home uniforms through mail-order catalogues. Since a close fit is the antithesis of lounge wear, these garments are among the most frequently ordered by mail, representatives of the largest mail-order outfitters say.

LEAD: FOSSIL fuel reserves, almost always discussed with the modifier ''dwindling'' attached, are now growing rapidly. The conventional wisdom of the 1970's was that the world was running out of oil, coal and natural gas. But in the last three years governments and the companies that do the drilling and mining have found far more than has been extracted.
LEAD: Three University of Illinois students have been charged with setting a fire last month that destroyed the Astroturf at the university's football stadium.

LEAD: Adjudicating and Stella Madrid, who won Grade I races half an hour apart two weeks ago at Belmont Park, came right back and did it again yesterday to prove themselves New York's leading 2-year-olds.

LEAD: Many times I've argued with short-sighted anti-competitive sports advocates about the merits of such activities. How, win or lose, they foster social interaction, camaraderie, team spirit, promote physical and mental conditioning, and create a sense of working toward goals and dreams. Celebration of one's own or his team's performance is normal and happy to see.

LEAD: The name of the Czechoslovak composer Bohuslav Martinu is well known, but probably relatively few American listeners can claim any real familiarity with his highly individualisticmusic, even though he lived in the United States for a dozen years (1941-53) and composed five of his six symphonies for American orchestras.
LEAD: THE ANTAGONISTS Hugo Black, Felix Frankfurter and Civil Liberties in Modern America. By James F. Simon. Illustrated. 312 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

LEAD: As the latest drug war in Colombia was entering its ninth week, three people sought as low-ranking cocaine traffickers were flown here today from Bogota in a United States marshals' jet to face Federal charges in Florida and Michigan.

LEAD: Weekends are the only time many people have to prepare dishes that require long, slow cooking. The best kind are those that take very little time to assemble and can be pretty much left unwatched on the stove.
LEAD: A Delta Air Lines airliner loading passengers caught fire here today, injuring six people and leaving a four-foot hole in the fuselage, officials said.

LEAD: Greek metalwork - known more through adaptations made by Romans in antiquity and Europeans in the 18th and 19th centuries than through the originals - is far more remarkable in its vigor than are later manifestations. This can be seen in an exhibition of 38 ancient Greek artifacts, vessels and items of jewelry produced over a period of 600 years, and a companion display of 10 neoclassical urns, candelabra and vases of the 18th and 19th centuries, exhibited at the Michael Ward Gallery, 9 East 93d Street.
LEAD: Stock exchange officials are bracing for tomorrow's market opening on Wall Street.

LEAD: If television reflects reality, however hazily, we the people would seem to be mired in growing confusion. While news and ''reality'' shows adopt questionable dramatization devices, entertainment formats drift ever further into inane diversions. Meanwhile, daytime shows like ''Geraldo'' are insisting that the land is being overrun by child molesters and Satanists.

LEAD: I FIRST SAW HIM AS A FOOT, a highly polished brown cordovan wagging merrily on a hassock. I spied it through the door. It was a beautiful foot, sleek, perfectly shaped. Such casual elegance and clean lines! But not a big foot, not formidable, maybe even a little . . . frail. I imagined cradling it in my arms, protecting it from un-smooth roads.

LEAD: The concern with roots that has affected (or infected) rock in recent years takes many forms. Some young bands become obsessed with a certain period, style or attitude and become living time capsules, churning out rockabilly or 60's garage-punk or purist psychedelia while resisting the taint of more contemporary influences.

LEAD: Can a performance artist who arose from the depths of lower Manhattan bohemia retain her artistic self-possession while backstroking through the shark-infested waters of commercial popular music? And can an artist with a radically original but idiosyncratically limited style continue to grow and yet retain the stylistic signatures that distinguished her in the first place?

LEAD: Stocks had a dizzying plunge on Friday, with the Dow Jones industrial average dropping a scary 190.58 points and reviving painful memories of the 1987 stock crash that produced a 508-point plunge on Oct. 19. Friday's heavy selling wiped out all the gains from an early October rally that, just last Monday, had taken the Dow to a new high of 2,791.41.

LEAD: It's the rare photographer who hasn't been moved by the glow of the setting sun or by rays of sunlight striking a colorful flower arrangement on the kitchen table. In such cases, using flash would only spoil the effect, so the designers of cameras with built-in flash units have provided ways to keep the flash from firing.

LEAD: Transcaucasia - beyond the Caucasus Mountains: few geographical descriptions summon up for Westerners more exotic images of Asia, from Batumi on the Black Sea to Baku on the Caspian Sea, from Iran's northern border through the breadbasket of the Soviet Union in Georgia.

LEAD: The Four Nations Ensemble, an early-instruments band directed by the harpsichordist Andrew Appel, describes the boundaries of its repertory as late Renaissance and Viennese Classics. LEAD: Karl Nelson is a man of many talents.

LEAD: IN his seven years in the Florida State House of Representatives, Robert J. Shelley has been a strong opponent of abortion and has cast votes to restrict it, including one last year to require girls younger than 18 years old to obtain the consent of a parent or a judge before having an abortion.

LEAD: Mary Ellen Pamela Eckert and Kevin L. Potucek, graduates of Wichita State University, were married in New York yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. Leroy Matz. The bride, 30 years old, is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William G. Eckert of Wichita, Kan. Mr. Potucek, 30, is a son of the late Dorothy Bircher Potucek and the late Joseph Potucek Jr.

LEAD: ''Here's your basic convict,'' Sam Cornish said. ''This ghoul here is our own design. Over there is Lucky Lemon Lio. That's for next year. If you need a barbarian ax or some monster hands, they're over against the wall.''

LEAD: AS the political crisis enveloping Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi deepened last week, with newspapers reporting that efforts to cover up kickbacks from a Swedish arms deal reached higher and higher in his administration, there was one place that the hottest topic in this parliamentary democracy was barely discussed at all.
LEAD: With four races left in the Nascar Winston Cup season, it appears that the title will go to either Dale Earnhardt or Rusty Wallace.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: It was helpful for Mr. Freedman to characterize some of the injustices engendered by the bureaucracy at 110 Livingston Street, but his gloom and doom portrayal of Seward Park High School missed the mark. It is true that this school has a large non-English-speaking population, a reflection of the community it serves.

LEAD: An illustration on Sept. 24 in The Business World, part 2 of The Times Magazine, with an article about German and Japanese investment in the United States, showed the West German flag upside down. The top stripe should be black, the middle stripe red and the bottom stripe gold.

LEAD: TO celebrate my birthday, some of my family gathered for the weekend at my son's country house in Vermont. It was a special birthday because it marked the gateway to what we call the golden years. From now on I can claim discounts on trains and buses and in certain stores. I am also eligible for a Medicare card with its reassurance of health care.

LEAD: If you are exiting from the Holland Tunnel in New Jersey, a right turn takes you to Hoboken and a left to Jersey City. In either direction lies one of the top high school running backs in New Jersey.

LEAD: NOSTALGIA WILL BE THE PRE-dominant theme at this fall's International Home Furnishings Market in High Point, N.C., where showrooms will feature such 19th-century styles as Victorian, Biedermeier and century-old Russian. To see such traditional merchandise is not unusual at High Point, the largest wholesale furniture market in the country.

LEAD: Katherine Ann Hudson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fletcher L. Hudson of Germantown, Tenn., was married yesterday to David George Zrike, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond W. Zrike of Greenwich, Conn. Msgr. Thomas P. Guinan and the Rev. James P. M. Walsh performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Michael the Archangel Church in

LEAD: Mark Twain on a visit to Australia called Sydney Harbor ''a wonder of the world.'' The vast expanse of water with its coves and inlets extending from North Head to the Parramatta is the heart of Sydney. The city wraps itself around the water's edge and along the promontories, which run like fingers on the hills above the shoreline.
LEAD: More than 11,000 Vietnamese boat people in detention centers here staged a hunger strike today to protest repatriation to their homeland, officials said.

LEAD: Just as Congress completes one of its most embarrassing failures to meet the requirements of the deficit-reduction law, lawmakers in both parties appear to be focusing seriously on ways to change the statute.

LEAD: Carlos Kleiber: Enigma, maverick or genius? Opinions about the most mercurial conductor of his generation range widely: He is unpredictable, unwilling to commit himself to future projects and reticent in dealing with the world at large. Many artists say they hardly ever give interviews; Mr. Kleiber has never been known to give one.

LEAD: IN New York City, where garage space rents for as much as a small apartment and a single space sells for more than $20,000, it is little wonder that the right to a rent-stabilized parking space, or at least the right to retain a place on a building's waiting list, has become an issue worth fighting for.
LEAD: For two games, at least, the 86th World Series will be on even terms.
LEAD: Fourteen members of the San Francisco Giants and the Oakland Athletics were not far from their hometowns when the all-California World Series opened last night.

LEAD: The engagement of Lynda Kathryn Jones to Johan Willem Edward Maitland, a son of Caro Maitland of Houston and the late Edward Jan Maitland, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth J. Jones of Larchmont, N.Y. A November wedding is planned.

LEAD: Elizabeth Kasson Simard and Edward Stillman Richardson were married yesterday at the United Congregational Church of Rowayton, Conn., by the Rev. John S. Livingston. Mrs. Richardson, 25 years old and a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Simard of Rowayton, graduated from Moravian College. She is a promotion supervisor at Woman's Day magazine in New York.

LEAD: To the dismay of many New York doctors and advocates for people with AIDS, a key laboratory test that can show whether an AIDS virus infection is progressing is all but unavailable in the New York State, although it is readily available elsewhere.
LEAD: The Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission has voted to relax restrictions on recreational and commercial fishing for striped bass next year.

LEAD: If there ever was a playwright who could find evil in a bright field of wild flowers or corruption in a baby's breath, it was that scourge of Brazil, Nelson Rodrigues. There could hardly be a better introduction to his work than the two plays - ''Family Album'' and ''All Nudity Will Be Punished'' - that the Brazilian director Antunes Filho has combined under the title ''Nelson 2 Rodrigues.
LEAD: Before the World Series began, the San Francisco Giants conceded that the Oakland Athletics had the edge in pitching. Nothing changed their minds tonight.

LEAD: No scandal in Congress this year is more outrageous than the budget mess. Both houses and both parties have failed in their duty to cut the deficit. President Bush did no better. Putting aside all the hogwash and politicking, it is clear that they're all creating problems, not solving them.

LEAD: For the program of her New York debut recital at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday evening, Donna Amato chose Russian and French piano works that revel in chromaticism. But her approach was often so heavy - either because she prefers a forceful touch or because she misjudged the volume of sound it takes to fill the intimate hall - that the opportunities the music affords for subtle coloristic interplay were often squandered.

LEAD: Megan C. Rauscher, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frank J. Rauscher Jr. of Weston, Conn., and Kenneth M. Brooks Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Brooks of Saratoga, Calif., were married yesterday in a ceremony performed by the Rev. Jeffrey Dugan, an Episcopal priest, at Christ and Holy Trinity Church in Westport,
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau will give two recitals at Carnegie Hall early next month, one devoted to Schubert and the other to Richard Strauss. The German baritone's first program, on Nov. 3, will offer poems of Goethe set to music by Schubert; the Strauss recital will take place Nov. 5. Hartmut Holl will be the accompanist.

LEAD: After the young Islanders squandered a 3-0 lead in their home opener and settled for a 3-3 tie with the Philadelphia Flyers today, the veterans Bryan Trottier and Don Maloney chose to stress the positive view that comes with experience.

LEAD: IN the next 60 days, Suffolk County will adopt a budget for 1990. An annual budget is the most important statement of public policy that our elected officials develop as part of their public responsibilities. It separates intentions and talk from action. The budget consolidates both fiscal and social policies.
LEAD: Walter Sisulu, South Africa's second leading jailed black nationalist after Nelson Mandela, was returned to his home today by the police after 25 years in prison.

LEAD: A secret Government report has been issued bitterly attacking the ousted Communist Party leader, Zhao Ziyang, for economic mismanagement. It is a new step in the campaign to hold Mr. Zhao responsible for China's economic and political problems.
LEAD: Sylvain Turgeon and Pat Verbeek, two forwards traded for each other, made big early contributions for the Devils and the Whalers in tonight's game at the Civic Center.

LEAD: If Truman were alive today, he would have even more reasons not to like Ike. Eisenhower made the decisions to overthrow the Governments of Mossadegh in Iran and Arbenz in Guatemala. As a result, the Shah was replaced by Khomeini and Central America is in turmoil. GEORGE JOCHNOWITZ New York, N.Y.

LEAD: Vasya Surin saw the aliens. In a park in Voronezh, 300 miles southeast of Moscow. Tass, the official Soviet news agency, said so, in a straight-faced report that conveniently, and perhaps not coincidentally, provided the Soviet public last week with plenty to ponder besides bare food shelves and chaotic politics.

LEAD: According to President Truman, his successor pushed Castro into the arms of the Soviets. He believes this could have been prevented if only Eisenhower had befriended Castro and showered him with financial assistance.

LEAD: ON Tuesday a committee is scheduled to meet in Washington in an effort to standardize state rules on identifying autos that transport people with mobility handicaps. The committee of 15, convening at the Department of Transportation, includes representatives of the handicapped as well as officials from state and

LEAD: A young recruit who worked three years to qualify for the Milwaukee police force shot himself to death at a firing range after failing his final chance at a marksmanship test. The recruit, Daniel Morales, 21 years old, was firing at the third and final target at the Police Training Academy when he turned his .357 revolver to his head and shot himself, a police spokesman said.
LEAD: FIORELLO H. LA GUARDIA AND THE MAKING OF MODERN NEW YORK By Thomas Kessner. Illustrated. 700 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Publishing Company. $24.95.
